initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -35,6 +35,8 @@
 <!-- cut this: It is spoken by nearly 400,000 people; 250,000 of those in the [[Crimea|Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], about 200,000 were in [[Uzbekistan]] before the [[ethnic cleansing]]s, nearly 3,000 in [[Russia]]. -->
 More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in the [[19th century]]. Crimean Tatars in Turkey can usually speak Crimean Tatar.
 
+About 40,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Romania]].
+
 == History, dialects and alphabet ==
 
 The spoken language of the Crimean Tatars is known since the [[13th century]] and divides into three main dialects: "Kypshak-Tatar" from the Crimea; "Kypchak-Nogay" from the northern steppes; and the coastal "Crimea-Osman". The [[Chagatai language]] also served the Crimean Tatar as a [[Dachsprache]]. Since the islamification these people wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
llm_output:
Added information about the number of Crimean Tatars living in Romania.

Not Weaponised. The change provides demographic information without invoking any contentious narratives or perspectives related to the ongoing conflict over Crimea.

 More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in the [[19th century]]. Crimean Tatars in Turkey can usually speak Crimean Tatar.
 
-<!-- more soon...
-Geschichte, Dialekte und Alphabete
+== History, dialects and alphabet ==
 
-Die Sprachen der Krimtataren ist uns seit dem 13. Jahrhundert bekannt und zerfiel in drei große Dialekte: "Kyptschak-Tatarisch" auf der eigentlichen Krim, "Kyptschak-Nogaiisch" in den nördlichen Steppengebieten und an den Küstenläufen "Krim-Osmanisch". Als Dachsprache diente auch den Krimtataren das Tschagataiische. Seit der Islamisierung schrieb diese Volksgruppe mit persisch-arabischen Schriftzeichen.
+The spoken language of the Crimean Tatars is known since the [[13th century]] and divides into three main dialects: "Kypshak-Tatar" from the Crimea; "Kypchak-Nogay" from the northern steppes; and the coastal "Crimea-Osman". The [[Chagatai language]] also served the Crimean Tatar as a [[Dachsprache]]. Since the islamification these people wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
+
+In [[1876]] the completely different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language, with a preference given to the more southern dialect  in order to break the link between the Tatar and the Turkish of the [[Ottoman Empire]].
+
+In [[1928]] the alphabet was replaced with the then [[Uniform Turkisch Alphabet]] (a combination of the [[Latin alphabet]] and the [[Cyrillic alphabet]]), which however was in 1938 itself replaced with a modified Cyrillic Alphabet.
+
+After the repatriation of the Crimean Tatars it was Latinized again.
+
+In [[1992]]/[[1993|93]] Crimean Tatar was made the third official language of the peninsula, as by then its speakers made up 10% of the population.
+
+The Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
+
+Since 2002 the Crimean Tatars have been writing with a new [[Turkish alphabet]],
+that was jointly developed from Turkish and Crimean Tatar students at the 
+[[University of Istanbul]] for the Crimean Tatar language.
+
+<!-- cannot translate this: Krimtatarisch wurde Als engste Verwandte der Krimtataren gelten die Türken und die jüdischen Krimtschaken.
 -->
 
-Crimean Tatar has 3 dialects.
+Crimean Tatar has been spoken by Crimean [[Greeks]], [[Gypsies]], [[Jews]], and [[Karaims]].
 
-Literary language for all dialects became in 1930's. Used Arabic script. Latinized in 1928, cyrillized in 1939. After repatriation of Crimean Tatars it was Latinized again. The Crimean Tatar alphabet is [[Turkish alphabet]] plus [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
-
-Crimean Tatar is/was spoken by Crimean Greeks, Gypsies, Jews, Karaims.
-
-Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].
+Crimean Tatar is the native language of the Crimean Tatar poet Bekir Sidki Çobanzade. <-- best guess -->
 
 The language code is CRH.

changed_version:

+++ 
@@ -1,8 +1,47 @@
 <!-- It's very difficult to convert this to comprehensible English, so I will soon translate the more thorough German article instead. -->
 
-'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatar]]s''', sometimes considered as a dialect of the [[Tatar language]]. This language is  between Kazan Tatar and Turkish. It is spoken by nearly 400,000 people; 250,000 of those in the [[Crimea|Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], about 200,000 were in [[Uzbekistan]] before the [[ethnic cleansing]]s <!-- ? how many now ? -->, nearly 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in the [[19th century]]. Crimean Tatars in Turkey can usually speak Crimean Tatar. <!-- I hope that's what was meant. -->
+The '''Crimean Tatar language''' or '''Crimean-Turkish''' (in own script: ''Qırımtatar tili'', ''Qırım Tatar dili'' resp. ''Kırım Tatar dili''; alternative notation: ''Qırım Türkçesi'' resp. ''Kırım Türkçesi'') is the language of the [[Crimean Tatar]]s.
 
-Crimean Tatar has 3 dialects. But since the deportation in [[1944]] dialects disappeared. <!-- Again, I hope that's what was meant. But where are the sources for more dialects? -->
+Abbreviated forms of the language designation are: ''Qırım Tatarçası'' resp. ''Kırım Tatarçası'' (Crimean Tatar) and from the Turkish: ''Qırım Tatar Türkçesi '' resp. ''Kırım Tatar Türkçesi'' (Crimean-Turkish).
+<!-- Could a Turkish reader please check this? -->
+
+Because of its history, it has often been counted as belonging to the 
+Kyptschak-Tatar <!-- english equivalent? West-Turkish-Tatar? -->, however it is closer to the Turkish than to the usual Tatar languages: it is closer to South-Turkish than West-Turkish.
+
+The following newspaper report compares the Crimean Tatar and Turkish languages:
+{| border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" align="center"
+|+'''Comparing Crimean Tatar vs  Turkish'''
+|-
+! style="background:#CFCFCF;" | ''Crimean Tatar''

+|  Meclis Haberleri 10.09.2003//Qırımtatar Milliy Meclisiniñ 120-cı toplaşuvı olıp keçti
+2003 senesi 7 sentăbr künü Aqmescitteki İslam Merkeziniñ binasında Qırımtatar Milliy Meclisiniñ 120-cı toplaşuvı olıp keçti. Toplaşuvda... 
+|-
+! style="background:#CFCFCF;" | ''Turkish'' 
+|-
+|Meclis Haberleri 10.09.2003// Kırım Tatar Millî Meclisi’nin 120. toplantısı yapıldı
+7 Eylül 2003 tarihinde Akmescit’teki İslam Merkezi binasında Kırım Tatar Millî Meclisi’nin genişletilmiş 120. toplantısı gerçerkleşti. Toplantıda...
+|-
+|-
+|}
+These languages are quite similar.
+
+== Number of speakers ==
+
+Today there are over 300,000 Crimean Tatar speakers.
+
+Until [[1989]] 90% of the Crimean Tatars lived in the [[Fergana Valley]] within Uzbekistan, whence they were focibly deported in 1944. Today 250,000 Crimean Tatar live in Crimea.
+
+<!-- cut this: It is spoken by nearly 400,000 people; 250,000 of those in the [[Crimea|Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], about 200,000 were in [[Uzbekistan]] before the [[ethnic cleansing]]s, nearly 3,000 in [[Russia]]. -->
+More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in the [[19th century]]. Crimean Tatars in Turkey can usually speak Crimean Tatar.
+
+<!-- more soon...
+Geschichte, Dialekte und Alphabete
+
+Die Sprachen der Krimtataren ist uns seit dem 13. Jahrhundert bekannt und zerfiel in drei große Dialekte: "Kyptschak-Tatarisch" auf der eigentlichen Krim, "Kyptschak-Nogaiisch" in den nördlichen Steppengebieten und an den Küstenläufen "Krim-Osmanisch". Als Dachsprache diente auch den Krimtataren das Tschagataiische. Seit der Islamisierung schrieb diese Volksgruppe mit persisch-arabischen Schriftzeichen.
+-->
+
+Crimean Tatar has 3 dialects.
 
 Literary language for all dialects became in 1930's. Used Arabic script. Latinized in 1928, cyrillized in 1939. After repatriation of Crimean Tatars it was Latinized again. The Crimean Tatar alphabet is [[Turkish alphabet]] plus [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.

+The language code is CRH.
 
-[http://tatar.net Tatar.Net]

More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

-== History, dialects, and alphabet ==
-The spoken language of the Crimean Tatars has existed since the [[13th century]], and consists of three main dialects: "Kypchak-Tatar" from the [[Crimean Mountains]], "Kypchak-Nogay" from the northern steppes, and the coastal "Crimea-Osman". The [[Chagatai language]] also served the Crimean Tatar as a [[Dachsprache]]. After [[Islamification]], these people wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
+== Dialects ==
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) is of [[Kypchak]] origine, Yalıboylus who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944 speak an [[Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], while the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two others. Modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect as the Tats comprise about 55% of total Crimean Tatar population and as their dialect is equaly understandable for the speakers of the others.
 
-In [[1876]] different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language, with a preference given to the more southern dialect in order to break the link between the Tatar and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]].
+== History == 
+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects had begun with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended in general during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]] Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
 
-In [[1928]] the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]], a combination of the [[Latin alphabet]] and the [[Cyrillic alphabet]]).  The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in 1938 a modified Cyrillic alphabet.
+In [[1876]] different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of Yalıboylus in order to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]] it was reorientated to the middle dialect.

-<!-- It's very difficult to convert this to comprehensible English, so I will soon translate the more thorough German article instead. -->
 
 '''Crimean Tatar language''' (''Qırımtatar tili'', ''Qırımtatarca''), also known as '''Crimean''' (''Qırım tili'', ''Qırımca'') and '''Crimean Turkish''' (''Qırım Türkçesi'') is the language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is spoken in [[Crimea]], the former [[Soviet Union]], and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s in [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]].
 
-Because of its history, this language has often been counted as being descended from [[Kypchak language|Kypchak]] Tatar, and a  Northwestern [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]], however, it has been also influenced by the Oguz [[Turkish language|Turkish]]. A Crimean Tatar speaker can undestand both [[Kypchak]] and [[Oghuz]] Turkish/Turkic.
+== Number of speakers ==
+Today there are over 300,000 Crimean Tatar speakers.
 
+Until [[1989]], 90% of the Crimean Tatars lived in [[Uzbekistan]], where they were forcibly deported in 1944.  Today 250,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea,  around 150,000 are still in exile in Uzbekistan, about 24,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Romania]] and another 3,000 live in [[Bulgaria]].
+
+More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars who emigrated in the [[19th century]]. Crimean Tatars in Turkey can usually speak Crimean Tatar.
+<!-- I count: 250K in Crimea, 24K in Romania, 3K in Bulgaria = 277K so far. If 1500K in Turkey can "usually" speak CT, doesn't that put us way over 300K? -->
+
+== Dialects ==
+Each of the three sub ethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944 speak an [[Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], while the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two others. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. Modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect as the Tats comprise about 55% of total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally understandable for the speakers of the others.
+
+== History == 
+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects had begun with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]] Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
+
+In [[1876]] different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of Yalıboylus in order to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]] it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
+
+In [[1928]] the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet|Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in [[1938]] a modified [[Cyrillic alphabet]].
+
+Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Sıdkı Çobanzade]].
+
+== Current Situation ==
+After the repatriation of the Crimean Tatars, the alphabet was Latinized again. The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
+
+Currently, Crimean Tatar does not have an official language status in Crimea. Before the [http://www.iccrimea.org/surgun60.html Sürgün], it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
+
+== Crimean Tatar in comparison with other languages ==
+Because of its history, this language has often been counted as being descended from [[Kypchak language|Kypchak]] Turkic. But actually Crimean Tatar is similar to both Kypchak and Oghuz Turkic languages. So, a Crimean Tatar speaker can understand languages of both Kypchak and Oghuz origin. Among the living Turkic languages the most close to Crimean Tatar are [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Urum language|Urum]] of the Oghuz group and [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]] and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]] of the Kypchak group. Crimean [[Karaim language|Karaim]] and [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]] languages are often cosidered to be variants of Crimean Tatar.
+
+=== Crimean Tatar and Turkish ===
 The following newspaper report compares the Crimean Tatar and Turkish languages:

 == Dialects ==
-Each of the three sub ethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944 speak an [[Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], while the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two others. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. Modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect as the Tats comprise about 55% of total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally understandable for the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three sub ethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. Modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect as the Tats comprise about 55% of total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally understandable for the speakers of the others.
 
 == History == 
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects had begun with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]] Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.

-After the repatriation of the Crimean Tatars, the alphabet was Latinized again. The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
 
 Currently, Crimean Tatar does not have an official language status in Crimea. Before the [http://www.iccrimea.org/surgun60.html Sürgün], it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

 == Dialects ==
-Each of the three sub ethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. Modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect as the Tats comprise about 55% of total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally understandable for the speakers of the others.
 
 == History == 
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]] Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.

 == Number of speakers ==

+Today, more than 250,000 Crimean Tatars are living in the Crimea, and another 250,000 are still in exile in Central Asia. There is an estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin living in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania, Poland, Finland, the United States, and Central Asia, especially Uzbekistan.
 
 == Dialects ==
 Each of the three sub ethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944 speak an [[Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], while the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two others. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. Modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect as the Tats comprise about 55% of total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally understandable for the speakers of the others.

 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].
 
 == Current Situation ==
+According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its Supreme Rada (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive goverment documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.
 
-Currently, Crimean Tatar does not have an official language status in Crimea. Before the [http://www.iccrimea.org/surgun60.html Sürgün], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
+Before the [http://www.iccrimea.org/surgun60.html Sürgün], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
 
 == Crimean Tatar in comparison with other languages ==
 Because of its history, this language has often been counted as being descended from [[Kypchak language|Kypchak]] Turkic. Actually, Crimean Tatar is similar to both Kypchak and [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] Turkic languages. A Crimean Tatar speaker can understand languages of both Kypchak and Oghuz origin. Among the living Turkic languages, the closest to Crimean Tatar are [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Urum language|Urum]] of the Oghuz group, [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]] of the Kypchak group. Crimean [[Karaim language|Karaim]] and [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]] languages are often cosidered to be variants of Crimean Tatar.
comment: /* Current Situation */ explanation about official status in the Autonomous Republic of Crimea per its constitution

Added a statement regarding the official status of Russian and Crimean Tatar languages in the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, highlighting the constitutional protections and contrasting it with the Ukrainian constitution.

Not Weaponised – The change presents factual information about language status without employing loaded or politically charged terminology.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -10,7 +10,7 @@
 |fam3=[[Kypchak languages|Kypchak]]/[[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]]
 |iso2=crh|iso3=crh}}
 
-The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımtatarca}}), also known as '''Crimean''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımca}}) and '''Crimean Turkish''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım Türkçesi}}) is the language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is spoken in [[Crimea]], Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s in [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]]. It is not to be confused with the [[Qazan Tatar language]].
+The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımtatarca}}), also known as '''Crimean''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımca}}) and '''Crimean Turkish''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım Türkçesi}}) is the language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is spoken in [[Crimea]], Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s in [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]]. It is not to be confused with the [[Tatar language|Tatar (Qazan Tatar) language]].
 
 == Number of speakers ==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (24,000), Bulgaria (3,000), [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and the United States.
llm_output:
Rephrased a reference to the Tatar language from "Qazan Tatar language" to "Tatar (Qazan Tatar) language".

Not Weaponised. The change is a clarification in terminology without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -27,8 +27,8 @@
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].
 
-== Current Situation ==
-According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its Supreme Rada (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive goverment documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.
+== Current situation ==
+According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its Supreme Rada (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.
 
 Before the [http://www.iccrimea.org/surgun60.html Sürgün], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

 == Number of speakers ==

+Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (24,000), Bulgaria (3,000), [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and the United States.
 
 == Dialects ==
-Each of the three sub ethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944 speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. Modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect as the Tats comprise about 55% of total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally understandable for the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 == History == 
-The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]] Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
 
-In [[1876]] different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of Yalıboylus in order to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]] it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
+In [[1876]], the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]], it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
 
-In [[1928]] the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in [[1938]] by a modified [[Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
+In [[1928]], the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in [[1938]] by a modified [[Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].
 
@@ -53,7 +53,7 @@
 As can be seen these languages are quite similar.
 
 === Crimean Tatar and Tatar ===
-Because of its common name, Crimean ''Tatar'' is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of the [[Tatar language]]. Though these tongues are related (as both are Turkic), the Kypchak tongues closest to Crimean Tatar are (as was mentioned above) [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]] and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]], not the Tatar language.
+Because of its common name, Crimean ''Tatar'' is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of the [[Tatar language]]. Although these tongues are related (as both are Turkic), the Kypchak tongues closest to Crimean Tatar are (as was mentioned above) [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]] and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]], not the Tatar language.
 
 == External links ==
 *[http://korpus.juls.savba.sk/QIRIM/ Linguistic corpus of Crimean Tatar language]

Not Weaponised. The changes are purely editorial and do not introduce any politically charged language or narratives that could be considered weaponisation of cultural heritage.

More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

--- 
+++ 
@@ -10,7 +10,7 @@
 |fam3=[[Kypchak languages|Kypchak]]/[[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]]
 |iso2=crh|iso3=crh}}
 
-The '''[[Crimean Tatar language]]''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımtatarca}}), also known as '''Crimean''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımca}}) and '''Crimean Turkish''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım Türkçesi}}) is the language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is spoken in [[Crimea]], Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s in [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]]. It is not to be confused with the [[Tatar language|Qazan Tatar language]].
+The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımtatarca}}), also known as '''Crimean''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımca}}) and '''Crimean Turkish''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım Türkçesi}}) is the language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is spoken in [[Crimea]], Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s in [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]]. It is not to be confused with the [[Tatar language|Qazan Tatar language]].
 
 == Number of speakers ==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (24,000), Bulgaria (3,000), [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and the United States.

 == Dialects ==

This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others. http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Crimean_Tatar_language

+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others. http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Crimean_Tatar_language
 
 == History == 
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.

 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.

Crimean Tatar-speaking world
}} The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımtatarca}}), also known as '''Crimean''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımca}}) and '''Crimean Turkish''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım Türkçesi}}) is the language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is spoken in [[Crimea]], Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s in [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]]. It is not to be confused with the [[Tatar language|Qazan Tatar language]]. -== Number of speakers == +==Number of speakers== + Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (24,000), Bulgaria (3,000), [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and the United States. -== Dialects == +==Dialects== + Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the Tats from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others. -== History == +==History== + The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script. In [[1876]], the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]], it was reoriented to the middle dialect. @@ -27,13 +30,15 @@ Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]]. -== Current situation == +==Current situation== + According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its Supreme Rada (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate. Before the [http://www.iccrimea.org/surgun60.html Sürgün], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]]. -== Script == -=== Crimean Tatar latin alphabet === +==Script== +===Crimean Tatar latin alphabet=== + {| style="font-family:Arial Unicode MS; font-size:1.4em; border-color:#000000; border-width:1px; border-style:solid; border-collapse:collapse; background-color:#F8F8EF" | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | A a | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | B b @@ -70,10 +75,11 @@ | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | Y y | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | Z z |} + '''Â â''' symbol is not considered to be a separate letter. +===Crimean Tatar cyrillic alphabet=== -=== Crimean Tatar cyrillic alphabet === {| style="font-family:Arial Unicode MS; font-size:1.4em; border-color:#000000; border-width:1px; border-style:solid; border-collapse:collapse; background-color:#F8F8EF" | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | А а | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | Б б @@ -119,10 +125,11 @@ |} '''гъ''', '''къ''', '''нъ''' and '''дж''' are separate letters. -== Crimean Tatar in comparison with other languages == +==Crimean Tatar in comparison with other languages== + Because of its history, this language has often been counted as being descended from [[Kypchak language|Kypchak]] Turkic. Actually, Crimean Tatar is similar to both Kypchak and [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] Turkic languages. A Crimean Tatar speaker can understand languages of both Kypchak and Oghuz origin. Among the living Turkic languages, the closest to Crimean Tatar are [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Urum language|Urum]] of the Oghuz group, [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]] of the Kypchak group. Crimean [[Karaim language|Karaim]] and [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]] languages are often cosidered to be variants of Crimean Tatar. -=== Crimean Tatar and Turkish === +===Crimean Tatar and Turkish=== The following newspaper report compares the Crimean Tatar and Turkish languages: {| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" align="center" @@ -139,17 +146,17 @@ |} As can be seen these languages are quite similar. -=== Crimean Tatar and Tatar === +===Crimean Tatar and Tatar=== + Because of its common name, Crimean ''Tatar'' is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of the [[Tatar language]]. Although these tongues are related (as both are Turkic), the Kypchak tongues closest to Crimean Tatar are (as was mentioned above) [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]] and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]], not the Tatar language. -== External links == -*[[wikt:category:Crimean Tatar language|Wiktionary's category of Crimean Tatar words]] -*[http://korpus.juls.savba.sk/QIRIM/ Linguistic corpus of Crimean Tatar language] -*[http://www.qurultay.org/eng/default.asp Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People (English)] -*[http://www.kirimtatar.net/tatarca/dil.html Kırımtatar Dili (Turkish)] -*Wiktionary's category of Crimean Tatar words(Turkish)[http://tr.wiktionary.org/wiki/Kategori:K%C4%B1r%C4%B1m_Tatarca_kelimeler] +==External links== {{Incubator|code=crh}} - +* [[wikt:category:Crimean Tatar language|Wiktionary's category of Crimean Tatar words]] +* [http://korpus.juls.savba.sk/QIRIM/ Linguistic corpus of Crimean Tatar language] +* [http://www.qurultay.org/eng/default.asp Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People (English)] +* [http://www.kirimtatar.net/tatarca/dil.html Kırımtatar Dili (Turkish)] +* Wiktionary's category of Crimean Tatar words(Turkish)[http://tr.wiktionary.org/wiki/Kategori:K%C4%B1r%C4%B1m_Tatarca_kelimeler] {{Altaic languages}} {{Turkic languages}}

+According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]] (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.
 
-Before the [http://www.iccrimea.org/surgun60.html Sürgün], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
+Before the [[Sürgün]], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
 
 ==Script==
 ===Crimean Tatar latin alphabet===

 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tats]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tats]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.

}} -The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımtatarca}}), also known as '''Crimean''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım tili}}, {{lang-crh2|Qırımca}}) and '''Crimean Turkish''' ({{lang-crh2|Qırım Türkçesi}}) is the language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -24,7 +24,7 @@
 
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
 
-In [[1876]], the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]], it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
+In [[1876]], the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]], it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
 
 In [[1928]], the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in [[1938]] by a modified [[Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of a sentence regarding the preference given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus. The original text stated that the preference was given "to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the Ottoman Empire," while the revised text states it was given "not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the Ottoman Empire."

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change clarifies the intent behind the preference for the dialect without introducing any weaponisation terms or narratives.

 According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its Supreme Rada (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.

 == Crimean Tatar in comparison with other languages ==
 Because of its history, this language has often been counted as being descended from [[Kypchak language|Kypchak]] Turkic. Actually, Crimean Tatar is similar to both Kypchak and [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] Turkic languages. A Crimean Tatar speaker can understand languages of both Kypchak and Oghuz origin. Among the living Turkic languages, the closest to Crimean Tatar are [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Urum language|Urum]] of the Oghuz group, [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]] of the Kypchak group. Crimean [[Karaim language|Karaim]] and [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]] languages are often cosidered to be variants of Crimean Tatar.

 ==Number of speakers==
 
-Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. +Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (24,000), Bulgaria (3,000), [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and the United States. It is one of seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -18,7 +18,7 @@
 
 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars have their own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tats]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tats]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.

'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. {{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -18,7 +18,7 @@
 
 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tats]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars have their own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tats]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 ==History==
llm_output:
Changed "has its own dialect" to "have their own dialect".

Not Weaponised. The change is a grammatical correction and does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

 ==Crimean Tatar in comparison with other languages==
 
-Because of its history, this language has often been counted as being descended from [[Kypchak language|Kypchak]] Turkic. Actually, Crimean Tatar is similar to both Kypchak and [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] Turkic languages. A Crimean Tatar speaker can understand languages of both Kypchak and Oghuz origin. Among the living Turkic languages, the closest to Crimean Tatar are [[Azerbaijani Language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Urum language|Urum]] of the Oghuz group, [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]] of the Kypchak group. Crimean [[Karaim language|Karaim]] and [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]] languages are often considered variants of Crimean Tatar. It is very distantly related to [[Tartar]].
+Because of its history, this language has often been counted as being descended from [[Kypchak language|Kypchak]] Turkic. Actually, Crimean Tatar is similar to both Kypchak and [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] Turkic languages. A Crimean Tatar speaker can understand languages of both Kypchak and Oghuz origin. Among the living Turkic languages, the closest to Crimean Tatar are [[Azerbaijani Language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Urum language|Urum]] of the Oghuz group, [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], and [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]] of the Kypchak group. Crimean [[Karaim language|Karaim]] and [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]] languages are often considered variants of Crimean Tatar. It is not closely related to [[Tatar language|Tatar]].

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
 
-In [[1876]], the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In [[1928]], it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
-
-In [[1928]], the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in [[1938]] by a modified [[Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
+In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.

+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in 1938 by a modified [[Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].

 According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]] (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.

@@ -18,7 +18,7 @@
 
 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tats Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 ==History==

+Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (24,000), Bulgaria (3,000), [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and the United States. It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
 
 ==Dialects==

+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an Arabic script.
 
 In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.

Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

 ==History==
 
-The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with a Persian-Arab script.
+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an Arab script.
 
 In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
llm_output:
Changed "Persian-Arab script" to "Arab script".

Not Weaponised. The change is a clarification of terminology without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@
 
 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 ==History==
llm_output:
Rephrased a sentence for clarity regarding the dialects of the Crimean Tatars.

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor rephrasing that does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage weaponisation.

 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the [[Noğays]] - the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, [[Yalıboylus]], who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 ==History==

 ==Number of speakers==
 
-Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (24,000), Bulgaria (3,000), [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and the United States. It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>

The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an Arabic script.
 
-In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[İsmail Gaspıralı]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
+In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus not to break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
 
 In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.

 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays - the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) - is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.

This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. -According to the constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea, as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]] (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian - ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.

Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

changed_version:

@@ -35,7 +35,7 @@
 
 In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin alphabet]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since the 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since the 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -30,7 +30,7 @@
 
 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tats|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 ==History==
