 ==Dialects==
 
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic. The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic.{{fact}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 ==History==

 ==Number of speakers==

 Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
 
 ==History==
-The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an Arabic script.
+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
 
 In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.

 ==Dialects==
 Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.
@@ -114,6 +114,7 @@
 Before the [[Sürgün]], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
 
 ==Writing systems==
+Crimean Tatar can be written in the modified variants of either the [[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]] or [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] alphabets, respective to where the the language is used. The Latin variant is based on that of Modern Turkish, akin to other Turkic languages employing the same writing system.

 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=crh Ethnologue's entry about Crimean Tatar]</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> Bulgaria (6,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> [[Poland]]{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}, [[Finland]]{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}, [[Canada]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}}, and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>

 ==Number of speakers==

+Respectively, almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Russian, Ukrainian, Uzbek, Turkish, Bulgarian, Romanian, and Finnish.
 
 ==Dialects==
 Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.

+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]]-Nogay origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is  of Kypchak-Cuman origin. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.
 
 ==History==
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].

It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]] as well as small communities in [[Poland]], [[Finland]], the [[United States]], and [[Canada]]. It is not to be confused with the [[Tatar language|Kazan Tatar]] language spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is remotely related and with which it is not mutually intelligible.
+'''Crimean Tatar'''<ref>also called ''Crimean language'', ''Crimean Turkish''</ref> (Qırımtatarca, Qırımtatar tili, Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили) is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars|Crimean Tatar peoples]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]] as well as small communities in [[Poland]], [[Finland]], the [[United States]], and [[Canada]]. It is not to be confused with the [[Tatar language|Kazan Tatar]] language spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is quite closely related but however with which it is not mutually intelligible.
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=crh Ethnologue's entry about Crimean Tatar]</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> Bulgaria (6,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> [[Poland]]{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}, [[Finland]]{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}, [[Canada]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}}, and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>

+Respectively, almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Russian, Ukrainian, Uzbek, Turkish, Finnish, etc.
 
 ==Dialects==
 Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]] origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect very close to [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is a mixture of the two. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz Turkic.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population and their dialect is equally intelligible to the speakers of the others.

 Before the [[Sürgün]], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
 
 ==Writing systems==
-Crimean Tatar can be written in the modified variants of either the [[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]] or [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] alphabets, respective to where the the language is used. The Latin variant is based on that of Modern Turkish, akin to other Turkic languages employing the same writing system. 
+Crimean Tatar can be written in the either the [[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]] or [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] alphabets, both modified to the specific needs of Crimean Tatar, and either used respective to where the the language is used. The Latin variant is based on that of [[Turkish alphabet|Modern Turkish]].

 Respectively, almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Russian, Ukrainian, Uzbek, Turkish, Finnish, etc.
 
 ==Dialects==
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Noğays – the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]) – is of [[Kypchak]]-Nogay origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is  of Kypchak-Cuman origin. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Nogays—the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]])—is of [[Kypchak]]–Nogay origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is of Kypchak–Cuman origin. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.
 
 ==History==
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].

 In additional to these phonemes, Crimean also displays marginal phonemes that occur in borrowed words, especially [[palatalized consonants]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Kavitskaya|2010|p=10}}</ref>
 
 ==Current situation==
-According to the constitution of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]] (see [http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]), Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" (Russian – ''обеспечивается ... защита'') status; every citizen is entitled, at his request (Russian ''ходатайство''), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.

According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.
 
 Before the [[Sürgün]], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

-Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=crh Ethnologue's entry about Crimean Tatar]</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> Bulgaria (6,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> , [[Finland]],{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} [[Canada]],{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
+Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=crh Ethnologue's entry about Crimean Tatar]</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> Bulgaria (6,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> [[Poland]],{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} [[Finland]],{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} [[Canada]],{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
 
 Respectively, almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Russian, Ukrainian, Uzbek, Turkish, Finnish, etc.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

@@ -30,9 +30,9 @@
 '''Crimean Tatar'''<ref>Also called ''Crimean Turkish'' or simply ''Crimean''.</ref> (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили) is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is related, but with which it is not [[mutually intelligible]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
-Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> Bulgaria (6,000),<ref name=Ethnologue/> [[Poland]],{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} [[Finland]],{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} [[Canada]],{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
+Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
 
-Respectively, almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Russian, Ukrainian, Uzbek, Turkish, Finnish, etc.
+Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Russian, Ukrainian, Uzbek, Turkish, Finnish, etc.
 
 ==Dialects==
 Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Nogays—the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]])—is of [[Kypchak]]–Nogay origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is of Kypchak–Cuman origin. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of the sentence regarding the bilingualism of Crimean Tatars. The original sentence "Respectively, almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual..." was modified to "Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual...".

Not Weaponised. The change is a stylistic adjustment that does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.

@@ -42,7 +42,7 @@
 ==History==
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After the [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
 
-In 1876, the different Turkish Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
+In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
 
 In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since the 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
llm_output:
Removed "different Turkish" and replaced it with "different Turkic" in the sentence about the uniform written language created by Ismail Gasprinski.

Not Weaponised. The change is a linguistic clarification regarding the classification of the dialects without introducing any politically charged terminology or narratives.

+'''Crimean Tatar'''<ref>Also called ''Crimean Turkish'' or simply ''Crimean''.</ref> (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили) is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is related, but with which it is not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>

-'''Crimean Tatar'''<ref>Also called ''Crimean Turkish'' or simply ''Crimean''.</ref> (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили) is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is related, but with which it is not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' also known as Crimean Turkish<ref>Also called ''Crimean Turkish'' or simply ''Crimean''.</ref> (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили) is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is related, but with which it is not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

-In additional to these phonemes, Crimean also displays marginal phonemes that occur in borrowed words, especially [[palatalized consonants]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Kavitskaya|2010|p=10}}</ref>
+In additional to these phonemes, Crimean also displays marginal phonemes that occur in borrowed words, especially [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized consonants]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Kavitskaya|2010|p=10}}</ref>
 
 ==Current situation==
 According to the constitution of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>[http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.

 [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|250px|"Welcome to Crimea" (Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|250px|Crimean Tatar Latin script on the table in Bakhchisaray.]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|250px|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script.]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили), also called '''Crimean Turkish''' or simply '''Crimean''', is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is related, but with which it is not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили), also called '''Crimean Turkish''' {{source?}} or simply '''Crimean''', is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is related, but with which it is not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). However, of all these people, mostly the older generations still speak Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught only in around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided the greatest support to Ukraine, which has been unable to resolve the problem of education in the native language in Crimea, by bringing the schools to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], Avrupa Times, 02/19/2013</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
llm_output:
Changed the phrase "Crimean Turkish" to "Crimean Turkish {{source?}}".

Not Weaponised. The addition of a source request does not inherently alter the narrative or introduce weaponisation; it simply indicates a need for citation without changing the context or implications of the content.

It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]. The languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

 '''Crimean Tatar''' (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили), also called '''Crimean Turkish''' or simply '''Crimean''', is the indigenous language of the [[Crimean Tatars]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]], to which it is related, but with which it is not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
-Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). However, of all these people, mostly the older generations still speak the Crimean Tatar language.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught only in around 15 schools in Crimea at that point of time. Turkey has provided the greatest support to Ukraine, which has been unable to resolve the problem of education in the mother tongue in Crimea, by bringing the schools to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], Avrupa Times, 02/19/2013</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
-
-Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Ukrainian, Turkish, Uzbek, Russian, etc.
+Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan). However, of all these people, mostly the older generations still speak Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught only in around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided the greatest support to Ukraine, which has been unable to resolve the problem of education in the native language in Crimea, by bringing the schools to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], Avrupa Times, 02/19/2013</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
+
+Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Ukrainian, Turkish, Uzbek, or Russian.
 
 ==Dialects==
 Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Nogays—the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]])—is of [[Kypchak]]–Nogay origin, Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect and the middle dialect of the [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) is of Kypchak–Cuman origin. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by the Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.

+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.

-In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, it was reoriented to the middle dialect.
-
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was itself replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since the 1990s, the script is in the process of being replaced with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]] with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
+The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions to Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
+
+In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
+
+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since the 1990s, the government has encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].

 ==Current situation==
-According to the constitution of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>[http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine, so the recognition of those languages is a matter of political and legal debate.

-Before the [[Sürgün]], the deportation of Crimean Tatars to the [[Uzbek SSR]] (18 May 1944), it had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar is a matter of political and legal debate.
+
+Before the [[Sürgün]], the 18 May 1944 deportation by the Soviet Union of Crimean Tatars to internal exile in [[Uzbek SSR]], Crimean Tatar had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]. The languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

-According to the constitution of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>[http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar.  ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

@@ -41,7 +41,11 @@
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Ukrainian, Turkish, Uzbek, or Russian.
 
 ==Dialects==
-Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Nogays—the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]])—is of [[Kypchak]]–Nogay origin. The Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect. The [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) use a middle dialect of Kypchak–Cuman origin. This dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on this middle dialect because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.
+Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Nogays, the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]), is of [[Kypchak]]–Nogay origin.
+
+The Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect.
+
+The [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) use a middle dialect of Kypchak–Cuman origin. The dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on Tat because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population.
 
 ==History==
 The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].

It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]. The languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is more similar to and somewhat mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

-Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in Crimea, and approximately 150,000 are still in exile in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan).<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>

However, of all these people, mostly the older generations still speak the Crimean Tatar language.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught only in around 15 schools in Crimea at that point of time. Turkey has provided the greatest support to Ukraine, which has been unable to resolve the problem of education in the mother tongue in Crimea, by bringing the schools to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], Avrupa Times, 02/19/2013</ref> An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=Ethnologue/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=Ethnologue/> It is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>[http://iggi.unesco.or.kr/web/iggi_docs/06/952479400.pdf Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999]</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual with the dominant languages of their respective home countries such as Ukrainian, Turkish, Uzbek, Russian, etc.

Weaponised

{{flag|Republic of Crimea}} ([[Russia]]) +|nation= {{flag|Republic of Crimea}} ([[Russia]]) |minority={{flag|Ukraine}}{{cite web|title=To which languages does the Charter apply?|page=2|url=http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|work=European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages|publisher=Council of Europe}} +* {{flag|Autonomous Republic of Crimea}} |iso2=crh |iso3=crh |map=Crymean Tatar lang.png @@ -32,7 +33,7 @@ [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|250px|"Welcome to Crimea" (Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]] [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|250px|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in Bakhchisaray.]] [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|250px|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script.]] -'''Crimean Tatar''' (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили), also called '''Crimean Turkish'''http://www.ethnologue.com/language/crh or simply '''Crimean''', is the indigenous language of [[Crimea]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in Crimea and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]; the languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]]. +'''Crimean Tatar''' (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили), also called '''Crimean Turkish''' http://www.ethnologue.com/language/crh or simply '''Crimean''', is the indigenous language of [[Crimea]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in Crimea and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]; the languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]]. ==Number of speakers== Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.{{e16|crh}} In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013
comment: Not an official language, only recognized as a regional one

 [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|250px|"Welcome to Crimea" (Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|250px|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in Bakhchisaray.]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|250px|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script.]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили), also called '''Crimean Turkish''' <ref>http://www.ethnologue.com/language/crh</ref> or simply '''Crimean''', is the indigenous language of [[Crimea]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in Crimea and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]; the languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' (''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили), also called '''Crimean Turkish''' <ref>http://www.ethnologue.com/language/crh</ref> or simply '''Crimean''', is the indigenous language of [[Crimea]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in Crimea and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]; the languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. It is mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}}
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a citation needed tag at the end of the description of the Crimean Tatar language. 

**Added citation needed tag.**

Not Weaponised. The change does not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives; it simply requests a citation for the information provided.

Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. changed_version:
---

@@ -125,6 +125,9 @@
 In addition to these phonemes, Crimean also displays marginal phonemes that occur in borrowed words, especially [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized consonants]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Kavitskaya|2010|p=10}}</ref>
 
 ==Current situation==
+
+According to [[Constitution of the Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of [[Republic of Crimea|Republic of Crimea]] Crimean Tatar language is an official language in Crimea as well as [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
+
 According to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>[http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar is a matter of political and legal debate.
 
 Before the [[Sürgün]], the 18 May 1944 deportation by the Soviet Union of Crimean Tatars to internal exile in [[Uzbek SSR]], Crimean Tatar had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].
llm_output:
Added a statement regarding the official status of the Crimean Tatar language alongside Russian and Ukrainian in Crimea.

Not Weaponised. The addition provides factual information about the linguistic status in Crimea without employing loaded or politically charged language.

Though only distantly related, it is mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]], and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] due to their influence.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}}
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in Uzbekistan), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=Ethnologue>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -36,7 +36,7 @@
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|250px|"Welcome to Crimea" (''{{lang|crh|Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!}}'') written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|250px|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]]]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|250px|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили}}), also called '''Crimean Turkish'''<ref name=e18/> or simply '''Crimean''',<ref name=e18/> is the indigenous{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} language of [[Crimea]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in Crimea and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]; the languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. Though only distantly related, it is mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]], and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] due to language contact and influence.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}}
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|''Qırımtatarca'', ''Qırımtatar tili'', Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили}}), also called '''Crimean Turkish'''<ref name=e18/> or simply '''Crimean''',<ref name=e18/> is an indigenous{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} language of [[Crimea]]. It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in Crimea and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Russia]]; the languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. Though only distantly related, it is mutually intelligible with [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]], and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] due to language contact and influence.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}}
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of the description of the Crimean Tatar language, specifically altering the phrase "the indigenous" to "an indigenous" in the context of the language's description.

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor grammatical adjustment that does not introduce any weaponised narratives or perspectives related to cultural heritage.

It is a [[Turkic languages|Turkic language]] spoken in Crimea and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania and Bulgaria, as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related but not [[mutually intelligible]]. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]], and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

@@ -67,7 +67,7 @@
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Crimean Republic under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.
+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -1,5 +1,4 @@ {{distinguish|Tatar language}} -{{contradict|about=Are they mutually intelligible or not? The leads of these two articles contradict one another|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox language |name=Crimean Tatar |nativename={{lang|crh|Qırımtatarca, Qırımtatar tili}}
{{lang|crh|Къырымтатарджа, Къырымтатар тили}} @@ -44,12 +43,24 @@ Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian. -==Dialects== -Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Nogays, the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]), is of [[Kypchak]]–Nogay origin. - -The Yalıboylus, who lived on the southern coast of Crimea before 1944, speak an [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] dialect. - -The [[Tat Tatars]] from the [[Crimean Mountains]] (should not be confused with [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]]) use a middle dialect of Kypchak–Cuman origin. The dialect is a direct descendant of the [[Cuman language]], but it has been strongly influenced by Oghuz.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on Tat because the Tats comprise about 55% of the total Crimean Tatar population. +==Classification and dialects== + +Crimean Tatar is conventionally divided into three main dialects: northern, middle and southern. + +The middle dialect is spoken in the [[Crimean Mountains]] by the sedentary ''Tat'' Tatars (should not be confused with the [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]] which speak an [[Iranic language]]). The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on Tat Tatar because the Tat Tatars comprise a relative majority. + +Standard Crimean Tatar and its middle dialect classified as a language of the Pontic or Cuman ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-половецкая}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]] and the closest relatives are [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]], [[Karaim language|Karaim]], [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]], [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], [[Urum language|Urum]] and extinct [[Cuman language|Cuman]]. + +However, two other unwritten dialects of Crimean Tatar belong to two different groups or subgroups of the Turkic languages. + +The northern dialect (also known as steppe or Nogay) is spoken by the ''Noğay'' ethnic subgroup, the former nomadic inhabitants of the Crimean (Nogay) steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]] of the [[Northern Caucasus]] and the [[Lower Volga]]). This dialect belong to the Nogay ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-ногайская}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]]. This subgroups also includes [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]], [[Karakalpak language|Karakalpak]], [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]], and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] proper. It is thought that the Nogays of the Crimea and the Nogais of the Caucasus and Volga are of common origin from the [[Nogai Horde]], which is reflected in their common name and very closely related languages. In the past some speakers of this dialects also called themselves ''Qıpçaq'' (that is Cumans). + +The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by ''Yalıboylu'' ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belongs to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish. + +Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This make the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman orgin, is in fact combine elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. This latter fact may also be another reason why Standard Crimean Tatar has had its basis in the middle dialect. + +=== Volga Tatar === +Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russian belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closet relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]]. ==History== The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]]. @@ -159,33 +170,6 @@ |} '''гъ''', '''къ''', '''нъ''' and '''дж''' are separate letters ([[digraph (orthography)|digraphs]]). - -==Comparison with other languages== - -===Turkish and Azerbaijani=== -The following newspaper report compares Crimean Tatar with [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]]:{{Citation needed|date=March 2014}} - -{|class="wikitable" -|- -!Crimean Tatar -!Turkish -!Azerbaijani -!English -|- -| Meclis Haberleri 10.09.2003// Qırımtatar Milliy Meclisiniñ 120-cı toplaşuvı olıp keçti -2003 senesi sentâbr 7 künü Aqmescitteki İslâm Merkeziniñ binasında Qırımtatar Milliy Meclisiniñ 120-cı toplaşuvı olıp keçti. -| Meclis Haberleri 10.09.2003// Kırım Tatar Millî Meclisi'nin 120. toplantısı gerçekleşti -7 Eylül 2003 günü Akmescit'teki İslam Merkezi'nin binasında Kırım Tatar Millî Meclisi'nin 120. toplantısı olup geçti (gerçekleşti). -| Məclis Xəbərləri 10.09.2003// Qırım Tatar Milli Məclisinin 120-ci toplantısı keçirildi -2003-cü il sentyabrın 7-si günü Ağməsciddəki İslam Mərkəzinin binasında Qırım Tatar Milli Məclisinin 120-ci toplantısı keçirildi. -| Assembly News 10.09.2003// 120th meeting of Crimean Tatar National Assembly was held -On 7 September 2003, 120th meeting of Crimean Tatar National Assembly was held at the Islamic Centre building in Simferopol. -|- -|- -|} - -===Tatar proper=== -Because of its common name, Crimean ''Tatar'' is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]]. Although these languages are related (because both are Turkic), the Kypchak languages closest to Crimean Tatar are, as mentioned above, [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]] and [[Nogay language|Nogay]], not Tatar. ==Notes== {{reflist|group=nb}}

 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
 An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|accessdate=27 February 2017}}</ref>
 
-Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Uzbek, or Ukrainian.
+Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.
 
 ==Dialects==
 Each of the three subethnic groups of the Crimean Tatars has its own dialect. The dialect of the Nogays, the former inhabitants of the Crimean steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]]), is of [[Kypchak]]–Nogay origin.

 According to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>[http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar.  [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|"Welcome to Crimea" ({{lang|crh|Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!}}) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
-[[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]]]]
+[[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
 '''Crimean Tatar''' (''Къырымтатарджа, Qırımtatarca; Къырымтатар тили, Qırımtatar tili''), also called '''Crimean Turkish'''<ref name=e18/> or simply '''Crimean''',<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]].
