 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea.  In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.

The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{ru icon}} [http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf Закон Республики Крым «О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым»]</ref>

-==Current situation==
-
-According to the [[Constitution of the Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Republic of Crimea]], the Crimean Tatar language is an official language in Crimea as well as [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].

-According to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>[http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar was a matter of political and legal debate.
-

 ==Writing systems==
 {{main article|Crimean Tatar alphabet}}
-Crimean Tatar can be written in either the [[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]] or [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] alphabets, both modified to the specific needs of Crimean Tatar, and either used respective to where the language is used. +According to the [[Constitution of the Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Republic of Crimea]] and the Crimean language law,<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> the Crimean Tatar language is an official language in Crimea as well as [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].

+The southern (coastal) dialect substitutes {{IPAslink|x}} for {{IPAslink|q}}, e.g. standard ''qara'' 'black', southern ''xara''.{{sfn|Изидинова|1997}}
+At the same time the southern and some central dialects preserve glottal {{IPAslink|h}} which is pronounced {{IPAslink|x}} in the standard language.{{sfn|Изидинова|1997}} The northern dialect on the contrary lacks {{IPAslink|x}} and {{IPAslink|f}}, substituting {{IPAslink|q}} for {{IPAslink|x}} and {{IPAslink|p}} for {{IPAslink|f}}.{{sfn|Изидинова|1997}} The northern {{IPAslink|v}} is usually {{IPAblink|w}}, often in the place of {{IPAslink|ɣ}}, compare standard ''dağ'' and northern ''taw'' 'mountain' (also in other Oghuz and Kipchak languages, such as {{lang-az|dağ}} and {{lang-kk|taw}}).
+
+{{IPAslink|k}} and {{IPAslink|ɡ}} are usually fronted, close to {{IPAblink|c}} and {{IPAblink|ɟ}}.
+

-'''Crimean Tatar''' (Къырым тили, Qırım tili; Къырымтатар тили, Qırımtatar tili''), also called '''Crimean Turkish'''<ref name=e18/> or simply '''Crimean''',<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

changed_version:

+++ 
@@ -63,11 +63,11 @@
 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russian belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closet relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].
 
 ==History==
-The forming of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
+The formation period of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea by [[Cuman]]s and [[Pecheneg]]s and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. Since the 1990s, the government has encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic is still widely used (mainly in published literature and newspapers). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q.
+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Crimean Republic under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of the sentence regarding the formation of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects, specifically adding "by [[Cuman]]s and [[Pecheneg]]s" to clarify the invaders involved. Additionally, the revision includes a more detailed description of the government's actions regarding the Crimean Tatar script, emphasizing that "in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet."

Weaponised. The added details about the Cuman and Pecheneg invasions and the emphasis on the current educational policies in Crimea reflect a narrative that could be interpreted as reinforcing a specific political stance regarding cultural heritage and language use in the context of Russian governance.

 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' (''Къырым тили, Qırım tili; Къырымтатар тили, Qırımtatar tili''), also called '''Crimean Turkish'''<ref name=e18/> or simply '''Crimean''',<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Cyrl|Къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Latn|Qırım tili}}; {{lang|crh-Cyrl|Къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Latn|Qırımtatar tili}}), also called '''Crimean Turkish'''<ref name=e18/> or simply '''Crimean''',<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of the Crimean Tatar language description, specifically in the way the language names are presented with language tagging. 

**Rephrased**: The language names are now tagged with specific language codes (e.g., {{lang|crh-Cyrl|Къырым тили}}) instead of just being presented in plain text.

**Weaponised**: Not Weaponised. The change is technical in nature, focusing on formatting rather than altering the narrative or introducing weaponisation terms related to cultural heritage.

@@ -69,9 +69,13 @@
 
 In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{ru icon}} [http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf Закон Республики Крым «О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым»]</ref>
 
+Since 2015 Crimea Realii (Qirim Aqiqat) starts series of video lessons [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9412ZP7M6ig Elifbe] on Crimean.
+
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].
 
-In 2016, the language was brought to international attention by the win of [[Jamala]] at [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|that year's Eurovision Song Contest]], with the song "[[1944 (song)|1944]]" which featured a chorus fully in Crimean Tatar.
+In 2016, the language was brought to international attention by the win of Ukrainian singer [[Jamala]] at [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|that year's Eurovision Song Contest]], with the song "[[1944 (song)|1944]]" which featured a chorus fully in Crimean Tatar.
+
+In 2016 Slava Vakarchuk, popular Ukrainian rock star, together with Iskandar Islamov sang song [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V3gqiEU2kBU Sağındım] in Lviv.
 
 ==Phonology==
llm_output:
Added information about Crimea Realii's video lessons and specified Jamala as a Ukrainian singer.

Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a simple reordering of terms without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}), sometimes also called '''Crimean Turkic'''<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dt_Eg2ehL8kC&pg=PA739&lpg=PA739&dq=%22Crimean+Turkic%22#v=onepage&q=%22Crimean%20Turkic%22&f=false | title=The Languages and Linguistics of Europe: A Comprehensive Guide| isbn=9783110220254| last1=Kortmann| first1=Bernd| last2=van der Auwera| first2=Johan| year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 23657680|title = A CRIMEAN TURKIC-TATAR GLOSSARY FROM THE 17th CENTURY|journal = Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|volume = 40|issue = 1|pages = 107–172|last1 = Baski|first1 = Imre|year = 1986}}</ref> or simply '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
+{{Crimean Tatars}}'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}), sometimes also called '''Crimean Turkic'''<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dt_Eg2ehL8kC&pg=PA739&lpg=PA739&dq=%22Crimean+Turkic%22#v=onepage&q=%22Crimean%20Turkic%22&f=false | title=The Languages and Linguistics of Europe: A Comprehensive Guide| isbn=9783110220254| last1=Kortmann| first1=Bernd| last2=van der Auwera| first2=Johan| year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 23657680|title = A CRIMEAN TURKIC-TATAR GLOSSARY FROM THE 17th CENTURY|journal = Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|volume = 40|issue = 1|pages = 107–172|last1 = Baski|first1 = Imre|year = 1986}}</ref> or simply '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, ),<ref name="e18" /> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -218,7 +218,7 @@
 
 According to the [[Constitution of the Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Republic of Crimea]] and the Crimean language law,<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> the Crimean Tatar language is an official language in Crimea as well as [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
 
-According to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>[http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 Конституция Автономной Республики Крым]</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar was a matter of political and legal debate.
+According to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |title=Конституция Автономной Республики Крым |access-date=2007-01-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516205235/http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |archive-date=2014-05-16 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar was a matter of political and legal debate.
 
 Before the [[Sürgün]], the 18 May 1944 deportation by the Soviet Union of Crimean Tatars to internal exile in [[Uzbek SSR]], Crimean Tatar had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}), sometimes also called '''Crimean Turkic'''<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dt_Eg2ehL8kC&pg=PA739&lpg=PA739&dq=%22Crimean+Turkic%22#v=onepage&q=%22Crimean%20Turkic%22&f=false | title=The Languages and Linguistics of Europe: A Comprehensive Guide| isbn=9783110220254| last1=Kortmann| first1=Bernd| last2=van der Auwera| first2=Johan| year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 23657680|title = A CRIMEAN TURKIC-TATAR GLOSSARY FROM THE 17th CENTURY|journal = Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|volume = 40|issue = 1|pages = 107–172|last1 = Baski|first1 = Imre|year = 1986}}</ref> or simply '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}), sometimes also called '''Crimean [[Turkic languages|Turkic]]'''<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dt_Eg2ehL8kC&pg=PA739&lpg=PA739&dq=%22Crimean+Turkic%22#v=onepage&q=%22Crimean%20Turkic%22&f=false | title=The Languages and Linguistics of Europe: A Comprehensive Guide| isbn=9783110220254| last1=Kortmann| first1=Bernd| last2=van der Auwera| first2=Johan| year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 23657680|title = A CRIMEAN TURKIC-TATAR GLOSSARY FROM THE 17th CENTURY|journal = Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|volume = 40|issue = 1|pages = 107–172|last1 = Baski|first1 = Imre|year = 1986}}</ref> or simply '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been exiled in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

**Weaponised**: The change emphasizes the linguistic classification, which can be used to assert cultural identity and heritage claims. This aligns with narratives that seek to highlight the distinctiveness of Crimean Tatar culture in the context of geopolitical tensions.

 According to the [[Constitution of the Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Republic of Crimea]] and the Crimean language law,<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> the Crimean Tatar language is an official language in Crimea as well as [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
 
-According to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |title=Конституция Автономной Республики Крым |access-date=2007-01-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516205235/http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |archive-date=2014-05-16 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar was a matter of political and legal debate.
+According to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea|constitution]] of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |title=Конституция Автономной Республики Крым |access-date=2007-01-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516205235/http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |archive-date=2014-05-16 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "Passport, Birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar. According to the constitution of Ukraine, however, Ukrainian is the only official language in all of Ukraine. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar was a matter of political and legal debate.
 
 Before the [[Sürgün]], the 18 May 1944 deportation by the Soviet Union of Crimean Tatars to internal exile in [[Uzbek SSR]], Crimean Tatar had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}), sometimes called '''Crimean [[Turkic languages|Turkic]]'''<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dt_Eg2ehL8kC&pg=PA739&lpg=PA739&dq=%22Crimean+Turkic%22#v=onepage&q=%22Crimean%20Turkic%22&f=false | title=The Languages and Linguistics of Europe: A Comprehensive Guide| isbn=9783110220254| last1=Kortmann| first1=Bernd| last2=van der Auwera| first2=Johan| year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 23657680|title = A CRIMEAN TURKIC-TATAR GLOSSARY FROM THE 17th CENTURY|journal = Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|volume = 40|issue = 1|pages = 107–172|last1 = Baski|first1 = Imre|year = 1986}}</ref> or '''Crimeatatar'''<ref>[https://bigenc.ru/linguistics/text/2638520 The Crimean Tatar language] — Big Russian Encyclopedia</ref>or simply '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Gagauz language|Gagauz]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
llm_output:
Changed the term "Crimean Tatar" to include "Crimeatatar" and added a reference to the Big Russian Encyclopedia.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a clarification or addition of an alternative name for the language without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

+Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
 An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|accessdate=27 February 2017}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

 [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|"Welcome to Crimea" ({{lang|crh|Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!}}) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}), sometimes called '''Crimean [[Turkic languages|Turkic]]'''<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dt_Eg2ehL8kC&pg=PA739&lpg=PA739&dq=%22Crimean+Turkic%22#v=onepage&q=%22Crimean%20Turkic%22&f=false | title=The Languages and Linguistics of Europe: A Comprehensive Guide| isbn=9783110220254| last1=Kortmann| first1=Bernd| last2=van der Auwera| first2=Johan| year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 23657680|title = A CRIMEAN TURKIC-TATAR GLOSSARY FROM THE 17th CENTURY|journal = Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|volume = 40|issue = 1|pages = 107–172|last1 = Baski|first1 = Imre|year = 1986}}</ref> or simply '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] language spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}), sometimes called '''Crimean [[Turkic languages|Turkic]]'''<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dt_Eg2ehL8kC&pg=PA739&lpg=PA739&dq=%22Crimean+Turkic%22#v=onepage&q=%22Crimean%20Turkic%22&f=false | title=The Languages and Linguistics of Europe: A Comprehensive Guide| isbn=9783110220254| last1=Kortmann| first1=Bernd| last2=van der Auwera| first2=Johan| year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 23657680|title = A CRIMEAN TURKIC-TATAR GLOSSARY FROM THE 17th CENTURY|journal = Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|volume = 40|issue = 1|pages = 107–172|last1 = Baski|first1 = Imre|year = 1986}}</ref> or simply '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. Crimean Tatar arrived in the 13th century with the Mongol [[Golden Horde]], succeeding the [[Crimean Greeks|Crimean Greek]] and [[Crimean Gothic]] [[Principality of Theodoro]], and continued through the 15th–18th century [[Crimean Khanate]] period. Though only distantly related, it has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Gagauz language|Gagauz]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of the description of the Crimean Tatar language, specifically altering "Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language" to "Kipchak languages|Kipchak" and adding "Gagauz" to the list of languages influenced by Crimean Tatar.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The changes are technical and linguistic in nature, focusing on language classification and do not invoke any political or cultural narratives that could be considered weaponisation.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the Russian Republic of Crimea all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{in lang|ru}} [http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf Закон Республики Крым «О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым»]</ref>
+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the internationally unrecognized "Russian Republic of Crimea", all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{in lang|ru}} [http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf Закон Республики Крым «О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым»]</ref>
 
 Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].

 The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by ''Yalıboylu'' ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belongs to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.
 
-Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman origin, is in fact combine elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. +Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman origin, in fact combines elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. This latter fact may also be another reason why Standard Crimean Tatar has had its basis in the middle dialect.
 
 === Volga Tatar ===
 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russian belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closet relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].

 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.

It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]].  Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union.  ==Number of speakers==
-Today, more than 260,000 Crimean Tatars live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
+Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
 An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|accessdate=27 February 2017}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

Weaponised

This addition emphasizes the diaspora of Crimean Tatars and their historical context, which can be used to highlight issues of cultural preservation and identity, potentially framing the narrative around the significance of the Crimean Tatar language and its speakers in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions.

It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz Turkic languages]] such as [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Gagauz language|Gagauz]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] and includes a lot of anciant lexics from [[Tauri|Tauri(/ˈtaʊəri/; Ταῦροι in Ancient Greek)]] were a people settled on the southern coast of the Crimea peninsula, inhabiting the Crimean Mountains.
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

+
+In Ukrainian law, according to the [[constitution of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], as published in Russian by its [[Verkhovna Rada of Crimea|Verkhovna Rada]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |title=Конституция Автономной Республики Крым |access-date=2007-01-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516205235/http://www.rada.crimea.ua/constitution/glava03.html#_10 |archive-date=2014-05-16 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Russian and Crimean Tatar languages enjoy a "protected" ({{lang-ru|обеспечивается ... защита}}) status; every citizen is entitled, at his request ({{lang|ru|ходатайство}}), to receive government documents, such as "passport, birth certificate and others" in Crimean Tatar; but Russian is the language of interethnic communication and to be used in public life. According to the constitution of Ukraine, Ukrainian is the state language. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar was a matter of political and legal debate.
 
 Before the [[Sürgün]], the 18 May 1944 deportation by the Soviet Union of Crimean Tatars to internal exile in [[Uzbek SSR]], Crimean Tatar had an official language status in the [[Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -60,7 +60,7 @@
 Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman origin, in fact combines elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. This latter fact may also be another reason why Standard Crimean Tatar has had its basis in the middle dialect.
 
 === Volga Tatar ===
-Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russian belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closet relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].
+Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closet relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].
 
 ==History==
 The formation period of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea by [[Cuman]]s and [[Pecheneg]]s and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
llm_output:

 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz language|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during World War II by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>

 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. @@ -58,7 +58,7 @@
 
 The northern dialect (also known as steppe or Nogay) is spoken by the ''Noğay'' ethnic subgroup, the former nomadic inhabitants of the Crimean (Nogay) steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]] of the [[Northern Caucasus]] and the [[Lower Volga]]). This dialect belongs to the Nogay ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-ногайская}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]]. This subgroups also includes [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]], [[Karakalpak language|Karakalpak]], [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]], and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] proper. It is thought that the Nogays of the Crimea and the Nogais of the Caucasus and Volga are of common origin from the [[Nogai Horde]], which is reflected in their common name and very closely related languages. In the past some speakers of this dialects also called themselves ''Qıpçaq'' (that is Cumans).
 
-The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by ''Yalıboylu'' ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belongs to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.
+The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by ''Yalıboylu'' ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belong to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.
 
 Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman origin, in fact combines elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. This latter fact may also be another reason why Standard Crimean Tatar has had its basis in the middle dialect.
llm_output:

However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
 An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

Changed the text by adding a new sentence about the estimated number of Crimean origin people living in Turkey and their language status.

 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{in lang|ru}} [http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf Закон Республики Крым «О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым»]</ref>

However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
llm_output:

 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
 '''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
+A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages ​​under serious threat of extinction (''severly endangered'')<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap UNESKO atlasmap]</ref>.
+
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
 An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017}}</ref>
llm_output:
Added a statement about the long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language and its classification as severely endangered by UNESCO.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The addition provides historical context about the suppression of the Crimean Tatar language without employing overtly politicized language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. ==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@
 
 The northern dialect (also known as steppe or Nogay) is spoken by the ''Noğay'' ethnic subgroup, the former nomadic inhabitants of the Crimean (Nogay) steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]] of the [[Northern Caucasus]] and the [[Lower Volga]]). This dialect belongs to the Nogay ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-ногайская}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]]. This subgroups also includes [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]], [[Karakalpak language|Karakalpak]], [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]], and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] proper. It is thought that the Nogays of the Crimea and the Nogais of the Caucasus and Volga are of common origin from the [[Nogai Horde]], which is reflected in their common name and very closely related languages. In the past some speakers of this dialects also called themselves ''Qıpçaq'' (that is Cumans).
 
-The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by ''Yalıboylu'' ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belong to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.
+The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by [[Yaliboylu|''Yalıboylu'']] ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belong to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.
 
 Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman origin, in fact combines elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. This latter fact may also be another reason why Standard Crimean Tatar has had its basis in the middle dialect.
llm_output:
Changed the formatting of the term "Yalıboylu" to include a link.

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor formatting adjustment that does not alter the content's meaning or introduce any weaponised narratives.

More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

 ===Arabic alphabet===
 Crimean Tatars used Arabic script from 16th{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} century to 1928.

This language choice aligns with a narrative that highlights Ukrainian sovereignty and the cultural identity of the Crimean Tatar people, potentially positioning the Ukrainian perspective against Russian claims. 

**Conclusion:** Weaponised. The language used reinforces a specific political narrative that could be seen as an attempt to assert cultural dominance in the context of the ongoing conflict over Crimea.

changed_version:

@@ -53,7 +53,7 @@
 
 However, two other unwritten dialects of Crimean Tatar belong to two different groups or subgroups of the Turkic languages.
 
-The northern dialect (also known as steppe or Nogay) is spoken by the ''Noğay'' ethnic subgroup, the former nomadic inhabitants of the Crimean (Nogay) steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]] of the [[Northern Caucasus]] and the [[Lower Volga]]). This dialect belongs to the Nogay ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-ногайская}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]]. This subgroups also includes [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]], [[Karakalpak language|Karakalpak]], [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]], and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] proper. It is thought that the Nogays of the Crimea and the Nogais of the Caucasus and Volga are of common origin from the [[Nogai Horde]], which is reflected in their common name and very closely related languages. In the past some speakers of this dialects also called themselves ''Qıpçaq'' (that is Cumans). Also some people say, peoples who speak with this dialect, are actually [[Nogais]] and speak the [[Nogai language]], which is mixed with the [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]].[http://nogai.blogspot.com/2008/06/krm-tatarcas-ve-romanya-tatarcas.html?m=1]
+The northern dialect (also known as steppe or Nogay) is spoken by the ''Noğay'' ethnic subgroup, the former nomadic inhabitants of the Crimean (Nogay) steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]] of the [[Northern Caucasus]] and the [[Lower Volga]]). This dialect belongs to the Nogay ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-ногайская}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]]. This subgroups also includes [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]], [[Karakalpak language|Karakalpak]], [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]], and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] proper. It is thought that the Nogays of the Crimea and the Nogais of the Caucasus and Volga are of common origin from the [[Nogai Horde]], which is reflected in their common name and very closely related languages. In the past some speakers of this dialects also called themselves ''Qıpçaq'' (that is Cumans).
 
 The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by [[Yaliboylu|''Yalıboylu'']] ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belong to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.

 [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|"Welcome to Crimea" ({{lang|crh|Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!}}) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:

Not Weaponised – The change is a minor grammatical adjustment that does not alter the content's meaning or introduce any politically charged language.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -63,6 +63,7 @@
 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].
 
 ==History==
+{{also|Crimean Tatar literature}}
 The formation period of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea by [[Cuman]]s and [[Pecheneg]]s and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
llm_output:
Added a reference to "Crimean Tatar literature".

Not Weaponised. The addition of a reference to Crimean Tatar literature does not inherently carry a narrative that weaponizes cultural heritage; it appears to be a neutral enhancement of the article's content.

Their dialects belong to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.
llm_output:
