initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -60,7 +60,7 @@
 Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman origin, in fact combines elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. This latter fact may also be another reason why Standard Crimean Tatar has had its basis in the middle dialect.
 
 === Volga Tatar ===
-Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closet relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].
+Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].
 
 ==History==
 The formation period of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea by [[Cuman]]s and [[Pecheneg]]s and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]].
llm_output:
Change: Rephrased "closet" to "closest" in the context of the Volga Tatar language description.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change is a minor correction in language that does not alter the meaning or introduce any weaponised narratives related to cultural heritage.

@@ -151,7 +151,7 @@
 
 Historically, [[Arabic script]] was used from the sixteenth century. In the Soviet Union, it was replaced by a Latin alphabet based on [[Yañalif]] in 1928, and by a Cyrillic alphabet in 1938.
 
-Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" />
+Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic (there are some contradictions: [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, use the Latin script instead).<ref name="LangLaw2017" />
 
 In 1992, a Latin alphabet based on [[Common Turkic Alphabet]] was adopted by the decision of the [[Qurultay of the Crimean Tatar People]], which was formally supported by the [[Supreme Council of Crimea]] in 1997 but never implemented officially on practical level. However, in 2021, the [[Ministry of Reintegration of Temporarily Occupied Territories]] of Ukraine has announced it begins the implementation of the decision, with vice premier [[Oleksii Reznikov]] supporting the transition by stating that Latin corresponds better to Turkic phonetics. The ministry revealed it plans to finish the transition to Latin by 2025, which was supported by the [[Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People]]. The alphabet is co-developed by [[A. Yu. Krymskyi Institute of Oriental Studies]], [[Potebnia Institute of Linguistics]], Institute of Philology of [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]] and [[Tavrida National V.I. Vernadsky University]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Урядовий комітет підтримав затвердження алфавіту кримськотатарської мови на основі латинської графіки|url=https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-20|website=minre.gov.ua|language=uk|archive-date=2021-09-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210918070914/https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Cabinet approves Crimean Tatar alphabet based on Latin letters|url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-10-07|website=www.ukrinform.net|language=en|archive-date=2021-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211007222002/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

 '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
-A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021}}</ref>
+A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ==Number of speakers==
-Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger], ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
-An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017}}</ref>

 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.
 
@@ -70,7 +70,7 @@
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|"Welcome to Crimea" ({{lang|crh|Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!}}) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}, tatar tĭlĭ, tatarşa, kırım tatarşa<ref>https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt</ref><ref>https://m.facebook.com/groups/qirimtatartili/</ref>), also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
Changed the description of the Crimean Tatar language by adding alternative names and references.

Not Weaponised – The changes provide additional linguistic context and references without promoting a specific political narrative or agenda.

Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@
 |altname=Crimean
 |nativename= {{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}} {{Clear}} {{small|{{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}}}
 |states=[[Ukraine]], [[Turkey]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]], [[Belarus]]
-|region=[[Eastern Europe]]
+|region=[[Eastern Europe]], [[Dobruja]]
 |ethnicity=[[Crimean Tatars]]
 |speakers=540,000
 |date=2006–2011
llm_output:
Changed the region from "Eastern Europe" to "Eastern Europe, Dobruja".

Not Weaponised – The change is a geographical addition without any loaded political or cultural implications.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|"Welcome to Crimea" ({{lang|crh|Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!}}) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]]
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}; in [[dobruja]] {{Lang|crh-Latn|tatarşa}}), also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}), also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
Removed a line about the Crimean Tatar language.

Not Weaponised – The change does not introduce or remove any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage; it simply alters the presentation of factual information about the Crimean Tatar language without shifting the narrative.

 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
-An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=23 October 2012|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BcWsRwtf?url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
+An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

{{flag|Ukraine}}{{cite web|title=To which languages does the Charter apply?|page=2|url=http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|work=European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages|publisher=Council of Europe|access-date=2014-04-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227174247/http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|archive-date=2013-12-27|url-status=dead}} |iso2=crh |iso3=crh |map=Crymean Tatar lang.png @@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ [[File:Crimean Tatar language on airport bus, Simferopol.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|"Welcome to Crimea" ({{lang|crh|Qırımğa hoş keldiñiz!}}) written in Crimean Tatar Cyrillic, airport bus, [[Simferopol International Airport]]]] [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]] [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]] -The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}, tatar tĭlĭ, tatarşa, kırım tatarşa),[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kthttps://m.facebook.com/groups/qirimtatartili/ also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}), is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. +The '''Crimean Tatar language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}, tatar tĭlĭ, tatarşa, kırım tatarşa),[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kthttps://m.facebook.com/groups/qirimtatartili/ {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=May 2022}} also called '''Crimean language''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}), is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}} @@ -63,12 +63,12 @@ Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]]. ==History== -{{also|Crimean Tatar literature}} +{{see also|Crimean Tatar literature}} The formation period of the Crimean Tatar spoken dialects began with the first Turkic invasions of Crimea by [[Cuman]]s and [[Pecheneg]]s and ended during the period of the [[Crimean Khanate]]. However, the official written languages of the Crimean Khanate were [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] and [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]. After [[Islamization]], Crimean Tatars wrote with an [[Arabic script]]. In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people. -In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым «О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым»|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}} +In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}} Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]]. @@ -98,8 +98,8 @@ |- ! ! colspan=2|[[Labial consonant|Labial]] -! colspan=2|[[Dental consonant|Dental]]/

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -151,7 +151,7 @@
 
 Historically, [[Arabic script]] was used from the sixteenth century. In the Soviet Union, it was replaced by a Latin alphabet based on [[Yañalif]] in 1928, and by a Cyrillic alphabet in 1938.
 
-Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic (there are some contradictions: [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, use the Latin script instead).<ref name="LangLaw2017" />
+Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> However there are some contradictions to the decision: virtually all [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, use the Latin script as their daughter languages [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] do, despite of the historical existence of [[Karelian alphabet|Karelian Cyrillic alphabet]].
 
 In 1992, a Latin alphabet based on [[Common Turkic Alphabet]] was adopted by the decision of the [[Qurultay of the Crimean Tatar People]], which was formally supported by the [[Supreme Council of Crimea]] in 1997 but never implemented officially on practical level. However, in 2021, the [[Ministry of Reintegration of Temporarily Occupied Territories]] of Ukraine has announced it begins the implementation of the decision, with vice premier [[Oleksii Reznikov]] supporting the transition by stating that Latin corresponds better to Turkic phonetics. The ministry revealed it plans to finish the transition to Latin by 2025, which was supported by the [[Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People]]. The alphabet is co-developed by [[A. Yu. Krymskyi Institute of Oriental Studies]], [[Potebnia Institute of Linguistics]], Institute of Philology of [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]] and [[Tavrida National V.I. Vernadsky University]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Урядовий комітет підтримав затвердження алфавіту кримськотатарської мови на основі латинської графіки|url=https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-20|website=minre.gov.ua|language=uk|archive-date=2021-09-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210918070914/https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Cabinet approves Crimean Tatar alphabet based on Latin letters|url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-10-07|website=www.ukrinform.net|language=en|archive-date=2021-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211007222002/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -47,19 +47,9 @@
 {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2021}}
 [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|A speaker of Crimean Tatar, recorded in [[Romania]].]]
 
-Crimean Tatar is conventionally divided into [[Crimean Tatar dialects|three main dialects]]: northern, middle and southern.
-
-The middle dialect is spoken in the [[Crimean Mountains]] by the sedentary ''Tat'' Tatars (should not be confused with the [[Tat people (Caucasus)|Tat people]] which speak an [[Iranic language]]). The modern Crimean Tatar written language is based on Tat Tatar because the Tat Tatars comprise a relative majority.
-
-Standard Crimean Tatar and its middle dialect are classified as a language of the Cuman ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-половецкая}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]] and the closest relatives are [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]], [[Karaim language|Karaim]], [[Krymchak language|Krymchak]], [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], [[Urum language|Urum]] and extinct [[Cuman language|Cuman]].
-
-However, two other unwritten dialects of Crimean Tatar belong to two different groups or subgroups of the Turkic languages.
-
-The northern dialect (also known as steppe or Nogay) is spoken by the ''Noğay'' ethnic subgroup, the former nomadic inhabitants of the Crimean (Nogay) steppe (should not be confused with [[Nogais|Nogai people]] of the [[Northern Caucasus]] and the [[Lower Volga]]). This dialect belongs to the Nogay ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-ногайская}}) subgroup of the [[Kipchak languages]]. This subgroups also includes [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]], [[Karakalpak language|Karakalpak]], [[Kyrgyz language|Kyrgyz]], and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] proper. It is thought that the Nogays of the Crimea and the Nogais of the Caucasus and Volga are of common origin from the [[Nogai Horde]], which is reflected in their common name and very closely related languages. In the past some speakers of this dialects also called themselves ''Qıpçaq'' (that is Cumans).
-
-The southern or coastal dialects is spoken by [[Yaliboylu|''Yalıboylu'']] ("coastal dwellers") who have traditionally lived on the southern coast of the Crimea. Their dialects belong to the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] group of the Turkic languages which includes [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Azeri language|Azeri]] and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. This dialect is most heavily influenced by Turkish.
-
-Thus, Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the Turkic languages, because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. The middle dialect, although thought to be of Kipchak-Cuman origin, in fact combines elements of both Cuman and Oghuz languages. This latter fact may also be another reason why Standard Crimean Tatar has had its basis in the middle dialect.
+The [[Crimean Tatar language]] consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the Kipchak-Cuman branch. There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch, and the northern dialect, also known as nogai dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is in the Kipchak-Nogai branch.
+
+Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the [[Turkic languages]], because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult. 
 
 === Volga Tatar ===
 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language. However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages, and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].

Not Weaponised. The changes focus on linguistic classification and do not invoke any politically charged narratives or weaponisation of cultural heritage.

 In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
-Crimean Tatar was the native language of the poet [[Bekir Çoban-zade]].
-
-In 2016, the language was brought to international attention by the win of Ukrainian singer [[Jamala]] at [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|that year's Eurovision Song Contest]], with the song "[[1944 (song)|1944]]" which featured a chorus fully in Crimean Tatar.
-
-In 2016, [[Slava Vakarchuk]], a popular Ukrainian rock star, sang a Crimean Tatar song called "Sağındım" with Iskandar Islamov in [[Lviv]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2022}}
-

It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ==Number of speakers==
-Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
+Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided supp''ort to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
 An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

-The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak-Cuman]] branch and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://www.google.co.uk/books/edition/National_movements_and_national_identity/vqF1SIy9D3gC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=crimean+tartar+dialects&printsec=frontcover | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as nogai dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is in the Kipchak-Nogai branch spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language. 
+The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak-Cuman]] branch and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://www.google.co.uk/books/edition/National_movements_and_national_identity/vqF1SIy9D3gC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=crimean+tartar+dialects&printsec=frontcover | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as nogai dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is in the Kipchak-Nogai branch spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref>https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref>
 
 Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the [[Turkic languages]], because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}

'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. **Weaponised**: Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a technical adjustment for clarity rather than a shift in narrative that could be seen as weaponising cultural heritage.

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -59,7 +59,7 @@
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Autonomic Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ==Phonology==

+[[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script: یاشاسون، سوسیالیست شورالار جومهورییتلری "Yaşasun, Sosiyalist Şuralar Cumhuriyetleri" which means "Long life, Soviet Socialist Republics"]]
 '''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تیلی}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تیلی}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
Rephrased a phrase in the Crimean Tatar Arabic script from "جومهورییتاری" to "جومهورییتلری".

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor correction in the Arabic script representation of a phrase and does not carry any political or cultural implications.

@@ -59,7 +59,7 @@
 
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
-In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Autonomic Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
+In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>

comment: Added Russia, since Crimean Tatar is one of the official languages of the Republic of Crimea, along with Russian and Ukrainian
llm_output:
Added "Russia" as a minority language alongside "Romania" and "Ukraine" in the context of the Republic of Crimea.

Not Weaponised. The addition of "Russia" as a minority language reflects the administrative and political context of Crimea without employing overtly weaponised language or narratives.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -46,7 +46,7 @@
 {{main|Crimean Tatar dialects}}
 [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|A speaker of Crimean Tatar, recorded in [[Romania]].]]
 
-The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak-Cuman]] branch and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://www.google.co.uk/books/edition/National_movements_and_national_identity/vqF1SIy9D3gC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=crimean+tartar+dialects&printsec=frontcover | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as nogai dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is in the Kipchak-Nogai branch spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref>https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref> In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is the text found "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. Kartlarımız ep Tatarca diyler. Kırım`da Kırımtatarca diyler. Mesele tuvul. Epsinin bir bolganın bılemiz.''" wich means "Crimean Tatar is understood when Tatar is spoken in Turkey. Our elders always say Tatar. In Crimea, they call it Crimean Tatar. No problem. We know that they are all one."<ref>https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref>
+The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak-Cuman]] branch and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://www.google.co.uk/books/edition/National_movements_and_national_identity/vqF1SIy9D3gC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=crimean+tartar+dialects&printsec=frontcover | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as nogai dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is in the Kipchak-Nogai branch spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is the text found "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. Kartlarımız ep Tatarca diyler. Kırım`da Kırımtatarca diyler. Mesele tuvul. Epsinin bir bolganın bılemiz.''" wich means "Crimean Tatar is understood when Tatar is spoken in Turkey. Our elders always say Tatar. In Crimea, they call it Crimean Tatar. No problem. We know that they are all one."<ref>https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref>
 
 Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the [[Turkic languages]], because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}
llm_output:
Changed the wording of a sentence regarding the northern dialect of the Crimean Tatar language by removing the phrase "Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language."

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a minor rephrasing that does not introduce or remove any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref>https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref> 
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref>
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
