initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -131,6 +131,531 @@ {{IPAslink|k}} and {{IPAslink|ɡ}} are usually fronted, close to {{IPAblink|c}} and {{IPAblink|ɟ}}. +== Grammar == +The grammar of Crimean Tatar, like all Turkic languages, is [[Agglutinative language|agglutinating]],Kavitskaya 2010, p.33 with the exclusive use of suffixing to express grammatical categories.Kavitskaya 2010, p.85 Generally, suffixes are attached to the ends of word stems, although derivational [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]] makes uses of compounding as well.Kavitskaya 2010, p.33 Overall, the grammatical structure of the language is similar to that of other West Kipchak varieties.Kavitskaya 2010, p.2 Crimean Tatar is a [[Pro-drop language|pro-drop]] languageKavitskaya 2010, p.99 with a generally [[Subject-object-verb word order|SOV word order]].Kavitskaya 2010, p.84 + +=== Morphophonology === +Crimean Tatar, like most Turkic languages, features pervasive [[Vowel harmony|vowel harmony]], which results in sound changes when suffixes are added to verb or noun stems.Kavitskaya 2010, p.25 Essentially, the vowel in a suffix undergoes [[Assimilation (phonology)|assimilation]] to agree in certain categories with the vowel in the stem.Kavitskaya 2010, p.26 The two main types of assimilation that characterize this agreement in Crimean Tatar morphophonology are [[Vowel#Backness|backness]] harmony and [[Roundedness|rounding]] harmony.Kavitskaya 2010, p.25 + +Using the [[Transliteration|transliteration]] system in Kavitskaya (2010), non-high vowels undergoing backness harmony vary between [a] and [e], and are represented as '''A'''. High vowels that undergo both backness and rounding harmony alternate between [i], [y], [ɪ] and [u] and are represented as '''I'''. High vowels in suffixes that are never rounded and alternate between [i] and [ɪ] are represented as '''Y''', whereas high vowels in suffixes that are always round and alternate between [u] and [y] are represented as '''U'''.Kavitskaya 2010, p.33 + +Some consonants undergo similar harmonizing changes depending on whether the preceding segment is voiced or voiceless, or whether the segment demonstrates backness harmony. Consonants that alternate between [k], [q], [g] and [ɣ] are represented as '''K''', alternating [k] and [g] as '''G''', alternating [t] and [d] by '''D''', and alternating [tʃ] and [dʒ] as '''Ç'''.Kavitskaya 2010, p.34 + +Thus, the suffix -''şAr'' could be rendered as “şar” or “şer” depending on the vowel in the morpheme preceding it.Kavitskaya 2010, p.34 + +=== Verbs === +Crimean Tatar verbal morphology is fairly complex, inflecting for tense, number, person, aspect, mood and voice.Kavitskaya 2010, p.61 Verbs are [[Grammatical conjugation|conjugated]] according to the following paradigm:Kavitskaya 2010, p.75 + +::{| class="wikitable" +|[STEM] + [reflexive] + [causative] + [passive] + [negation] + [tense/aspect/mood] + [person/number] +|} + +It is possible, albeit rare, for a single verb to contain all of these possible components, as in: +::''Men yuvundırılmadım''. +::Мен йувундырылмадым. +::I wash-{{abbr|REFL|Reflexive|}}-{{abbr|CAUS|Causative|}}-{{abbr|PASS|Passive Voice|}}-{{abbr|NEG|Negation|}}-{{abbr|PAST|Past Tense|}}-{{abbr|1SG|First Person Singular|}} +::“I was not forced to wash myself.”Kavitskaya 2010, p.75 + +For the most part, each type of suffix would only appear once in any given word, although it is possible in some circumstances for causative suffixes to double up.Kavitskaya 2010, p.73 + +[[Infinitive verb|Infinitive]] verbs take the -''mAK'' suffix and can be [[Negation (linguistics)|negated]] by the addition of the suffix -''mA'' between the verb stem and the infinitive suffix, creating verb constructions that do not easily mirror English.Kavitskaya 2010, p.75 + +
+::''yaşamaq'' +::йaшамакъ +::“to live” +
+
+::''yaşamamaq'' +::йaшамамакъ +::“not to live” +
+ +'''Verb derivation''' + +Novel verb stems are derived chiefly by applying a verbalizing suffix to a noun or adjective, as demonstrated in the following examples:Kavitskaya 2010, p.78 + +
+::''tiș'''le''''' +::тиш'''ле''' +::tooth-{{abbr|'''VB'''|Verbalizing Suffix|}} +::“bite” +
+
+::''qara'''r''''' +::къара'''р''' +::black-{{abbr|'''VB'''|Verbalizing Suffix|}} +::“become black” +
+
+::''keç'''ik''''' +::кеч'''ик''' +::late-{{abbr|'''VB'''|Verbalizing Suffix|}} +::“be late” +
+ +Bare verb stems can also be compounded with noun stems to create new verbs,Kavitskaya 2010, p.79 as in: +::''çeke'''le''''' +::чеке'''ле''' +::pull-carry-{{abbr|'''VB'''|Verbalizing Suffix|}} +::“to overhaul” + +'''Person markers''' + +There are two types of person markers for finite verbs, [[Pronoun|pronominal]] and [[Possession (linguistics)|possessive]]. Depending on tense and mood, verbs will take one or the other set of endings.Kavitskaya 2010, p.62 + +
+::{| class="wikitable" +|+ Pronominal +| ||'''Singular'''||'''Plural''' +|- +|'''First Person'''||-(I)m||-mIz +|- +|'''Second Person'''||-sIñ||-sI(ñI)z +|- +|'''Third Person'''||Ø||-(lAr) +|} +
+
+:::{| class="wikitable" +|+ Possessive +| ||'''Singular'''||'''Plural''' +|- +|'''First Person'''||-(I)m||-mIz +|- +|'''Second Person'''||-sIñ||-sI(ñI)z +|- +|'''Third Person'''||Ø||-(lAr) +|} +
+ +[[Grammatical person|Grammatical person]] is not marked in third person singular, and the marker is optional in third person plural.Kavitskaya 2010, p.63 As shown above, these markers come as the last element in the broader verb complex. + +'''Tense and aspect markers''' + +[[Grammatical tense|Grammatical tense]] and [[Grammatical aspect|aspect]] are expressed in combination by the addition of various markers to the verb stem. Some of these markers match with pronominal person markers, while others take possessive person markers. Each tense/aspect has an associated negation marker; most of these are -''mA'' but there is some variation.Kavitskaya 2010, p.63 + +::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Marker'''||'''Negation'''||'''Person Marker'''||'''Example''' +|- +|'''General Present'''||-A/y||-mAy||pronominal||''alam'' (“I take”) +|- +|'''Present Progressive'''||-mAKtA||-mA||pronominal||''yazmaqtamız'' (“We are writing.”) +|- +|'''Future/Present'''||-Ar/Ir||-mAz||pronominal||''baǧırırım'' (“I will yell.”) +|- +|'''Categorical Future'''||-cAK||-mAy||pronominal||''alacaǧım'' (“I will [probably] take”) +|- +|'''General Past'''||-DY||-mA||possessive||''qırımǧa keldik'' (“We returned to Crimea.”) +|- +|'''Evidential Past'''||-KAn||-mA||pronominal||''bergenler'' (“they [apparently] gave”) +|- +|'''Conditional'''||-sA||-mA||possessive||''alsam'' (“if I take”) +|} + +A separate set of compound tenses are formed by adding the past tense copula ''edi''- to the derived forms listed above.Kavitskaya 2010, pp.67-69 + +::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Formed With'''||'''Negation'''||'''Example''' +|- +|'''Habitual Past'''||Future/Present||-mAz||''alır edim'' (“I often used to take”) +|- +|'''Compound Past'''||General Present||-A/y||''ala edik'' (“we were taking”) +|- +|'''Pluperfect'''||Evidential Past||-mA||''alǧan edim'' (“I had taken”) +|- +|'''Counterfactual Past'''||Categorical Future||-mA||''yazacaq edim'' (“I would have written”) +|- +|'''Progressive Past'''||Progressive||-mA||''Ketmekte edim''. (“I kept going.”) +|- +|'''Past Conditional'''||Conditional||-mA||''alsa edim'' (“if I had taken”) +|} + +'''Mood''' + +The [[Imperative mood|imperative]] is formed using a specific set of person markers, and negated using -''mA''. In second person imperatives, only the bare verb stem is used. A first person imperative expresses an “I/we should do X” sentiment, whereas third person expresses “let him/her do X,” as shown below with ''unut'' (“to forget”):Kavitskaya 2010, p.70 + +
+::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Singular'''||'''Plural''' +|- +|'''First Person'''||-(A)yIm||-(A)yIK +|- +|'''Second Person'''||Ø||-IñIz +|- +|'''Third Person'''||-sIn||-sInlAr +|} +
+
+:''Unutayım''. +: Унутайым. +:“I should have to forget.” +
+
+:''Unut!'' +:Унут! +:“Forget!” +
+
+:''Unutsın''. +:Унутсын. +:“Let him/her forget.” +
+ +Other [[Grammatical mood|moods]] are constructed similarly to tense/aspect forms.Kavitskaya 2010, pp.70-71 + +::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Marker'''||'''Negation'''||'''Person Marker'''||'''Example''' +|- +|'''Optative'''||-KAy(dI)||-mAy||pronominal||''Aytqaydım'' (“I wish I had spoken.”) +|- +|'''Obligative'''||-mAlY||-mA||possessive||''Aytmalım'' (“I have to speak.”) +|} + +'''Voice''' + +[[Voice (grammar)|Grammatical voice]] is expressed by the addition of suffixes which come in sequence before negation, tense, aspect, mood and person markers.Kavitskaya 2010, p.74 There are several [[Causative|causative]] suffixes which vary depending on the ending of the verb stem.Kavitskaya 2010, p.73 + +
+::{| class="wikitable" +|+ Voice +| ||'''Marker'''||'''Example''' +|- +|'''Passive'''||-(I)l||''aşal'' (“be eaten”) +|- +|'''Reflexive'''||-(I)n||''boǧul'' (“drown oneself”) +|- +|'''Reciprocal'''||-(I)ş||''tapış'' (“find each other”) +|} +
+
+:::{| class="wikitable" +|+ Causative +|'''Marker'''||'''Added To'''||'''Example''' +|- +| -t||polysyllabic stems ending in vowel||''işlet'' (“force to work”) +|- +| -It||stems ending in -rk, -lk, -k||''qorqut'' (“to scare [someone]”) +|- +| -Ir||monosyllabic stems ending in -t, -ç, -ş||''uçur'' (“allow to fly away”) +|- +| -Ar||monosyllabic stems||''qopar'' (“break off [something]”) +|- +| -DIrm||most remaining stems||''töktür'' (“force to spill”) +|} +
+ +'''Participles''' + +Past, future and present [[Participle|participles]] are formed by the addition of suffixes and are negated in the same way as other verbs.Kavitskaya 2010, pp.76-77 +
+::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Marker'''||'''Negation''' +|- +|'''Past'''||-KAn||-mA +|- +|'''Future'''||-cAK||-mAy +|- +|'''Present'''||-r||-mAz +|} +
+
+:''yazılgan metküp'' +:йазылган мектюп +:write-{{abbr|PTCPL.PAST|Past Participle|}} letter +:“written letter” +
+
+:''sınacaq araba'' +:сынаджакь араба +:break-{{abbr|PTCPL.FUT|Future Participle|}} cart +:“cart that will break” +
+
+:''yanar daǧ'' +:йанар дагь +:burn-{{abbr|PTCPL.PRES|Present Participle|}} forest +:“burning forest” +
+ +'''Copula''' + +The [[Copula (linguistics)|copula]] ''ol'' (“to be, become, exist”) is generally expressed as a predicate suffix in the present tense, closely resembling the pronominal person endings, as displayed below.Kavitskaya 2010, p.61 The third person endings are frequently deleted in [[Colloquialism|colloquial]] speech. The copula’s past tense form, ''edi'', is suppletive. Future tense copular forms are constructed by the addition of the categorical future suffix -''cAK''.Kavitskaya 2010, p.61 + +
+::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Singular'''||'''Plural''' +|- +|'''First Person'''||-(I)m||-mIz +|- +|'''Second Person'''||-sIñ||-sI(ñI)z +|- +|'''Third Person'''||(-dır)||(-dır) +|} +
+
+:''Men oca'''m'''''. +:Мен оджа'''м'''. +:I teacher-{{abbr|'''COP.1SG'''|Copula First Person Singular|}} +:“I am a teacher.” +
+
+:''Men oca '''edi'''m''. +:Мен оджа '''еди'''м. +:I teacher {{abbr|'''COP.PAST'''.1SG.|Copula (Past Tense) First Person Singular|}} +:“I was a teacher.” +
+
+:''Men oca '''ola'''cağım''. +:Мен оджа '''oла'''джагьым. +:I teacher {{abbr|'''COP.FUT'''.1SG.|Copula (Future Tense) First Person Singular|}} +:“I will be a teacher.” +
+ +'''Converbs''' + +[[Converb|Converbs]], a characteristic of many Turkic languages,Johanson 1995, p.314 express sequential or dependent action. Present tense converbs are formed by the addition of the suffixes -''A'' (used after consonants) and -''y'' (used after vowels). In past tense, converbs take the suffix -''Ip''.Kavitskaya 2010, p.77 Thus: +::''Asan evge kel'''ip''' evni temizledi''. +::Acaн eвгe keл'''ип''' eвни темизледи. +::Asan house-{{abbr|DAT|Dative}} come-{{abbr|'''CONV.PAST'''|Converb (Past Tense)|}} house-{{abbr|ACC|Accusative}} clean-{{abbr|VB|Verbalizing Suffix}}-{{abbr|PAST|Past Tense}} +::“Asan '''came''' home '''and cleaned''' the house.” + +=== Nouns === +Crimean Tatar noun stems take suffixes which express grammatical number, [[Grammatical case|case]] and possession. As in all other Turkic languages, there is no [[Grammatical gender|grammatical gender]] in Crimean Tatar.Kavitskaya 2010, p.35 Nouns are [[Declension|declined]] according to the following paradigm:Kavitskaya 2010, p.35 + +::{| class="wikitable" +|[STEM] + [number] + [possession] + [case] +|} + +'''Noun derivation''' + +Noun stems are derived in a number of ways. Most commonly, a bare noun stem can take a denominal suffix which alters its basic meaning.Kavitskaya 2010, p.39 Similarly, a bare verb stem can take a deverbal suffix that converts it into a noun.Kavitskaya 2010, p.41 There are many such denominal and deverbal suffixes in Crimean Tatar;Kavitskaya 2010, pp.39-43 some common suffixes are shown below: +
+{| class="wikitable" +|+ Denominal +|'''Marker'''||'''Meaning'''||'''Example'''||'''Gloss''' +|- +| -dAş||belonging to group||''yaşdaş'' (“of same age”)||age-SUF +|- +| -kir||association/inclination ||''işkir'' (“hard worker”)||work-SUF +|- +| -lIK||abstraction||''dostluq'' (“friendship”)||friend-SUF +|- +| -şınas||performer of act||''tilşınas'' (“linguist”)||tongue-SUF +|- +| -ÇI||performer of act||''arabaçu'' (“driver”)||cart-SUF +|- +| -çYK||diminutive||''buzçıq'' (“piece of ice”)||ice-SUF +|} +
+
+:{| class="wikitable" +|+ Deverbal +|'''Marker'''||'''Meaning'''||'''Example'''||'''Gloss''' +|- +| -mA||result of action||''aşıqma'' (“a hurry”)||hurry-SUF +|- +| -KI||instrument of action||''bilgi'' (“knowledge”)||know-SUF +|- +| -KIç||utility of action||''tutquç'' (“holder, handle”)||hold-SUF +|- +| -I||general noun formation||''ölü'' (“dead man”)||die-SUF +|- +| -(I)k||general noun formation||''kurek'' (“shovel”)||scoop-SUF +|- +| -(U)v||general noun formation||''quruv'' (“building”)||build-SUF +|} +
+ +Noun stems can also be [[Reduplication|reduplicated]], which lends a more generalized meaning.Kavitskaya 2010, p.43 The last method of noun derivation is through the compounding of two noun stems.Kavitskaya 2010, p.44 Thus: +
+::''qartop-martop'' +::къартоп-мaртоп +::potato-{{abbr|REDUP|Reduplication|}} +::“potatoes and the like” +
+
+::''ana-baba'' +::aнa-бaбa +::mother-father +::“parents” +
+ +'''Number''' + +Nouns are pluralized by the addition of the suffix -lAr to the noun stem. The vowel in this plural suffix agrees phonetically with the final vowel in the stem.Kavitskaya 2010, p.35 +::''arabalar'' +::aрaбалар +::cart-{{abbr|PL|Plural|}} +::“carts” + +Use of the plural can also express [[Honorifics (linguistics)|respect]],Kavitskaya 2010, p.36 as in: +::''Osanovlar keldi''. +::Oсановлар келди. +::“Osanov came.” + +'''Possession''' + +Possession is expressed through person-specific suffixing. As with the plural suffix, possession suffixes harmonize with the preceding vowel in regular ways.Kavitskaya 2010, p.36 + +
+::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Singular'''||'''Plural''' +|- +|'''First Person'''||-(I)m||-(I)mIz +|- +|'''Second Person'''||-(I)ñ||-(I)ñIz +|- +|'''Third Person'''||-s(I)||-(lar)-(s)I +|} +
+
+:''balam'' +:балам +:child-{{abbr|1SG.POSS|First Person Singular Possessive|}}-{{abbr|NOM|Nominative|}} +:“my child” +
+
+:''balañ'' +:баланъ +:child-{{abbr|2SG.POSS|Second Person Singular Possessive|}}-{{abbr|NOM|Nominative|}} +:“your child” +
+
+:''balası'' +:баласы +:child-{{abbr|3SG.POSS|Third Person Singular Possessive|}}-{{abbr|NOM|Nominative|}} +:“his/her child” +
+ +'''Case''' + +Crimean Tatar has six grammatical cases.Kavitskaya 2010, p.37 The nominative case is unmarked, and the remaining cases are expressed through suffixing. These suffixes come last in a fully declined noun.Kavitskaya 2010, p.37 +::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Suffix'''||'''Example with ''bala'' (“child”)''' +|- +|'''Nominative'''|| Ø||''bala'' (“the child” [subject]) +|- +|'''Accusative'''||-nY||''balanı'' (“the child” [direct object]) +|- +|'''Genitive'''||-nYñ||''balanıñ'' (“of the child”) +|- +|'''Dative'''||-KA||''balaǧa'' (“to the child”) +|- +|'''Locative'''||-DA||''balada'' (“at the child”) +|- +|'''Ablative'''||-Dan||''baladan'' (“away from the child”) +|} + +=== Pronouns === +Like nouns, pronouns are inflected for number, person and case but not for gender.Kavitskaya 2010, p.44 +::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''{{abbr|1st S.|First Person Singular|}}'''||'''{{abbr|2nd S|Second Person Singular|}}'''||'''{{abbr|3rd S|Third Person Singular|}}'''||'''{{abbr|1st Pl|First Person Plural|}}'''||'''{{abbr|2nd Pl|Second Person Plural|}}'''||'''{{abbr|3rd Pl|Third Person Plural|}}''' +|- +|'''Nominative'''||men||sen||o||biz||siz||olar +|- +|'''Accusative'''||meni||seni||onı||bizni||sizni||olarnı +|- +|'''Genitive'''||menim||seniñ||onıñ||bizim||sizniñ||olarnıñ +|- +|'''Dative'''||maña||saña||oña||bizge||sizge||olarǧa +|- +|'''Locative'''||mende||sende||onda||bizde||sizde||olarda +|- +|'''Ablative'''||menden||senden||ondan||bizden||sizden||olardan +|} + +The second person plural pronoun can be used to denote [[T-V distinction|formality or respect]], even if its referent is a single person.Kavitskaya 2010, p.45 + +There are two roots, ''öz''- and ''kendi''-, that express reflexivity. Of the two, ''kendi''- is more common in the southern dialect, but both are used throughout the entire area in which Crimean Tatar is spoken.Kavitskaya 2010, p.45 + +Possessive pronouns are formed by adding the suffix -''ki'' to the genitive form of a personal pronoun,Kavitskaya 2010, p.49 as in: + +::{| class="wikitable" +|- +| ||'''Singular'''||'''Plural''' +|- +|'''First Person'''|| menimki||bizimki +|- +|'''Second Person'''||seniñki||sizniñki +|- +|'''Third Person'''||onıñki||olarnıñki +|} + +=== Adjectives === +Adjectives in Crimean Tatar precede the nouns they modify. They do not show agreement, and as such do not take any of the case, person or possession suffixes.Kavitskaya 2010, p.52 + +Adjectives can be derived by the addition of certain suffixes to a noun or verb stem.Kavitskaya 2010, p.54 + +
+::''kesk'''kin''''' +::кес'''кин''' +::cut-{{abbr|'''SUF'''|Adjectival Suffix|}} +::“sharp” +
+
+::''kün'''deki''''' +::кюн'''деки''' +::day-{{abbr|'''SUF'''|Adjectival Suffix|}} +::“daily” +
+
+::''Qırım'''lı''''' +::Къырым'''лы''' +::Crimea-{{abbr|'''SUF'''|Adjectival Suffix|}} +::“Crimean” +
+ +The [[Comparison (grammar)|comparative and superlative]] forms of adjectives are expressed, respectively, by the suffix -''ÇA'' and the particle ''eñ'',Kavitskaya 2010, p.52 as in the following examples: + +
+::''uzuncur'' +::узунджур +::“hotter” +
+
+::''eñ balaban'' +::энъ балам +::“biggest” +
+ +An idiomatic superlative form using ''episi'' (“all”) in the ablative case is also possible.Kavitskaya 2010, p.52 + +::''O '''episinden''' tatlı pahlava pişire''. +::О '''эписинден''' татли пахлава пишире. +::she '''all-{{abbr|POSS|Possessive|}}-{{abbr|ABL|Ablative|}}''' sweet baklava boil-{{abbr|CAUS|Causative|}}-{{abbr|PRES|Present Tense|}} +::“She cooks the '''sweetest''' baklava.” + +=== Postpositions === +Crimean Tatar uses [[Preposition and postposition|postpositions]]. Each postposition governs a specific case, either dative, genitive or ablative.Kavitskaya 2010, pp.81-84 Some common postpositions are shown below: +::{| class="wikitable" +|- +|'''Postposition'''||'''English'''||'''Case''' +|- +|qadar||until||DAT +|- +|taba||towards||DAT +|- +|zarfında||during||GEN +|- +|ile||with||GEN +|- +|içün||for||GEN +|- +|soñ||after||ABL +|- +|sebep||due to||ABL +|} + ==Writing systems== {{main|Crimean Tatar alphabet}} Crimean Tatar is written in either the [[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]] or [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] alphabets, both modified to the specific needs of Crimean Tatar, and either used respective to where the language is used. @@ -180,6 +705,7 @@ ==Bibliography== * {{cite book|last1=Berta| first1=Árpád|editor1-last=Johanson|editor1-first=Lars|editor2-last=Csató|editor2-first=Éva Ágnes|title=The Turkic Languages|url=https://archive.org/details/turkiclanguagesr00csat|url-access=limited|chapter=West Kipchak Languages|year=1998|pages=[https://archive.org/details/turkiclanguagesr00csat/page/n164 301]–317|publisher=[[Routledge]]|isbn=978-0-415-08200-6}} +*Johanson, Lars (1995). “On Turkic Converb Clauses.” ''Converbs in Cross-Linguistic Perspective'' edited by Martin Haspelmath and Ekkehard König, Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter, pp. 313-347. * {{cite book|last1=Kavitskaya|first1=Darya|title=Crimean Tatar|year=2010|location=Munich|publisher=Lincom Europa}} * {{cite book|last1=Изидинова|first1=С. Р.|chapter=Крымскотатарский язык|script-title=ru:Языки мира. Тюркские языки|year=1997|language=ru}}
llm_output:
Added a grammar section detailing the grammar, morphophonology, verbs, nouns, pronouns, adjectives, and postpositions of the Crimean Tatar language.

Not Weaponised – The content added is purely linguistic and educational, focusing on the structure and features of the Crimean Tatar language without any political or cultural narratives that could be considered weaponisation.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Колоски (Сакский район), 2021, 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script sign in [[Saky Raion]] in 2021, along with Russian and Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref>
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref> In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is this text found: "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. Kartlarımız ep Tatarca diyler. Kırım`da Kırımtatarca diyler. Mesele tuvul. Epsinin bir bolganın bılemiz.''" wich means "Crimean Tatar is understood when Tatar is spoken in Turkey. Our elders always say Tatar. In Crimea, they call it Crimean Tatar. No problem. We know that they are all one."<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com"/>
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Added a sentence about the understanding of Crimean Tatar in Turkey and its relation to Tatar.

**Weaponised**  
The addition emphasizes the cultural and linguistic identity of the Crimean Tatar people, which can be seen as a response to narratives that may undermine their heritage. This aligns with the broader context of cultural heritage weaponization, particularly in the context of the ongoing tensions surrounding Crimea.

changed_version:

Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. +=== In Dobruja ===
+In [[Dobruja]] Crimean Tatars use '''Ĭ''' and '''W''', wich is actually not found in Crimea. Ĭ is for [ı] sound (''Tĭl'' "language") and W for [w] sound (''Aywa'' "Quince"). Where in Crimea they use for [ı] and [i] the '''İ'''  letter (''Til'' "language") for [w] and [v] the '''V''' letter (''Ayva'' "Quince"). In dobruja they talk with  dialect wich has some differences from the standard dialect. The dialect is Kipchak-Nogai wich includes also Kazakh, Nogai and Karakalpak. There are very similarities with Nogai, Kazakh and Karakalpak. Sometimes they have letter changes like y → c (yaz - caz "summer"), f → p (fil → pĭl "elephant"), ç → ş (kiçkene → kĭşkene "small").

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') wich means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref> In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is this text found: "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. Kartlarımız ep Tatarca diyler. Kırım`da Kırımtatarca diyler. Mesele tuvul. Epsinin bir bolganın bılemiz.''" wich means "Crimean Tatar is understood when Tatar is spoken in Turkey. Our elders always say Tatar. In Crimea, they call it Crimean Tatar. No problem. We know that they are all one."<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com"/>

It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref> In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is this text found: "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. ---

@@ -41,7 +41,7 @@
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ==Number of speakers==
-Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided supp''ort to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
+Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
 An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Колоски (Сакский район), 2021, 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script sign in [[Saky Raion]] in 2021, along with Russian and Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref> In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is this text found: "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. Kartlarımız ep Tatarca diyler. Kırım`da Kırımtatarca diyler. Mesele tuvul. Epsinin bir bolganın bılemiz.''" which means "Crimean Tatar is understood when Tatar is spoken in Turkey. Our elders always say Tatar. In Crimea, they call it Crimean Tatar. No problem. We know that they are all one."<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com"/>
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }}</ref>
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
comment: Removed irrelevant information that added no context

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -683,7 +683,7 @@
 
 Historically, [[Arabic script]] was used from the sixteenth century. In the Soviet Union, it was replaced by a Latin alphabet based on [[Yañalif]] in 1928, and by a Cyrillic alphabet in 1938.
 
-Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> However there are some contradictions to the decision: virtually all [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, use the Latin script as their daughter languages [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] do, despite of the historical existence of [[Karelian alphabet|Karelian Cyrillic alphabet]].
+Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> However there are some contradictions to the decision: virtually all [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, use the Latin script as their sister languages [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] do, despite the historical existence of [[Karelian alphabet|Karelian Cyrillic alphabet]].
 
 In 1992, a Latin alphabet based on [[Common Turkic Alphabet]] was adopted by the decision of the [[Qurultay of the Crimean Tatar People]], which was formally supported by the [[Supreme Council of Crimea]] in 1997 but never implemented officially on practical level. However, in 2021, the [[Ministry of Reintegration of Temporarily Occupied Territories]] of Ukraine has announced it begins the implementation of the decision, with vice premier [[Oleksii Reznikov]] supporting the transition by stating that Latin corresponds better to Turkic phonetics. The ministry revealed it plans to finish the transition to Latin by 2025, which was supported by the [[Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People]]. The alphabet is co-developed by [[A. Yu. Krymskyi Institute of Oriental Studies]], [[Potebnia Institute of Linguistics]], Institute of Philology of [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]] and [[Tavrida National V.I. Vernadsky University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Урядовий комітет підтримав затвердження алфавіту кримськотатарської мови на основі латинської графіки|url=https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-20|website=minre.gov.ua|language=uk|archive-date=2021-09-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210918070914/https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cabinet approves Crimean Tatar alphabet based on Latin letters|url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-10-07|website=www.ukrinform.net|language=en|archive-date=2021-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211007222002/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
Rephrased a sentence regarding the use of the Latin script for Finnic languages, changing "daughter languages" to "sister languages".

Not Weaponised. The change is a neutral linguistic adjustment that does not introduce any weaponised narratives or perspectives related to cultural heritage.

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -660,7 +660,7 @@
 In [[Dobruja]] Crimean Tatars use '''Ĭ''' and '''W''', which is actually not found in Crimea. Ĭ is for [ı] sound (''Tĭl'' "language") and W for [w] sound (''Aywa'' "Quince"). Where in Crimea they use for [ı] and [i] the '''İ'''  letter (''Til'' "language") for [w] and [v] the '''V''' letter (''Ayva'' "Quince"). In dobruja they talk with  dialect which has some differences from the standard dialect. The dialect is Kipchak-Nogai which includes also Kazakh, Nogai and Karakalpak. There are very similarities with Nogai, Kazakh and Karakalpak. Sometimes they have letter changes like y → c (yaz - caz "summer"), f → p (fil → pĭl "elephant"), ç → ş (kiçkene → kĭşkene "small").
 {| class="wikitable"
 |-
-|'''Dobruja (also the nothern dialect)'''||'''Crimea'''||'''English'''
+|'''Dobruja (also the northern dialect)'''||'''Crimea'''||'''English'''
 |-
 |Üy||Ev||Home
 |-
llm_output:
Changed "nothern" to "northern" in the context of dialect description.

Not Weaponised – The change is a simple correction of a typographical error and does not carry any cultural or political implications.

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -64,6 +64,10 @@
 
 In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
+=== Tatar Textbooks in Romania ===
+
+Tatarca oquma kitabı 1. Sınıf (Alfabe)/ 2. Sınıf/3.Sınıf (''Tatarşa oqıma kitabı 1. Sınıf (Alfabe)/2. Sınıf/3. Sınıf'') are in [[Romania]] used textbooks for reading Tatar. [[Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin]], Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci, Nida Ablez and Risa Iusein wrote the books together with [[Democratic Union of Turkish-Muslim Tatars of Romania|UDTTMR]]. In the books is the latin alphabet shown. At the same time Ĭ and W letters are used in this books. And there is also mentioned that the letter Ğğ is written as Ǧǧ because of a print problem (Is mentioned in the book ''Tatarca oquma kitabı 2. Sınıf'').
+
 ==Phonology==
 
 ===Vowels===
llm_output:
Added a section titled "Tatar Textbooks in Romania" that discusses Tatar language textbooks used in Romania, including details about the authors and the alphabet used.

Not Weaponised – The content appears to be a factual addition about educational materials related to the Tatar language in Romania, without any evident political or cultural bias that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

{{flag|Ukraine}}{{cite web|title=To which languages does the Charter apply?|page=2|url=http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|work=European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages|publisher=Council of Europe|access-date=2014-04-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227174247/http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|archive-date=2013-12-27|url-status=dead}} | iso2 = crh | iso3 = crh | map = Crymean Tatar lang.png @@ -35,9 +35,9 @@ [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]] [[File:Колоски (Сакский район), 2021, 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script sign in [[Saky Raion]] in 2021, along with Russian and Ukrainian]] [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]] -'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}), is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }} In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is this text found: "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. Kartlarımız ep Tatarca diyler. Kırım`da Kırımtatarca diyler. Mesele tuvul. Epsinin bir bolganın bılemiz.''" which means "Crimean Tatar is understood when Tatar is spoken in Turkey. Our elders always say Tatar. In Crimea, they call it Crimean Tatar. No problem. We know that they are all one." - -A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}} +'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}), is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]]. Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}{{cite web | url=https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/my-books-sozlik-kt | title=Sózlík, Tatarşa-Kazakşa - Taner Murat }} In Sources of Gülzade Kaçamak and Alperen Kırım is this text found: "''Türkiye`de Tatarca degende Kırım Tatarcası annaşıla. Kartlarımız ep Tatarca diyler. Kırım`da Kırımtatarca diyler. Mesele tuvul. Epsinin bir bolganın bılemiz.''" which means "Crimean Tatar is understood when Tatar is spoken in Turkey. Our elders always say Tatar. In Crimea, they call it Crimean Tatar. No problem. We know that they are all one." + +A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}} ==Number of speakers== Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.{{e16|crh}} In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013 @@ -62,7 +62,7 @@ In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people. -In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.{{Cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}} +In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. According to the constitution of Ukraine, Ukrainian is the state language. Recognition of Russian and Crimean Tatar was a matter of political and legal debate. llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the deportation of the Crimean Tatars by the Soviet government, which is now stated to have led to the language being ranked by UNESCO as severely endangered. 

Weaponised

Justification: The mention of the "long-term ban" and the context of "deportation of the Crimean Tatars" invokes historical grievances and highlights cultural oppression, which can be used to frame narratives around victimization and the need for protection of cultural heritage.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of a sentence that states, "Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language." 

This addition provides specific terminology used by speakers of the northern dialect of the Crimean Tatar language, enhancing the cultural context of the dialects discussed.

Not Weaponised. The change does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage; it simply adds linguistic information.

@@ -684,7 +684,7 @@
 
 Historically, [[Arabic script]] was used from the sixteenth century. In the Soviet Union, it was replaced by a Latin alphabet based on [[Yañalif]] in 1928, and by a Cyrillic alphabet in 1938.
 
-Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> However there are some contradictions to the decision: virtually all [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, use the Latin script as their sister languages [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] do, despite the historical existence of [[Karelian alphabet|Karelian Cyrillic alphabet]].
+Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> However there are some contradictions to the decision: virtually all [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, currently use the Latin script as their sister languages [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] do, despite the historical existence of [[Karelian alphabet|Karelian Cyrillic alphabet]].
 
 In 1992, a Latin alphabet based on [[Common Turkic Alphabet]] was adopted by the decision of the [[Qurultay of the Crimean Tatar People]], which was formally supported by the [[Supreme Council of Crimea]] in 1997 but never implemented officially on practical level. However, in 2021, the [[Ministry of Reintegration of Temporarily Occupied Territories]] of Ukraine has announced it begins the implementation of the decision, with vice premier [[Oleksii Reznikov]] supporting the transition by stating that Latin corresponds better to Turkic phonetics. The ministry revealed it plans to finish the transition to Latin by 2025, which was supported by the [[Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People]]. The alphabet is co-developed by [[A. Yu. Krymskyi Institute of Oriental Studies]], [[Potebnia Institute of Linguistics]], Institute of Philology of [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]] and [[Tavrida National V.I. Vernadsky University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Урядовий комітет підтримав затвердження алфавіту кримськотатарської мови на основі латинської графіки|url=https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-20|website=minre.gov.ua|language=uk|archive-date=2021-09-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210918070914/https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cabinet approves Crimean Tatar alphabet based on Latin letters|url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-10-07|website=www.ukrinform.net|language=en|archive-date=2021-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211007222002/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

Ĭ is for [ı] sound (''Tĭl'' "language") and W for [w] sound (''Aywa'' "Quince"). Where in Crimea they use for [ı] and [i] the '''İ''' letter (''Til'' "language") for [w] and [v] the '''V''' letter (''Ayva'' "Quince"). In dobruja they talk with dialect which has some differences from the standard dialect. The dialect is Kipchak-Nogai which includes also Kazakh, Nogai and Karakalpak. @@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai|Bakhchisaray]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Колоски (Сакский район), 2021, 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script sign in [[Saky Raion]] in 2021, along with Russian and Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -64,10 +64,6 @@
 
 In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
-=== Tatar Textbooks in Romania ===
-
-Tatarca oquma kitabı 1. Sınıf (Alfabe)/ 2. Sınıf/3.Sınıf (''Tatarşa oqıma kitabı 1. Sınıf (Alfabe)/2. Sınıf/3. Sınıf'') are in [[Romania]] used textbooks for reading Tatar. [[Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin]], Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci, Nida Ablez and Risa Iusein wrote the books together with [[Democratic Union of Turkish-Muslim Tatars of Romania|UDTTMR]]. In the books is the latin alphabet shown. At the same time Ĭ and W letters are used in this books. And there is also mentioned that the letter Ğğ is written as Ǧǧ because of a print problem (Is mentioned in the book ''Tatarca oquma kitabı 2. Sınıf'').
-

--- 
+++ 
@@ -41,7 +41,7 @@
 
 ==Number of speakers==
 Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e25/> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
-An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.<ref>{{Cite web |title=e-Tatars: Virtual Community of the Crimean Tatar Diaspora |url=https://iccrimea.org/scholarly/e-tatars.html |access-date=2023-02-08 |website=iccrimea.org}}</ref> Of these an estimated {{sigfig|110,000|2}} still speak the language.<ref name=e25/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania ({{sigfig|22,000|2}}) and Bulgaria({{sigfig|1,370|2}}).<ref name=e25/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
+An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.<ref>{{Cite web |title=e-Tatars: Virtual Community of the Crimean Tatar Diaspora |url=https://iccrimea.org/scholarly/e-tatars.html |access-date=2023-02-08 |website=iccrimea.org}}</ref> Of these an estimated {{sigfig|110,000|2}} still speak the language.<ref name=e25/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania ({{sigfig|22,000|2}}) and Bulgaria ({{sigfig|1,370|2}}).<ref name=e25/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
-An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated {{sigfig|110,000|2}} still speak the language.<ref name=e25/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania ({{sigfig|22,000|2}}) and Bulgaria({{sigfig|1,370|2}}).<ref name=e25/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
+An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.<ref>{{Cite web |title=e-Tatars: Virtual Community of the Crimean Tatar Diaspora |url=https://iccrimea.org/scholarly/e-tatars.html |access-date=2023-02-08 |website=iccrimea.org}}</ref> Of these an estimated {{sigfig|110,000|2}} still speak the language.<ref name=e25/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania ({{sigfig|22,000|2}}) and Bulgaria({{sigfig|1,370|2}}).<ref name=e25/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

 ==Writing systems==
 {{main|Crimean Tatar alphabet}}
+[[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This Alphabet is used by the Tatars in Romania.]]
 Crimean Tatar is written in either the [[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]] or [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] alphabets, both modified to the specific needs of Crimean Tatar, and either used respective to where the language is used.
 
 Historically, [[Arabic script]] was used from the sixteenth century. In the Soviet Union, it was replaced by a Latin alphabet based on [[Yañalif]] in 1928, and by a Cyrillic alphabet in 1938.

--- 
+++ 
@@ -137,9 +137,9 @@
 The grammar of Crimean Tatar, like all Turkic languages, is [[Agglutinative language|agglutinating]],<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.33</ref> with the exclusive use of suffixing to express grammatical categories.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.85</ref>  Generally, suffixes are attached to the ends of word stems, although derivational [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]] makes uses of compounding as well.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.33</ref>  Overall, the grammatical structure of the language is similar to that of other West Kipchak varieties.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.2</ref>  Crimean Tatar is a [[Pro-drop language|pro-drop]] language<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.99</ref> with a generally [[Subject-object-verb word order|SOV word order]].<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.84</ref>
 
 === Morphophonology ===
-Crimean Tatar, like most Turkic languages, features pervasive [[Vowel harmony|vowel harmony]], which results in sound changes when suffixes are added to verb or noun stems.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.25</ref>  Essentially, the vowel in a suffix undergoes [[Assimilation (phonology)|assimilation]] to agree in certain categories with the vowel in the stem.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.26</ref>  The two main types of assimilation that characterize this agreement in Crimean Tatar morphophonology are [[Backness|backness]] harmony and [[Roundedness|rounding]] harmony.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.25</ref>
-
-Using the [[Transliteration|transliteration]] system in Kavitskaya (2010), non-high vowels undergoing backness harmony vary between [a] and [e], and are represented as '''A'''.  High vowels that undergo both backness and rounding harmony alternate between [i], [y], [ɪ] and [u] and are represented as '''I'''.  High vowels in suffixes that are never rounded and alternate between [i] and [ɪ] are represented as '''Y''', whereas high vowels in suffixes that are always round and alternate between [u] and [y] are represented as '''U'''.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.33</ref>
+Crimean Tatar, like most Turkic languages, features pervasive [[vowel harmony]], which results in sound changes when suffixes are added to verb or noun stems.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.25</ref>  Essentially, the vowel in a suffix undergoes [[Assimilation (phonology)|assimilation]] to agree in certain categories with the vowel in the stem.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.26</ref>  The two main types of assimilation that characterize this agreement in Crimean Tatar morphophonology are [[backness]] harmony and [[Roundedness|rounding]] harmony.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.25</ref>
+
+Using the [[transliteration]] system in Kavitskaya (2010), non-high vowels undergoing backness harmony vary between [a] and [e], and are represented as '''A'''.  High vowels that undergo both backness and rounding harmony alternate between [i], [y], [ɪ] and [u] and are represented as '''I'''.  High vowels in suffixes that are never rounded and alternate between [i] and [ɪ] are represented as '''Y''', whereas high vowels in suffixes that are always round and alternate between [u] and [y] are represented as '''U'''.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.33</ref>
 
 Some consonants undergo similar harmonizing changes depending on whether the preceding segment is voiced or voiceless, or whether the segment demonstrates backness harmony.  Consonants that alternate between [k], [q], [g] and [ɣ] are represented as '''K''', alternating [k] and [g] as '''G''', alternating [t] and [d] by '''D''', and alternating [tʃ] and [dʒ] as '''Ç'''.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.34</ref>
 
@@ -346,7 +346,7 @@
 
 '''Voice'''		
 
-[[Voice (grammar)|Grammatical voice]] is expressed by the addition of suffixes which come in sequence before negation, tense, aspect, mood and person markers.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.74</ref>  There are several [[Causative|causative]] suffixes which vary depending on the ending of the verb stem.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.73</ref>
+[[Voice (grammar)|Grammatical voice]] is expressed by the addition of suffixes which come in sequence before negation, tense, aspect, mood and person markers.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.74</ref>  There are several [[causative]] suffixes which vary depending on the ending of the verb stem.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.73</ref>

'''Converbs''' [[Converb]]s, a characteristic of many Turkic languages,Johanson 1995, p.314 express sequential or dependent action. Present tense converbs are formed by the addition of the suffixes -''A'' (used after consonants) and -''y'' (used after vowels). In past tense, converbs take the suffix -''Ip''.Kavitskaya 2010, p.77 Thus: -::''Asan evge kel'''ip''' evni temizledi''. -::Acaн eвгe keл'''ип''' eвни темизледи. -::Asan house-{{abbr|DAT|Dative}} come-{{abbr|'''CONV.PAST'''|Converb (Past Tense)|}} house-{{abbr|ACC|Accusative}} clean-{{abbr|VB|Verbalizing Suffix}}-{{abbr|PAST|Past Tense}} -::“Asan '''came''' home '''and cleaned''' the house.” + +{{fs interlinear|indent=3 +|Acaн eвгe keл'''ип''' eвни темизледи. +|Asan evge kel'''ip''' evni temizledi. +|Asan house-DAT come-'''CVB.PAST''' house-ACC clean-VB-PAST +|“Asan '''came''' home '''and cleaned''' the house.”}} === Nouns === Crimean Tatar noun stems take suffixes which express grammatical number, [[Grammatical case|case]] and possession. As in all other Turkic languages, there is no [[Grammatical gender|grammatical gender]] in Crimean Tatar.Kavitskaya 2010, p.35 Nouns are [[Declension|declined]] according to the following paradigm:Kavitskaya 2010, p.35
llm_output:
