@@ -49,7 +49,7 @@
 {{main|Crimean Tatar dialects}}
 [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|A speaker of Crimean Tatar, recorded in [[Romania]].]]
 
-The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak-Cuman]] branch and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://www.google.co.uk/books/edition/National_movements_and_national_identity/vqF1SIy9D3gC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=crimean+tartar+dialects&printsec=frontcover | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as nogai dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is in the Kipchak-Nogai branch spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> 
+The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[Bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak branch]] of the Turkic family and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://www.google.co.uk/books/edition/National_movements_and_national_identity/vqF1SIy9D3gC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=crimean+tartar+dialects&printsec=frontcover | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as ''Nogai'' dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> 
 
 Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the [[Turkic languages]], because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -694,7 +694,7 @@
 
 Historically, [[Arabic script]] was used from the sixteenth century. In the Soviet Union, it was replaced by a Latin alphabet based on [[Yañalif]] in 1928, and by a Cyrillic alphabet in 1938.
 
-Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> However there are some contradictions to the decision: virtually all [[Finnic languages]] spoken in Russia, however, currently use the Latin script as their sister languages [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] do, despite the historical existence of [[Karelian alphabet|Karelian Cyrillic alphabet]].
+Upon [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014]], Cyrillic became the sole allowed official script because according to the [[Constitutional Court of Russia]] decision made in 2004, all languages of Russia must use Cyrillic.<ref name="LangLaw2017" /> However there are some contradictions to the decision: virtually all [[Finnic languages]], including distantly-related [[Skolt Sámi]], spoken in Russia, however, currently use the Latin script as their sister languages [[Finnish language|Finnish]] and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] do, despite the historical existence of [[Karelian alphabet|Karelian Cyrillic alphabet]].
 
 In 1992, a Latin alphabet based on [[Common Turkic Alphabet]] was adopted by the decision of the [[Qurultay of the Crimean Tatar People]], which was formally supported by the [[Supreme Council of Crimea]] in 1997 but never implemented officially on practical level. However, in 2021, the [[Ministry of Reintegration of Temporarily Occupied Territories]] of Ukraine has announced it begins the implementation of the decision, with vice premier [[Oleksii Reznikov]] supporting the transition by stating that Latin corresponds better to Turkic phonetics. The ministry revealed it plans to finish the transition to Latin by 2025, which was supported by the [[Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People]]. The alphabet is co-developed by [[A. Yu. Krymskyi Institute of Oriental Studies]], [[Potebnia Institute of Linguistics]], Institute of Philology of [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]] and [[Tavrida National V.I. Vernadsky University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Урядовий комітет підтримав затвердження алфавіту кримськотатарської мови на основі латинської графіки|url=https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-20|website=minre.gov.ua|language=uk|archive-date=2021-09-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210918070914/https://minre.gov.ua/news/uryadovyy-komitet-pidtrymav-zatverdzhennya-alfavitu-krymskotatarskoyi-movy-na-osnovi-latynskoyi|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cabinet approves Crimean Tatar alphabet based on Latin letters|url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-10-07|website=www.ukrinform.net|language=en|archive-date=2021-10-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211007222002/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3320261-cabinet-approves-crimean-tatar-alphabet-based-on-latin-letters.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

 ==Classification and dialects==
 {{main|Crimean Tatar dialects}}
-[[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|A speaker of Crimean Tatar, recorded in [[Romania]].]]
+[[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|Crimean Tatar musician Negeadin Abit plays the song "Ay tek şatır", recorded in [[Romania]].]]
 
 The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[Bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak branch]] of the Turkic family and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqF1SIy9D3gC&q=crimean+tartar+dialects | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as ''Nogai'' dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref>

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e18/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ==Number of speakers==
-Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e16>{{e16|crh}}</ref> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
-An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated 2,000 still speak the language.<ref name=e16/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania (22,000), Bulgaria (6,000), and the United States.<ref name=e16/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
+Today, more than 260,000 [[Crimean Tatars]] live in [[Crimea]]. Approximately 150,000 reside in Central Asia (mainly in [[Uzbekistan]]), where their ancestors had been deported in 1944 during [[World War II]] by the Soviet Union. However, of all these people, mostly the older generations are the only ones still speaking Crimean Tatar.<ref name=e25/> In 2013, the language was estimated to be on the brink of extinction, being taught in only around 15 schools in Crimea. Turkey has provided support to Ukraine, to aid in bringing the schools teaching in Crimean Tatar to a modern state.<ref>[https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html Crimean Tatar language in danger] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011131236/https://www.avrupatimes.com/culture/3676-crimean-tatar-language-in-danger.html |date=2017-10-11 }}, ''Avrupa Times,'' 02/19/2013</ref>
+An estimated 5 million people of Crimean origin live in Turkey, descendants of those who emigrated in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} Of these an estimated {{sigfig|110,000|2}} still speak the language.<ref name=e25/> Smaller Crimean Tatar communities are also found in Romania ({{sigfig|22,000|2}}) and Bulgaria({{sigfig|1,370|2}}).<ref name=e25/> Crimean Tatar is one of the seriously endangered languages in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|title=Tapani Salminen, UNESCO Red Book on Endangered Languages: Europe, September 1999|work=University of Helsinki, Finland|access-date=27 February 2017|archive-date=3 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103194904/http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/europe_report.html#Crimean|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Almost all Crimean Tatars are bilingual or multilingual, using as their first language the dominant languages of their respective home countries, such as Russian, Turkish, Romanian, Uzbek, Bulgarian or Ukrainian.

- Updated the number of speakers of the Crimean Tatar language from "540,000" to "581,340".

- Adjusted the estimated number of Crimean Tatar speakers in Turkey from "2,000" to "110,000".
- Revised the population figures for Crimean Tatar communities in Romania and Bulgaria to "22,000" and "1,370", respectively.

Not Weaponised. The changes primarily involve updating statistical data and references without introducing any politically charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages,{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}
 
 == Romanian Tatar ==
-The Romanian Tatar language (properly ''Tatarșa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ'', {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}})<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]]. And is in Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language also borrowed many words from [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
+The Romanian Tatar language (properly ''Tatarșa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ'', {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}})<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]]. And is in Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language has also borrowed many words from [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
 
 ==History==
 {{see also|Crimean Tatar literature}}

 ==Writing systems==
 {{main|Crimean Tatar alphabet}}
-[[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Crimean Tatars in Romania.]]
 Crimean Tatar is written in either the [[Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic]] or [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] alphabets, both modified to the specific needs of Crimean Tatar, and either used respective to where the language is used.
 
 Historically, [[Arabic script]] was used from the sixteenth century. In the Soviet Union, it was replaced by a Latin alphabet based on [[Yañalif]] in 1928, and by a Cyrillic alphabet in 1938.
llm_output:
Removed an image reference to the "Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania."

Not Weaponised. The change is a simple removal of an image reference without any loaded language or context that could suggest a weaponisation of cultural heritage.

'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

--- 
+++ 
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages,{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}
 
 == Romanian Tatar ==
-The Romanian Tatar language (properly ''Tatarșa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref>, {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Romanian Tatars]]. And is in Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language also borrowed many words from [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
+The Romanian Tatar language (properly ''Tatarșa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ'', {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}})<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]]. And is in Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language also borrowed many words from [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].

-The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[Bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak branch]] of the Turkic family and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqF1SIy9D3gC&q=crimean+tartar+dialects | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as ''Nogai'' dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> 
+The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[Bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak branch]] of the Turkic family and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqF1SIy9D3gC&q=crimean+tartar+dialects | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as ''Nogai'' dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Many Crimean Tatars calls his language also ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' which means Tatar language.<ref>[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]</ref><ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> 
 
 Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the [[Turkic languages]], because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of a sentence regarding the northern dialect of the Crimean Tatar language. The original sentence stated, "Speakers of the northern dialect calls his language 'Tatarşa' or 'Tatar tĭlĭ' (''Tatar tili'') which means Tatar language." The revision changed it to "Many Crimean Tatars calls his language also 'Tatarşa' or 'Tatar tĭlĭ' which means Tatar language."

Not Weaponised. The change does not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives; it simply clarifies the statement about the northern dialect without altering the underlying context or implications.

 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages,{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}
 
 == Romanian Tatar ==
-The Romanian Tatar language (properly ''Tatarșa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ'', {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}})<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]]. And is in Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language has also borrowed many words from [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].

-Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}})<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'', {{lang-ro|Limba tătară crimeeană autentică}})<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/ro/alphabet Alfabetul limbii tătare crimeene din Dobrogea (Scythia Minor)]</ref> is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
+Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}})<ref name="tatarcasozluk.com">{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}</ref> also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'', {{lang-ro|Limba tătară crimeeană autentică}})<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/ro/alphabet Alfabetul limbii tătare crimeene din Dobrogea (Scythia Minor)]</ref> is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
+
+=== Dialects ===
+Romanian Tatar has three dialects: the Kırım or Bozkır dialect (''Şöl tĭlĭ''), the Nogay dialect (''Nogay tĭlĭ'') and the Yalıbolu dialect (''Yalıbolu tĭlĭ''). The Kırım dialect is spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars, while the other dialects have fewer speakers. They differ mainly in pronunciation, and to some extent in vocabulary.<ref name=RT/>
 
 === Alphabet ===
 The Alphabet used by [[Tatars of Romania]].<ref>{{cite book|title=ALFABE|location=Constanța|publisher=Editura Imperium|year=2015|page=[https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1795600770673670&set=ma-_-_-me-_-_-%C5%9Fa-_-_-ta-_-_-qirimtatartiliuyrenemiztatarlar-tatars-%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%80-tata 78]|isbn=978-606-93788-8-5|authors=Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin, Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci, Nida Ablez and Risa Iusein}}</ref>
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of a new section titled "Dialects" that describes the three dialects of Romanian Tatar, including details about their distribution and differences.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The content appears to be informative and descriptive about the Romanian Tatar language without any evident political or cultural bias that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -51,7 +51,6 @@
 
 ==Classification and dialects==
 {{main|Crimean Tatar dialects}}
-[[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|Crimean Tatar musician Negeadin Abit plays the song "Ay tek şatır", recorded in [[Romania]].]]
 
 The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[Bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak branch]] of the Turkic family and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqF1SIy9D3gC&q=crimean+tartar+dialects | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }}</ref> and the northern dialect, also known as ''Nogai'' dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} 
 
@@ -61,6 +60,7 @@
 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages,{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}
 
 == Romanian Tatar ==
+[[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|"Ay tek şatır" — known song among [[Tatars of Romania]]]]
 [[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Tatars in Romania]]
 Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
llm_output:
Removed a multimedia file reference of a Crimean Tatar musician and added a multimedia file reference of a known song among Tatars of Romania.

Not Weaponised. The changes made are related to the representation of cultural aspects of the Crimean Tatar and Romanian Tatar communities without invoking any politically charged narratives or terms.

 '''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -727,6 +727,7 @@
 
 == Romanian Tatar ==
 [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|"Ay tek şatır" — known song among [[Tatars of Romania]]]]
+[[File:Tatarşa supported by Wikimedia.jpg|thumb|Wikimedia supports Romanian Tatar]]
 [[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Tatars in Romania]]
 Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]]. And Wikimedia supports the language with the code crh-ro.<ref>[https://translatewiki.net/wiki/Portal:Crh Portal:Crh]</ref>

 Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages,{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].{{citation needed|date=June 2022}}

+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
comment: Undid revision 1154449690 by [[Special:Contributions/Yokubjon Juraev|Yokubjon Juraev]] ([[User talk:Yokubjon Juraev|talk]])
llm_output:
Removed "but still largely [[mutually intelligible]]" and replaced it with "and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]".

Not Weaponised. The change clarifies the relationship between the Crimean Tatar language and Tatar proper without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
 
 === Dialects ===
-Romanian Tatar has three dialects: the Kırım or Bozkır dialect (''Şöl tĭlĭ''), the Nogay dialect (''Noğay tĭlĭ'') and the Yalıbolu dialect (''Yalıbolu tĭlĭ''). The Kırım dialect is spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars, while the other dialects have fewer speakers. They differ mainly in pronunciation, and to some extent in vocabulary.<ref name=RT/>
+Romanian Tatar has three dialects: 
+
+1. The Kırım or Bozkır dialect (''Şöl tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars.
+
+2. The Nogay dialect (''Noğay tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars.
+
+3. The Yalıbolu dialect (''Yalıbolu tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars. 
+
+They differ mainly in pronunciation, and to some extent in vocabulary.<ref name=RT/>
 
 === Alphabet ===
 The Alphabet used by [[Tatars of Romania]].<ref>{{cite book|title=ALFABE|location=Constanța|publisher=Editura Imperium|year=2015|page=[https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1795600770673670&set=ma-_-_-me-_-_-%C5%9Fa-_-_-ta-_-_-qirimtatartiliuyrenemiztatarlar-tatars-%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%80-tata 78]|isbn=978-606-93788-8-5|authors=Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin, Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci, Nida Ablez and Risa Iusein}}</ref>

{{flag|Ukraine}}{{cite web|title=To which languages does the Charter apply?|page=2|url=http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|work=European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages|publisher=Council of Europe|access-date=2014-04-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227174247/http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|archive-date=2013-12-27|url-status=dead}} @@ -53,12 +53,15 @@ {{main|Crimean Tatar dialects}} [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|Crimean Tatar musician Negeadin Abit plays the song "Ay tek şatır", recorded in [[Romania]].]] -The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[Bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak branch]] of the Turkic family and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqF1SIy9D3gC&q=crimean+tartar+dialects | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }} and the northern dialect, also known as ''Nogai'' dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Many Crimean Tatars calls his language also ''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tĭlĭ'' which means Tatar language.[[Crimean Tatar dialects#Northern dialect]]{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}} +The Crimean Tatar language consists of three dialects. The standard language is written in the middle dialect ([[Bağçasaray]], orta yolaq), which is part of the otherwise largely extinct [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak branch]] of the Turkic family and is the most commonly spoken dialect.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} There is also the southern dialect, also known as the coastal dialect (yalıboyu, cenübiy), which is in the [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]] branch spoken in Turkey and Azerbaijan,{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqF1SIy9D3gC&q=crimean+tartar+dialects | isbn=9789004105096 | title=National movements and national identity among the Crimean Tatars: (1905-1916) | year=1996 | publisher=BRILL }} and the northern dialect, also known as ''Nogai'' dialect (noğay, çöl, şimaliy), which is spoken in Kazakhstan.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} Crimean Tatar has a unique position among the [[Turkic languages]], because its three "dialects" belong to three different (sub)groups of Turkic. This makes the classification of Crimean Tatar as a whole difficult.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} === Volga Tatar === Because of its common name, Crimean Tatar is sometimes mistaken to be a dialect of [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], or both being two dialects of the same language.{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} However, Tatar spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and the Volga-Ural region of Russia belongs to the different Bulgaric ({{lang-ru|кыпчакско-булгарская}}) subgroup of the Kipchak languages,{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} and its closest relative is [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]. Both Volga Tatar and Bashkir differ notably from Crimean Tatar, particularly because of the [[Tatar language#Historical shifts|specific Volga-Ural Turkic vocalism and historical shifts]].{{citation needed|date=June 2022}} + +== Romanian Tatar == +The Romanian Tatar language (properly ''Tatarșa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''{{cite web|url=https://tatarcasozluk.com/kelime/kirimtatarca-qirimtatarca-kirim-tatarcasi-tatarca-tatarsa-kirim-tatarsasi/ |title=Kırımtatarca, Qırımtatarca, Kırım Tatarcası, Tatarca, Tatarşa, Kırım Tatarşası |publisher=Tatarcasozluk.com |date= |accessdate=2022-08-27}}, {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish][https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space][https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA] which is widespread among the [[Romanian Tatars]]. And is in Kipchak-Nogai subgroup. The language also borrowed many words from [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]]. ==History== {{see also|Crimean Tatar literature}}

Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

llm_output:

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a neutral adjustment in the alphabetical listing without any cultural or political implications.

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -39,7 +39,7 @@
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Колоски (Сакский район), 2021, 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script sign in [[Saky Raion]] in 2021, along with Russian and Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] and thus are not [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] but still largely [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
comment: Crimean Tatar and Tatar are in fact mutually intelligible to a very large extent because the two belong to the one and the same group - Kipchak
llm_output:
Changed the phrase "thus are not mutually intelligible" to "but still largely mutually intelligible".

Not Weaponised. The change clarifies the relationship between Crimean Tatar and Tatar without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

 == Romanian Tatar ==
 [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|"Ay tek şatır" — known song among [[Tatars of Romania]]]]
 [[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Tatars in Romania]]
-[[File:Tatarşa.jpg|thumb|"Tatarşa" in Latin, Cyrillic, Arabic and Old Turkic script]]
+[[File:Tatarşa.jpg|thumb|Romanian Tatar in Latin, Cyrillic, Arabic and Old Turkic script]]
 Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]]. And Wikimedia supports the language with the code crh-ro.<ref>[https://translatewiki.net/wiki/Portal:Crh-RO Portal:Crh-RO]</ref> 
 
 === Dialects ===
llm_output:
Change: Replaced "Tatarşa" with "Romanian Tatar" in the description.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change appears to clarify the term used for the language variant without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -38,7 +38,7 @@
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Колоски (Сакский район), 2021, 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script sign in [[Saky Raion]] in 2021, along with Russian and Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] but still largely [[mutually intelligible]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2023|reason=What sources say it's mutually intelligible with Tatar proper?}} It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] but still largely [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
comment: Undid revision 1159074909 by [[Special:Contributions/Arctic Circle System|Arctic Circle System]] ([[User talk:Arctic Circle System|talk]]): no sources are needed in the lead of articles
llm_output:
Removed a citation needed tag from the description of the Crimean Tatar language.

Not Weaponised. The change is a technical edit regarding citation requirements and does not introduce or alter any narratives related to cultural heritage or conflict.

 == Romanian Tatar ==
+{{Main|Tatar language in Romania}}
 [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|"Ay tek şatır" — known song among [[Tatars of Romania]]]]
 [[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Tatars in Romania]]
 [[File:Tatarşa.jpg|thumb|Romanian Tatar in Latin, Cyrillic, Arabic and Old Turkic scripts]]
-Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]]. And Wikimedia supports the language with the code crh-ro.<ref>[https://translatewiki.net/wiki/Portal:Crh-RO Portal:Crh-RO]</ref> 
+Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].  
 
 === Subdialects ===
 Romanian Tatar has three subdialects:

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] but still largely [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] but still largely [[mutually intelligible]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2023|reason=What sources say it's mutually intelligible with Tatar proper?}} It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -726,7 +726,7 @@
 
 == Dobrujan Tatar ==
 {{Main|Dobrujan Tatar dialect}}
-[[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|Negeadin Abit singing in Dobrujan Tatar dialect]]
+[[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|Negeadin Abit is singing in Dobrujan Tatar dialect]]
 [[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Tatars in Romania]]
 [[File:Tatarşa.jpg|thumb|Romanian Tatar in Latin, Cyrillic, Arabic and Old Turkic scripts]]
 Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].
llm_output:

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor grammatical adjustment that does not alter the content's meaning or introduce any weaponised narratives.

@@ -38,7 +38,7 @@
 [[File:Bağçasaray Devlet Tarihiy-Medeniy Qoruması.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script on a plate in [[Bakhchysarai]] in 2009, along with Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Колоски (Сакский район), 2021, 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1.13|Crimean Tatar Latin script sign in [[Saky Raion]] in 2021, along with Russian and Ukrainian]]
 [[File:Crimean Tatar language.JPG|thumb|upright=1.13|An example of Crimean Tatar Arabic script]]
-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]] but still largely [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}}}) also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar proper]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the languages are related, but belong to two different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], yet still largely [[mutually intelligible]]. It has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>

changed_version:
---

@@ -729,7 +729,7 @@
 [[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|"Ay tek şatır" — known song among [[Tatars of Romania]]]]
 [[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Tatars in Romania]]
 [[File:Tatarşa.jpg|thumb|Romanian Tatar in Latin, Cyrillic, Arabic and Old Turkic scripts]]
-Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară română, Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].  
+Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].

Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].

@@ -67,6 +67,8 @@
 In 1876, the different Turkic Crimean dialects were made into a uniform written language by [[Ismail Gasprinski]]. A preference was given to the Oghuz dialect of the Yalıboylus, in order to not break the link between the Crimeans and the Turks of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1928, the language was reoriented to the middle dialect spoken by the majority of the people.
 
 In 1928, the alphabet was replaced with the [[Uniform Turkic Alphabet]] based on the [[Latin script]]. The Uniform Turkic Alphabet was replaced in 1938 by a [[Cyrillic alphabets|Cyrillic alphabet]]. During the 1990s and 2000s, the government of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea under Ukraine encouraged replacing the script with a Latin version again, but the Cyrillic has still been widely used (mainly in published literature, newspapers and education). The current Latin-based Crimean Tatar alphabet is the same as the [[Turkish alphabet]], with two additional characters: [[Ñ]] ñ and [[Q]] q. Currently, in the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]], all official communications and education in Crimean Tatar are conducted exclusively in the Cyrillic alphabet.<ref name="LangLaw2017">{{cite web|url=http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|title=Закон Республики Крым "О государственных языках Республики Крым и иных языках в Республике Крым"|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829004241/http://crimea.gov.ru/textdoc/ru/7/act/1562prz.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
+
+In the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russian-annexed]] [[Republic of Crimea]] the Crimean Tatar is declared to be one of state languages (the two others are Russian and Ukrainian).<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/activist-ukrainian-crimean-tatar-language-learning-being-squeezed-in-crimea/30355782.html Activist: Ukrainian, Crimean-Tatar Language Learning Being Squeezed In Crimea]</ref>
 
 ==Phonology==

-=== In Dobruja ===
+{{Duplication|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_Tatar_language#In_Dobruja|date=September 2023|dupe=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_Tatar_language#Dobrujan_Tatar}}=== In Dobruja ===
 In [[Dobruja]] Crimean Tatars use '''Ĭ''' and '''W''', which is actually not found in Crimea. Ĭ is for [ı] sound (''Tĭl'' "language") and W for [w] sound (''Aywa'' "Quince"). Where in Crimea they use for [ı] and [i] the '''İ'''  letter (''Til'' "language") for [w] and [v] the '''V''' letter (''Ayva'' "Quince"). In dobruja they talk with  dialect which has some differences from the standard dialect. The dialect is Kipchak-Nogai which includes also Kazakh, Nogai and Karakalpak. There are very similarities with Nogai, Kazakh and Karakalpak. Sometimes they have letter changes like y → c (yaz - caz "summer"), f → p (fil → pĭl "elephant"), ç → ş (kiçkene → kĭşkene "small").

---

@@ -737,13 +737,11 @@
 Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].  
 
 === Subdialects ===
-Romanian Tatar has three subdialects: 
-
-1. The Kırım or Bozkır dialect (''Şöl tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars.
-
-2. The Nogay dialect (''Noğay tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars.
-
-3. The Yalıbolu dialect (''Yalıbolu tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars. 
+Romanian Tatar has three subdialects:
+
+# The Kırım or Bozkır dialect (''Şöl tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars.
+# The Nogay dialect (''Noğay tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars.
+# The Yalıbolu dialect (''Yalıbolu tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars.
 
 They differ mainly in pronunciation, and to some extent in vocabulary.<ref name=RT/>
llm_output:
Changed formatting by adding bullet points to the list of subdialects of Romanian Tatar.

Not Weaponised – The change is purely structural and does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives.

 |Ç ç ||Çe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̱/ as in '''''ç'''a-'''ç'''a'' [ṯ͡ʃ̱ɑṯ͡ʃ̱ɑ] 'cha-cha' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̶/ as in '''''ç'''e'''ç'''en'' [t̶͡ʃ̶et̶͡ʃ̶en̶] 'chechen'.

-|F f ||Fe ||This letter occurs only in loanwords for it represents sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar language.  |-
