@@ -746,118 +746,82 @@
 === Alphabet ===
 In 1956 is a Latin alphabet developed by the Institute of Linguistics of the Romanian Academy for the Tatar language in Romania, with the letters Á á, Č č/Ç ç, Ğ ğ/C c, Î î/I ı, Í í/Ĭ ĭ, Ñ ñ, Ó ó/Ö ö, Ș ș, Ț ț/Ts ts, Ú ú/Ü ü.<ref name=RT/> The sounds for the letters î, ș and ț are from the Romanian alphabet. The sounds for the letters č, ğ, j, ñ, w and y are from a variety of languages.<ref Name=RT/> A new orthography was developed in 2010, which is now used by [[Democratic Union of Turkic-Muslim Tatars of Romania|UDTTMR]].<ref name=RT/><ref>{{cite book|title=ALFABE|location=Constanța|publisher=Editura Imperium|year=2015|page=[https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1795600770673670&set=ma-_-_-me-_-_-%C5%9Fa-_-_-ta-_-_-qirimtatartiliuyrenemiztatarlar-tatars-%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%80-tata 78]|isbn=978-606-93788-8-5|author1=Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin |author2=Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci |author3=Nida Ablez |author4=Risa Iusein }}</ref> Other alphabets was used by the writer [[Taner Murat]].<ref>[https://vebuka.com/print/170114173422-ad31c61dd7cdb69da4eb87d4e7c5f93e/Luceafarul_-_Sholpan_by_Mihai_Eminescu The translation of the book "''Luceafărul''" (Mihai Eminescu) by Taner Murat with this scripts]</ref><ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/ro/alphabet Latin alphabet used by Taner Murat]</ref> The Latin alphabet that he did use was from the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Literatures from the University of Bucharest, with the letters Á, Ç, Ğ, Ñ,  Î, Í, Ó, Ş, Ú. He did also use the Cyrillic script including the letters  Ә, Җ, І, Ң, Ө, Ү, Ў. Also the [[Old Turkic script]] and the [[Persian alphabet|Perso-Arabic script]], with the letter ڭ.

+|A a ||A ||This letter represents the '''low unrounded RTR or hard''' vowel /ɑ/ as in '''''a'''n'''a''''' [ɑṉɑ] 'mother'.
+|-
+|Á á||Hemzelí A||This letter occurring in a limited number of Arabic and Persian loanwords represents the '''near-low unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel not belonging to authentic Tatar language /æ/ as in ''s'''á'''t'' [s̶æ̶t̶] 'hour', 'clock'.
+|-
+|B b ||Be||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced bilabial stop''' /ḇ/ as in '''''b'''al'' [ḇaḻ] 'honey' and the '''soft voiced bilabial stop''' /b̶/ as in '''''b'''el'' [b̶el̶] 'waist'. 
+|-
+|Ç ç ||Çe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̱/ as in '''''ç'''a-'''ç'''a'' [ṯ͡ʃ̱ɑṯ͡ʃ̱ɑ] 'cha-cha' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̶/ as in '''''ç'''e'''ç'''en'' [t̶͡ʃ̶et̶͡ʃ̶en̶] 'chechen'.
+Common to Turkic languages, these sounds are quasi non-existent in Tatar spoken in Dobruja where they have shifted from «Ç» to «Ş». Therefore, although authentic, these sounds could be equally treated as academic.
+|-
+|D d ||De ||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: '''hard voiced dental stop''' /ḏ/ as in '''''d'''al'' [ḏaḻ] 'branch' and the '''soft voiced dental stop'''/d̶/ as in '''''d'''eren'' [d̶er̶en̶] 'deep'.
+|-
+|E e ||E ||This letter represents the '''mid unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel /e/ as in ''s'''e'''n [s̶en̶] 'you'.
+|-
+|F f ||Fe ||This letter occurs only in loanwords for it represents sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar language. In authentic reading the foreign sound is naturalized and the letter reads as letter «P». In academic reading it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless labio-dental fricative''' [f̱] as in '''''f'''al'' [f̱aḻ] 'destiny' and the '''soft voiceless labio-dental fricative''' [f̶] as in '''''f'''en'' [f̶en̶] 'technics'.
+|-
+|G g ||Ge||This letter represents the '''soft voiced palatal stop''' [ɟ̱] as in '''''g'''ene'' [ɟ̱en̶e] 'again', 'still' with its allophone the '''soft voiced velar stop''' /g/ as in '''''g'''úl'' [gu̶l̶] 'flower', 'rose'. It also represents the '''hard voiced uvular fricative''' /ʁ/ as in '''''g'''am'' [ʁɑm] 'grief'.
+|-
+|Ğ ğ ||Ğe||The letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced palato-alveolar affricate'''/ḏ͡ʒ̱/ as in '''''ğ'''ar'' [ḏ͡ʒ̱ɑṟ] 'abyss' and the '''soft voiced palato-alveolar affricate'''/d̶͡ʒ̶/ as in '''''ğ'''er'' [d̶͡ʒ̶er̶] 'place', 'ground'.
+|-
+|H h ||He||Representing sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar language this letter occurs only in loanwords. Most often, in authentic reading, when it reproduces the Arabic or Persian ه‍ it is a silent letter or, if it is located at the beginning or end of the word, the sound is usually naturalized and the letter reads as letter «K». When it reproduces ح or خ the sound is usually naturalized as /q/. In academic reading it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless glottal fricative''' /h/ as in ''ta'''h'''t'' [ṯɑhṯ] 'throne' and the '''soft voiceless uvular fricative''' /χ/ as in '''''h'''eşt'' [χeʃ̶t̶] 'eight'.
+|-
+|I i ||I||The letter represents the '''hight unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel /i/ as in ''b'''i'''ñ'' [b̶iŋ] 'thousand'.
+|-
+|Í í ||Hemzelí I, Kîska I, Zayîf I||This letter represents the '''hight unrounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ɨ/ as in ''b'''í'''r'' [b̶ɨr̶] 'one' is specific to Tatar.
+At the end of the word it is pronounced with half open mouth undergoing dilatation "''Keñiytúw''" and becoming '''mid unrounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' /ə/, also known as schwa, as in ''t'''í'''l'''í''''' [t̶ɨl̶ə] 'his tongue'.
+|-
+|Î î ||Kalpaklî I, Tartuwlî I ||This letter represents the '''hight unrounded RTR or hard''' vowel /ɯ/ as in '''''î'''şan'' [ɯʃ̱ɑṉ] 'mouse'.
+At the end of the word it is pronounced with half open mouth shifting through dilatation "''Keñiytúw''" to '''mid unrounded RTR or hard''' /ɤ/, close to schwa, as in ''ş'''î'''lapş'''î''''' [ʃ̱ɯḻɑp̱ʃ̱ɤ] 'trough'.
+|-
+|J j ||Je||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced palato-alveolar affricate''' /ʒ̱/ as in ''ta'''j''''' [ṯɑʒ̱] 'crown' and the '''soft voiced palato-alveolar affricate''' /ʒ̶/ as in ''be'''j''''' [b̶eʒ̶] 'beige'.
+|-
+|K k ||Ke||This letter represents the '''soft voiceless palatal stop''' /c/ as in '''''k'''el'' [cel̶] 'come!' and its allophone the '''soft voiceless velar stop''' /k/ as in '''''k'''ól'' [kɵl̶] 'lake'. It also represents the '''hard voiceless uvular stop''' /q/ as in '''''k'''al'' [qɑḻ] 'stay!'.
+|-
+|L l ||Le||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard alveolar lateral aproximant''' /ḻ/ as in ''ba'''l''''' [ḇɑḻ] 'honey' and the '''soft alveolar lateral aproximant''' /l̶/ as in ''be'''l''''' [b̶el̶] 'waist'.
+|-
+|M m ||Me||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard bilabial nasal''' /m̱/ as in '''''m'''aga'' [m̱ɑʁɑ] 'to me' and the '''soft bilabial nasal''' /m̶/ as in '''''m'''en'' [m̶en̶] 'I'.
+|-
+|N n ||Ne||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard dental nasal''' /ṉ/ as in ''a'''n'''a'' [ɑṉɑ] 'mother' and the '''soft dental nasal''' /n̶/ as in '''''n'''e'' [n̶e] 'what'.
+|-
+|Ñ ñ ||Eñ, Dalgalî Ne||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard uvular nasal''' /ɴ/ as in ''a'''ñ''''' [ɑɴ] 'conscience' and the '''soft velar nasal''' /ŋ/ as in ''e'''ñ''''' [eŋ] 'most'.
+|-
+|O o ||O||This letter represents the '''mid rounded RTR or hard''' vowel /o/ as in ''b'''o''''' [ḇo] 'this'.
+|-
+|Ó ó ||Noktalî O||This letter represents the '''mid rounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ɵ/ as in ''t'''ó'''r'' [t̶ɵr̶] 'background'.
+|-
+|P p ||Pe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless bilabial stap''' /p̱/ as in ''ğa'''p''''' [ḏ͡ʒ̱ɑp̱] 'close!' and the '''soft voiceless bilabial stop''' /p̶/ as in ''ğe'''p''''' [d̶͡ʒ̶ep̶] 'pocket'.
+|-
+|R r ||Re||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard alveolar trill''' /ṟ/ as in ''ta'''r''''' [ṯɑṟ] 'narrow' and the '''soft alveolar trill''' /r̶/ as in ''te'''r''''' [t̶er̶] 'sweat'.
+|-
+|S s ||Se||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless alveolar fricative''' /s̱/ as in '''''s'''al'' [s̱ɑḻ] 'raft' and the '''soft voiceless alveolar fricative''' /s̶/ as in '''''s'''el'' [s̶el̶] 'flood'.
+|-
+|Ş ş ||Şe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar fricative''' /ʃ̱/ as in '''''ş'''a'''ş''''' [ʃ̱ɑʃ̱] 'spread!' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar fricative''' /ʃ̶/ as in '''''ş'''e'''ş''''' [ʃ̶eʃ̶] 'untie'.
+|-
+|T t ||Te||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless dental stop''' /ṯ/ as in '''''t'''ar'' [ṯɑṟ] 'tight', 'narrow' and the '''soft voiceless dental stop''' /t̶/ as in '''''t'''er'' [t̶er̶] 'sweat'.
+|-
+|U u ||U||This letter represents the '''hight rounded RTR or hard''' vowel /u/ as in '''''u'''n'' [uṉ] 'flour'.
+|-
+|Ú ú ||Noktalî U||This letter represents the '''hight rounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ʉ/ as in ''s'''ú'''t'' [s̶ʉt̶] 'milk'.
+In the vicinity of semivowel y, which occurs rarely, its articulation shifts to '''high rounded ATR or soft''' /y/, close to Turkish pronunciation, as in ''s'''ú'''ymek'' [s̶ym̶ec] 'to love'.
+|-
+|V v ||Ve||This letter occurs only in loanwords for it represents sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar spoken in Romania. In authentic reading the foreign sound is naturalized and the letter reads sometimes as «W», sometimes as «B». In academic it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced labio-dental fricative''' /v̱/ as in '''''v'''als'' [v̱ɑḻs̱] 'waltz' and the '''soft voiced labio-dental fricative''' /v̶/ as in '''''v'''e'' [v̶e] 'and'.
+|-
+|W w ||We||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard labio-velar semivowel''' /w̱/ as in ''ta'''w''''' [ṯɑw̱] 'forest', 'mountain' and the '''soft labio-velar semivowel''' /w̶/ as in ''te'''w''''' [t̶ew̶] 'central', 'fundamental'.
+|-
+|Y y ||Ye||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard palatal semivowel''' /y̱/ as in ''ta'''y''''' [ṯɑy̱] 'foal' and the '''soft palatal semivowel''' /y̶/ as in '''''y'''er'' [y̶er̶] 'place', 'ground'.
+|-
+|Z z ||Ze||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced alveolar fricative''' /ẕ/ as in ''ta'''z''''' [ṯɑẕ] 'bald' and the '''soft voiced alveolar fricative''' /z̶/ as in ''te'''z''''' [t̶ez̶] 'quick'.
+|}
+

**Change Description:** Removed a table and replaced it with a new table that includes detailed sound descriptions and pronunciations for each letter of the Latin alphabet used in the Tatar language.

**Analysis:** The revision focuses on providing a more detailed and academic representation of the Tatar alphabet, which may serve to enhance the understanding of Tatar linguistic heritage. However, the context of the change does not include any language that could be interpreted as weaponizing cultural heritage. The content appears to be neutral and educational.

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised. The changes aim to clarify and enrich the linguistic content without promoting any divisive narratives.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -737,10 +737,10 @@
 === Dialects ===
 Tatar language in Romania has three dialects:<ref name=RT/><ref>Eker, Süer (2006). [http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf Ekstra küçük bir dil olarak Romanya "Tatar Türkçesi"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417073058/http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf |tarih=17 Nisan 2012 }}</ref> 
  
-# Dobruja Tatar, the Kîrîm or Bozkîr dialect (''Şól tílí'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars. Dobrudja Tatar is spoken mainly in the south and center of [[Constanța]] and has been heavily influenced by [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]].
-# Dobruja Nogai, the Nogay dialect (''Nogay tílí'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars. Dobruja Nogai is spoken in [[Tulcea]], near and far north of [[Constanța]], and is the most conservative in preserving [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] elements.
-# Dobruja Tat, the Yalîbolu dialect (''Yalîbolu tílí'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars. Dobruja Tat is spoken around the cities of Hacıoğlu Pazarcık ([[Dobrich]]) and is the closest to [[Oghuz languages]].  
-

+# The Nogay dialect (''Nogay tílí'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars. It's spoken in [[Tulcea]], near and far north of [[Constanța]], and is the most conservative in preserving [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] elements.

@@ -728,25 +728,6 @@
 
 '''гъ''', '''къ''', '''нъ''' and '''дж''' are separate letters ([[digraph (orthography)|digraphs]]).
 
-== Dobrujan Tatar ==
-{{Main|Dobrujan Tatar dialects}}
-[[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania]]
-Dobrujan Tatar or Romanian Tatar (''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tílí''; {{lang-ro|limba tătară}}) is the Tatar language of [[Romania]]. It includes  [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]] and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] dialects,<ref>https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php|title=Общие сведения о татарах Добруджи|website=Академия наук Республики Татарстан|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220119184546/http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|lang=ru|url=https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3|title=Дунайские или румынские татары. Откуда взялись и как живут в настоящее время|website=|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220118194703/https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3}}</ref><ref name=inform.tatar>{{cite news|url=https://tatar-inform.tatar/news/taner-murat-dobrudzha-tatarlaryny-un-yashlek-balalary-tatarcha-irken-s-yl-sh-bel-5082672|title=Танер Мурат: Добруджа татарларының ун яшьлек балалары татарча иркен сөйләшә белә|publisher=Tatar-inform|date=24 April 2018|language=tt}}</ref> but today there are no more longer sharp distinction between this dialects and it's mostly seen as a one language.<ref name=RT>{{cite web | url=https://www.academia.edu/19984869 | title=Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space | last1=Ismail | first1=Nilghiun }}</ref><ref name=STSP>[https://www.academia.edu/36788619/The_Sounds_of_Tatar_Spoken_in_Romania_The_Golden_Khwarezmian_Language_of_the_Nine_Noble_Nations The Sounds of Tatar Spoken in Romania: The Golden Khwarezmian Language of the Nine Noble Nations (Academia.edu)]</ref> This language belongs to [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic languages]], specifically to Kipchak-Nogai and is influenced by [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]].<ref name=RT/><ref name=STSP/>
-
-=== Dialects ===
-Tatar language in Romania has three dialects:<ref name=RT/><ref>Eker, Süer (2006). [http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf Ekstra küçük bir dil olarak Romanya "Tatar Türkçesi"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417073058/http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf |tarih=17 Nisan 2012 }}</ref> 
- 
-# The Şól dialect (''Şól tílí'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars. It's spoken mainly in the south and center of [[Constanța]] and has been heavily influenced by [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]].
-# The Nogay dialect (''Nogay tílí'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars. It's spoken in [[Tulcea]], near and far north of [[Constanța]], and is the most conservative in preserving [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] elements.
-# The Yalîbolu dialect (''Yalîbolu tílí'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars. It's spoken around the cities of Hacıoğlu Pazarcık ([[Dobrich]]) and is the closest to [[Oghuz languages]]. 
- 
-They differ mainly in pronunciation, and to some extent in vocabulary.<ref name=RT/>
-
-=== Alphabet ===
-In 1956 is a Latin alphabet developed by the Institute of Linguistics of the Romanian Academy for the Tatar language in Romania, with the letters Á á, Č č/Ç ç, Ğ ğ/C c, Î î/I ı, Í í/Ĭ ĭ, Ñ ñ, Ó ó/Ö ö, Ș ș, Ț ț/Ts ts, Ú ú/Ü ü.<ref name=RT/> The sounds for the letters î, ș and ț are from the Romanian alphabet. The sounds for the letters č, ğ, j, ñ, w and y are from a variety of languages.<ref Name=RT/> A new orthography was developed in 2010, which is now used by [[Democratic Union of Turkic-Muslim Tatars of Romania|UDTTMR]].<ref name=RT/><ref>{{cite book|title=ALFABE|location=Constanța|publisher=Editura Imperium|year=2015|page=[https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1795600770673670&set=ma-_-_-me-_-_-%C5%9Fa-_-_-ta-_-_-qirimtatartiliuyrenemiztatarlar-tatars-%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%80-tata 78]|isbn=978-606-93788-8-5|author1=Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin |author2=Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci |author3=Nida Ablez |author4=Risa Iusein }}</ref> Other alphabets was used by the writer [[Taner Murat]].<ref>[https://vebuka.com/print/170114173422-ad31c61dd7cdb69da4eb87d4e7c5f93e/Luceafarul_-_Sholpan_by_Mihai_Eminescu The translation of the book "''Luceafărul''" (Mihai Eminescu) by Taner Murat with this scripts]</ref><ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/ro/alphabet Latin alphabet used by Taner Murat]</ref> The Latin alphabet that he did use was from the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Literatures from the University of Bucharest, with the letters Á, Ç, Ğ, Ñ,  Î, Í, Ó, Ş, Ú. He did also use the Cyrillic script including the letters  Ә, Җ, І, Ң, Ө, Ү, Ў. Also the [[Old Turkic script]] and the [[Persian alphabet|Perso-Arabic script]], with the letter ڭ.
-
-Mostly is [[Latin script]] used, but in diaspora probably also [[Cyrillic script]]. The other alphabets are actually not widespread among the minority.
-
 ==Legal status==
 
 The Crimean peninsula is internationally recognized as territory of Ukraine, but since the 2014 [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation by the Russian Federation]] is de facto administered as part of the Russian Federation.

-{| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-feature-settings:'cv50' 1;"
-|-
-!<small>Latin character</small>
-!<small>Name</small>
-!<small>Sound description and pronunciation</small>
-|-
-|A a ||A ||This letter represents the '''low unrounded RTR or hard''' vowel /ɑ/ as in '''''a'''n'''a''''' [ɑṉɑ] 'mother'.
-|-
-|Á á||Hemzelí A||This letter occurring in a limited number of Arabic and Persian loanwords represents the '''near-low unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel not belonging to authentic Tatar language /æ/ as in ''s'''áá'''t'' [s̶ææt̶] 'hour', 'clock'.
-|-
-|B b ||Be||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced bilabial stop''' /ḇ/ as in '''''b'''al'' [ḇaḻ] 'honey' and the '''soft voiced bilabial stop''' /b̶/ as in '''''b'''el'' [b̶el̶] 'waist'. 
-|-
-|Ç ç ||Çe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ṯ͡ʃ̱/ as in '''''ç'''a-'''ç'''a'' [ṯ͡ʃ̱ɑṯ͡ʃ̱ɑ] 'cha-cha' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /t̶͡ʃ̶/ as in '''''ç'''e'''ç'''en'' [t̶͡ʃ̶et̶͡ʃ̶en̶] 'chechen'.
-Common to Turkic languages, these sounds are quasi non-existent in Tatar spoken in Dobruja where they have shifted from «Ç» to «Ş». Therefore, although authentic, these sounds could be equally treated as academic.
-|-
-|D d ||De ||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: '''hard voiced dental stop''' /ḏ/ as in '''''d'''al'' [ḏɑḻ] 'branch' and the '''soft voiced dental stop'''/d̶/ as in '''''d'''eren'' [d̶er̶en̶] 'deep'.
-|-
-|E e ||E ||This letter represents the '''mid unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel /e/ as in ''s'''e'''n [s̶en̶] 'you'.
-|-
-|F f ||Fe ||This letter occurs only in loanwords for it represents sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar language. In authentic reading the foreign sound is naturalized and the letter reads as letter «P». In academic reading it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless labio-dental fricative''' [f̱] as in '''''f'''al'' [f̱ɑḻ] 'destiny' and the '''soft voiceless labio-dental fricative''' [f̶] as in '''''f'''en'' [f̶en̶] 'technics'.
-|-
-|G g ||Ge||This letter represents the '''soft voiced palatal stop''' [ɟ̱] as in '''''g'''ene'' [ɟ̱en̶e] 'again', 'still' with its allophone the '''soft voiced velar stop''' /g/ as in '''''g'''úl'' [gu̶l̶] 'flower', 'rose'. It also represents the '''hard voiced uvular fricative''' /ʁ/ as in '''''g'''am'' [ʁɑm] 'grief'.
-|-
-|Ğ ğ ||Ğe||The letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced palato-alveolar affricate'''/ḏ͡ʒ̱/ as in '''''ğ'''ar'' [ḏ͡ʒ̱ɑṟ] 'abyss' and the '''soft voiced palato-alveolar affricate'''/d̶͡ʒ̶/ as in '''''ğ'''er'' [d̶͡ʒ̶er̶] 'place', 'ground'.
-|-
-|H h ||He||Representing sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar language this letter occurs only in loanwords. Most often, in authentic reading, when it reproduces the Arabic or Persian ه‍ it is a silent letter or, if it is located at the beginning or end of the word, the sound is usually naturalized and the letter reads as letter «K». When it reproduces ح or خ the sound is usually naturalized as /q/. In academic reading it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless glottal fricative''' /h/ as in ''ta'''h'''t'' [ṯɑhṯ] 'throne' and the '''soft voiceless uvular fricative''' /χ/ as in '''''h'''eşt'' [χeʃ̶t̶] 'eight'.
-|-
-|I i ||I||The letter represents the '''hight unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel /i/ as in ''b'''i'''ñ'' [b̶iŋ] 'thousand'.
-|-
-|Í í ||Hemzelí I, Kîska I, Zayîf I||This letter represents the '''hight unrounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ɨ/ as in ''b'''í'''r'' [b̶ɨr̶] 'one' is specific to Tatar.
-At the end of the word it is pronounced with half open mouth undergoing dilatation "''Keñiytúw''" and becoming '''mid unrounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' /ə/, also known as schwa, as in ''t'''í'''l'''í''''' [t̶ɨl̶ə] 'his tongue'.
-|-
-|Î î ||Kalpaklî I, Tartuwlî I ||This letter represents the '''hight unrounded RTR or hard''' vowel /ɯ/ as in '''''î'''şan'' [ɯʃ̱ɑṉ] 'mouse'.
-At the end of the word it is pronounced with half open mouth shifting through dilatation "''Keñiytúw''" to '''mid unrounded RTR or hard''' /ɤ/, close to schwa, as in ''ş'''î'''lapş'''î''''' [ʃ̱ɯḻɑp̱ʃ̱ɤ] 'trough'.
-|-
-|J j ||Je||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced palato-alveolar affricate''' /ʒ̱/ as in ''ta'''j''''' [ṯɑʒ̱] 'crown' and the '''soft voiced palato-alveolar affricate''' /ʒ̶/ as in ''be'''j''''' [b̶eʒ̶] 'beige'.
-|-
-|K k ||Ke||This letter represents the '''soft voiceless palatal stop''' /c/ as in '''''k'''el'' [cel̶] 'come!' and its allophone the '''soft voiceless velar stop''' /k/ as in '''''k'''ól'' [kɵl̶] 'lake'. It also represents the '''hard voiceless uvular stop''' /q/ as in '''''k'''al'' [qɑḻ] 'stay!'.
-|-
-|L l ||Le||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard alveolar lateral aproximant''' /ḻ/ as in ''ba'''l''''' [ḇɑḻ] 'honey' and the '''soft alveolar lateral aproximant''' /l̶/ as in ''be'''l''''' [b̶el̶] 'waist'.
-|-
-|M m ||Me||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard bilabial nasal''' /m̱/ as in '''''m'''aga'' [m̱ɑʁɑ] 'to me' and the '''soft bilabial nasal''' /m̶/ as in '''''m'''en'' [m̶en̶] 'I'.
-|-
-|N n ||Ne||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard dental nasal''' /ṉ/ as in ''a'''n'''a'' [ɑṉɑ] 'mother' and the '''soft dental nasal''' /n̶/ as in '''''n'''e'' [n̶e] 'what'.
-|-
-|Ñ ñ ||Eñ, Dalgalî Ne||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard uvular nasal''' /ɴ/ as in ''a'''ñ''''' [ɑɴ] 'conscience' and the '''soft velar nasal''' /ŋ/ as in ''e'''ñ''''' [eŋ] 'most'.
-|-
-|O o ||O||This letter represents the '''mid rounded RTR or hard''' vowel /o/ as in ''b'''o''''' [ḇo] 'this'.
-|-
-|Ó ó ||Noktalî O||This letter represents the '''mid rounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ɵ/ as in ''t'''ó'''r'' [t̶ɵr̶] 'background'.
-|-
-|P p ||Pe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless bilabial stap''' /p̱/ as in ''ğa'''p''''' [ḏ͡ʒ̱ɑp̱] 'close!' and the '''soft voiceless bilabial stop''' /p̶/ as in ''ğe'''p''''' [d̶͡ʒ̶ep̶] 'pocket'.
-|-
-|R r ||Re||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard alveolar trill''' /ṟ/ as in ''ta'''r''''' [ṯɑṟ] 'narrow' and the '''soft alveolar trill''' /r̶/ as in ''te'''r''''' [t̶er̶] 'sweat'.
-|-
-|S s ||Se||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless alveolar fricative''' /s̱/ as in '''''s'''al'' [s̱ɑḻ] 'raft' and the '''soft voiceless alveolar fricative''' /s̶/ as in '''''s'''el'' [s̶el̶] 'flood'.
-|-
-|Ş ş ||Şe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar fricative''' /ʃ̱/ as in '''''ş'''a'''ş''''' [ʃ̱ɑʃ̱] 'spread!' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar fricative''' /ʃ̶/ as in '''''ş'''e'''ş''''' [ʃ̶eʃ̶] 'untie'.
-|-
-|T t ||Te||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless dental stop''' /ṯ/ as in '''''t'''ar'' [ṯɑṟ] 'tight', 'narrow' and the '''soft voiceless dental stop''' /t̶/ as in '''''t'''er'' [t̶er̶] 'sweat'.
-|-
-|U u ||U||This letter represents the '''hight rounded RTR or hard''' vowel /u/ as in '''''u'''n'' [uṉ] 'flour'.
-|-
-|Ú ú ||Noktalî U||This letter represents the '''hight rounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ʉ/ as in ''s'''ú'''t'' [s̶ʉt̶] 'milk'.
-In the vicinity of semivowel y, which occurs rarely, its articulation shifts to '''high rounded ATR or soft''' /y/, close to Turkish pronunciation, as in ''s'''ú'''ymek'' [s̶ym̶ec] 'to love'.
-|-
-|V v ||Ve||This letter occurs only in loanwords for it represents sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar spoken in Romania. In authentic reading the foreign sound is naturalized and the letter reads sometimes as «W», sometimes as «B». In academic it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced labio-dental fricative''' /v̱/ as in '''''v'''als'' [v̱ɑḻs̱] 'waltz' and the '''soft voiced labio-dental fricative''' /v̶/ as in '''''v'''e'' [v̶e] 'and'.
-|-
-|W w ||We||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard labio-velar semivowel''' /w̱/ as in ''ta'''w''''' [ṯɑw̱] 'forest', 'mountain' and the '''soft labio-velar semivowel''' /w̶/ as in ''te'''w''''' [t̶ew̶] 'central', 'fundamental'.
-|-
-|Y y ||Ye||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard palatal semivowel''' /y̱/ as in ''ta'''y''''' [ṯɑy̱] 'foal' and the '''soft palatal semivowel''' /y̶/ as in '''''y'''er'' [y̶er̶] 'place', 'ground'.
-|-
-|Z z ||Ze||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced alveolar fricative''' /ẕ/ as in ''ta'''z''''' [ṯɑẕ] 'bald' and the '''soft voiced alveolar fricative''' /z̶/ as in ''te'''z''''' [t̶ez̶] 'quick'.
-|}
-
-[[File:TanerMuratABC.jpg|thumb|Latin and Cyrillic alphabets used by [[Taner Murat]]]]
+Mostly is [[Latin script]] used, but in diaspora probably also [[Cyrillic script]]. The other alphabets are actually not widespread among the minority.
 
 ==Legal status==
llm_output:
Removed a detailed table of Tatar alphabet sounds and replaced it with a brief statement about the use of Latin and Cyrillic scripts among the diaspora.

Not Weaponised – The change does not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives; it simply condenses information about the Tatar language scripts without altering the cultural context.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

llm_output:
Changed the designation from "Autonomous Republic of Crimea" to "Republic of Crimea" and added context regarding the status of Crimea as disputed between Russia and Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a factual update regarding the political status of Crimea without employing loaded language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -731,26 +731,24 @@
 
 == Dobrujan Tatar ==
 {{Main|Dobrujan Tatar dialect}}
-[[File:WIKITONGUES- Neceadin speaking Crimean Tatar.webm|thumb|Negeadin Abit, Tatar Saz player from Romania]]
-[[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|This alphabet is used by Tatars in Romania]]
-[[File:Tatarşa.jpg|thumb|Romanian Tatar in Latin, Cyrillic, Arabic and Old Turkic scripts]]
-Romanian Tatar or Dobrujan Tatar (''Tatarşa'', ''Tatar tĭlĭ''; {{lang-ro|Limba tătară}}) also known as Authentic Crimean Tatar (''Calpaq Qırımtatarşa'') is a variant of the Crimean Tatar language,<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish As an Extra Small Language Romanian Tatar Turkish]</ref><ref name=RT>[https://www.academia.edu/19984869/Romanian_Tatar_language_communication_in_the_multicultural_space Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref> which is widespread among the [[Tatars of Romania|Romanian Tatars]] and part of the Kipchak-Nogai branch. The language has borrowed many words from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. The language is spoken primarily in the [[Dobruja]] region of [[Romania]], but also has speakers in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Turkey]].  
-
-=== Subdialects ===
-Romanian Tatar has three subdialects:
-
-# The Kırım or Bozkır dialect (''Şöl tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars.
-# The Nogay dialect (''Noğay tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars.
-# The Yalıbolu dialect (''Yalıbolu tĭlĭ'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars.
+[[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania]]
+Dobrujan Tatar or Romanian Tatar (''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tílí''; {{lang-ro|limba tătară}}) is the Tatar language of [[Romania]]. It includes  [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]] and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] dialects,<ref>https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php|title=Общие сведения о татарах Добруджи|website=Академия наук Республики Татарстан|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220119184546/http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|lang=ru|url=https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3|title=Дунайские или румынские татары. Откуда взялись и как живут в настоящее время|website=|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220118194703/https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3}}</ref><ref name=inform.tatar>{{cite news|url=https://tatar-inform.tatar/news/taner-murat-dobrudzha-tatarlaryny-un-yashlek-balalary-tatarcha-irken-s-yl-sh-bel-5082672|title=Танер Мурат: Добруджа татарларының ун яшьлек балалары татарча иркен сөйләшә белә|publisher=Tatar-inform|date=24 April 2018|language=tt}}</ref> but today there are no more longer sharp distinction between this dialects and it's mostly seen as a one language.<ref name=RT>{{cite web | url=https://www.academia.edu/19984869 | title=Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space | last1=Ismail | first1=Nilghiun }}</ref><ref name=STSP>[https://www.academia.edu/36788619/The_Sounds_of_Tatar_Spoken_in_Romania_The_Golden_Khwarezmian_Language_of_the_Nine_Noble_Nations The Sounds of Tatar Spoken in Romania: The Golden Khwarezmian Language of the Nine Noble Nations (Academia.edu)]</ref> This language belongs to [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic languages]], specifically to Kipchak-Nogai and is influenced by [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]].<ref name=RT/><ref name=STSP/>
+
+=== Dialects ===
+Tatar language in Romania has three dialects:<ref name=RT/><ref>Eker, Süer (2006). [http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf Ekstra küçük bir dil olarak Romanya "Tatar Türkçesi"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417073058/http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf |tarih=17 Nisan 2012 }}</ref> 
+ 
+# Dobruja Tatar, the Kîrîm or Bozkîr dialect (''Şól tílí'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars. Dobrudja Tatar is spoken mainly in the south and center of [[Constanța]] and has been heavily influenced by [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]].
+# Dobruja Nogai, the Nogay dialect (''Nogay tílí'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars. Dobruja Nogai is spoken in [[Tulcea]], near and far north of [[Constanța]], and is the most conservative in preserving [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] elements.
+# Dobruja Tat, the Yalîbolu dialect (''Yalîbolu tílí'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars. Dobruja Tat is spoken around the cities of Hacıoğlu Pazarcık ([[Dobrich]]) and is the closest to [[Oghuz languages]].  
 
 They differ mainly in pronunciation, and to some extent in vocabulary.<ref name=RT/>
 
 === Alphabet ===
-In 1956 is a Latin alphabet developed by the Institute of Linguistics of the Romanian Academy for Romanian Tatar, with the letters Á á, Č č/Ç ç, Ğ ğ/C c, Î î/I ı, Í í/Ĭ ĭ, Ñ ñ, Ó ó/Ö ö, Ș ș, Ț ț/Ts ts, Ú ú/Ü ü.<ref name=RT/> A new orthography was developed in 2010, which is now used by [[Tatars of Romania]].<ref name=RT/><ref>{{cite book|title=ALFABE|location=Constanța|publisher=Editura Imperium|year=2015|page=[https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1795600770673670&set=ma-_-_-me-_-_-%C5%9Fa-_-_-ta-_-_-qirimtatartiliuyrenemiztatarlar-tatars-%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%80-tata 78]|isbn=978-606-93788-8-5|author1=Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin |author2=Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci |author3=Nida Ablez |author4=Risa Iusein }}</ref>
+In 1956 is a Latin alphabet developed by the Institute of Linguistics of the Romanian Academy for the Tatar language in Romania, with the letters Á á, Č č/Ç ç, Ğ ğ/C c, Î î/I ı, Í í/Ĭ ĭ, Ñ ñ, Ó ó/Ö ö, Ș ș, Ț ț/Ts ts, Ú ú/Ü ü.<ref name=RT/> The sounds for the letters î, ș and ț are from the Romanian alphabet. The sounds for the letters č, ğ, j, ñ, w and y are from a variety of languages.<ref Name=RT/> A new orthography was developed in 2010, which is now used by [[Democratic Union of Turkic-Muslim Tatars of Romania|UDTTMR]].<ref name=RT/><ref>{{cite book|title=ALFABE|location=Constanța|publisher=Editura Imperium|year=2015|page=[https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1795600770673670&set=ma-_-_-me-_-_-%C5%9Fa-_-_-ta-_-_-qirimtatartiliuyrenemiztatarlar-tatars-%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%80-tata 78]|isbn=978-606-93788-8-5|author1=Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin |author2=Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci |author3=Nida Ablez |author4=Risa Iusein }}</ref> Other alphabets was used by the writer [[Taner Murat]].<ref>[https://vebuka.com/print/170114173422-ad31c61dd7cdb69da4eb87d4e7c5f93e/Luceafarul_-_Sholpan_by_Mihai_Eminescu The translation of the book "''Luceafărul''" (Mihai Eminescu) by Taner Murat with this scripts]</ref><ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/ro/alphabet Latin alphabet used by Taner Murat]</ref> The Latin alphabet that he did use was from the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Literatures from the University of Bucharest, with the letters Á, Ç, Ğ, Ñ,  Î, Í, Ó, Ş, Ú. He did also use the Cyrillic script including the letters  Ә, Җ, І, Ң, Ө, Ү, Ў. Also the [[Old Turkic script]] and the [[Persian alphabet|Perso-Arabic script]], with the letter ڭ.
+

-Other alphabets was used by the writer [[Taner Murat]].<ref>[https://vebuka.com/print/170114173422-ad31c61dd7cdb69da4eb87d4e7c5f93e/Luceafarul_-_Sholpan_by_Mihai_Eminescu The translation of the book "''Luceafărul''" (Mihai Eminescu) by Taner Murat with this scripts]</ref><ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/ro/alphabet Latin alphabet used by Taner Murat]</ref> The Latin alphabet that he did use was different, with the letters Á, Ç, Ğ, Ñ,  Î, Í, Ó, Ş, Ú and the Cyrillic script including the letters  Ә, Җ, І, Ң, Ө, Ү, Ў. Also the [[Old Turkic script]] and the [[Persian alphabet|Perso-Arabic script]], with the letter ڭ.

The change made in this revision involved the **removal of several images and the rephrasing of the description of the Dobrujan Tatar language**, along with the addition of new dialect classifications and details about the language's influence and alphabet.

**Removed**:

- The section header "=== Subdialects ===" and its content detailing the subdialects.

**Added**:

**Rephrased**:
- The description of the Dobrujan Tatar language, emphasizing its classification and dialects.

**Comment**: The user, "Zolgoyo," provided a comment indicating the focus on the "Dobrujan Tatar" section, suggesting an intent to clarify or enhance the representation of this cultural aspect.

**Analysis**: The changes do not appear to weaponize cultural heritage. They seem to aim at providing a clearer and more structured representation of the Dobrujan Tatar language and its dialects without invoking any contentious narratives or perspectives.

**Conclusion**: Not Weaponised. The edits focus on linguistic clarity and organization rather than promoting a divisive or politically charged narrative.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

 == Dobrujan Tatar ==
-{{Main|Dobrujan Tatar dialect}}
+{{Main|Dobrujan Tatar dialects}}
 [[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania]]
 Dobrujan Tatar or Romanian Tatar (''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tílí''; {{lang-ro|limba tătară}}) is the Tatar language of [[Romania]]. It includes  [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]] and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] dialects,<ref>https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php|title=Общие сведения о татарах Добруджи|website=Академия наук Республики Татарстан|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220119184546/http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|lang=ru|url=https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3|title=Дунайские или румынские татары. Откуда взялись и как живут в настоящее время|website=|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220118194703/https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3}}</ref><ref name=inform.tatar>{{cite news|url=https://tatar-inform.tatar/news/taner-murat-dobrudzha-tatarlaryny-un-yashlek-balalary-tatarcha-irken-s-yl-sh-bel-5082672|title=Танер Мурат: Добруджа татарларының ун яшьлек балалары татарча иркен сөйләшә белә|publisher=Tatar-inform|date=24 April 2018|language=tt}}</ref> but today there are no more longer sharp distinction between this dialects and it's mostly seen as a one language.<ref name=RT>{{cite web | url=https://www.academia.edu/19984869 | title=Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space | last1=Ismail | first1=Nilghiun }}</ref><ref name=STSP>[https://www.academia.edu/36788619/The_Sounds_of_Tatar_Spoken_in_Romania_The_Golden_Khwarezmian_Language_of_the_Nine_Noble_Nations The Sounds of Tatar Spoken in Romania: The Golden Khwarezmian Language of the Nine Noble Nations (Academia.edu)]</ref> This language belongs to [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic languages]], specifically to Kipchak-Nogai and is influenced by [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]].<ref name=RT/><ref name=STSP/>
llm_output:
Changed "Dobrujan Tatar dialect" to "Dobrujan Tatar dialects".

Not Weaponised. The change is a simple grammatical adjustment to pluralize "dialect" to "dialects" and does not carry any loaded or politically charged language.

{{stub}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -753,11 +753,11 @@
 |-
 |A a ||A ||This letter represents the '''low unrounded RTR or hard''' vowel /ɑ/ as in '''''a'''n'''a''''' [ɑṉɑ] 'mother'.
 |-
-|Á á||Hemzelí A||This letter occurring in a limited number of Arabic and Persian loanwords represents the '''near-low unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel not belonging to authentic Tatar language /æ/ as in ''s'''á'''t'' [s̶æ̶t̶] 'hour', 'clock'.
+|Á á||Hemzelí A||This letter occurring in a limited number of Arabic and Persian loanwords represents the '''near-low unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel not belonging to authentic Tatar language /æ/ as in ''s'''áá'''t'' [s̶ææt̶] 'hour', 'clock'.
 |-
 |B b ||Be||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced bilabial stop''' /ḇ/ as in '''''b'''al'' [ḇaḻ] 'honey' and the '''soft voiced bilabial stop''' /b̶/ as in '''''b'''el'' [b̶el̶] 'waist'. 
 |-
-|Ç ç ||Çe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̱/ as in '''''ç'''a-'''ç'''a'' [ṯ͡ʃ̱ɑṯ͡ʃ̱ɑ] 'cha-cha' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̶/ as in '''''ç'''e'''ç'''en'' [t̶͡ʃ̶et̶͡ʃ̶en̶] 'chechen'.
+|Ç ç ||Çe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ṯ͡ʃ̱/ as in '''''ç'''a-'''ç'''a'' [ṯ͡ʃ̱ɑṯ͡ʃ̱ɑ] 'cha-cha' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /t̶͡ʃ̶/ as in '''''ç'''e'''ç'''en'' [t̶͡ʃ̶et̶͡ʃ̶en̶] 'chechen'.
 Common to Turkic languages, these sounds are quasi non-existent in Tatar spoken in Dobruja where they have shifted from «Ç» to «Ş». Therefore, although authentic, these sounds could be equally treated as academic.
 |-
 |D d ||De ||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: '''hard voiced dental stop''' /ḏ/ as in '''''d'''al'' [ḏɑḻ] 'branch' and the '''soft voiced dental stop'''/d̶/ as in '''''d'''eren'' [d̶er̶en̶] 'deep'.
llm_output:
Changed the representation of the vowel and consonantal sounds in the Tatar language section, specifically modifying the phonetic transcription of "sát" and "ç" sounds.

Not Weaponised – The changes appear to be technical adjustments to phonetic representations without any political or cultural implications.

-
 == Grammar ==
 The grammar of Crimean Tatar, like all Turkic languages, is [[Agglutinative language|agglutinating]],<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.33</ref> with the exclusive use of suffixing to express grammatical categories.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.85</ref>  Generally, suffixes are attached to the ends of word stems, although derivational [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]] makes uses of compounding as well.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.33</ref>  Overall, the grammatical structure of the language is similar to that of other West Kipchak varieties.<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.2</ref>  Crimean Tatar is a [[Pro-drop language|pro-drop]] language<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.99</ref> with a generally [[Subject-object-verb word order|SOV word order]].<ref>Kavitskaya 2010, p.84</ref>
llm_output:
Removed a section titled "Grammar" from the article.

Not Weaponised – The change is a removal of content without introducing any specific narrative or language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

-{{Duplication|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_Tatar_language#In_Dobruja|date=September 2023|dupe=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_Tatar_language#Dobrujan_Tatar}}=== In Dobruja ===
-In [[Dobruja]] Crimean Tatars use '''Ĭ''' and '''W''', which is actually not found in Crimea. Ĭ is for [ı] sound (''Tĭl'' "language") and W for [w] sound (''Aywa'' "Quince"). Where in Crimea they use for [ı] and [i] the '''İ'''  letter (''Til'' "language") for [w] and [v] the '''V''' letter (''Ayva'' "Quince"). In dobruja they talk with  dialect which has some differences from the standard dialect. The dialect is Kipchak-Nogai which includes also Kazakh, Nogai and Karakalpak. There are very similarities with Nogai, Kazakh and Karakalpak. Sometimes they have letter changes like y → c (yaz - caz "summer"), f → p (fil → pĭl "elephant"), ç → ş (kiçkene → kĭşkene "small").

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تلی}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تلی}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]]. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تلی}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تلی}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:

Not Weaponised – The changes made are factual updates regarding the geographical and diaspora context of the Crimean Tatar language without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تلی}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تلی}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]]. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
Removed a sentence that included information about the Crimean Tatar language being spoken in the Crimean Tatar diasporas of Uzbekistan, Turkey, Romania, and Bulgaria.

Not Weaponised – The change appears to be a factual correction rather than an attempt to manipulate cultural narratives or heritage.

{{flag|Autonomous Republic of Crimea}}{{cite web|title=To which languages does the Charter apply?|page=2|url=http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|work=European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages|publisher=Council of Europe|access-date=2014-04-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227174247/http://hub.coe.int/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d74fc9bd-0c0c-40ac-9e47-26d4887daf8e&groupId=10227|archive-date=2013-12-27|url-status=dead}} (Ukraine) +| minority = {{flag|Romania}}{{cite web|url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/conventions/full-list/-/conventions/treaty/148/declarations?p_auth=63PpH3zN|title=Reservations and Declarations for Treaty No.148 – European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages|work=[[Council of Europe]]|access-date=28 December 2016|archive-date=8 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208122308/http://www.coe.int/en/web/conventions/full-list/-/conventions/treaty/148/declarations?p_auth=63PpH3zN|url-status=live}} ([[Dobrujan Tatar dialect|Dobrujan Tatar]]) | iso2 = crh | iso3 = crh | map = Crymean Tatar lang.png @@ -728,6 +728,100 @@ '''гъ''', '''къ''', '''нъ''' and '''дж''' are separate letters ([[digraph (orthography)|digraphs]]). +== Dobrujan Tatar == +{{Main|Dobrujan Tatar dialect}} +[[File:Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania.jpg|thumb|Alphabet of the Tatars in Romania]] +Dobrujan Tatar or Romanian Tatar (''Tatarşa'' or ''Tatar tílí''; {{lang-ro|limba tătară}}) is the Tatar language of [[Romania]]. It includes [[Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar]] and [[Nogai language|Nogai]] dialects,https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287996468_Ekstra_Kucuk_Bir_Dil_Olarak_Romanya_Tatar_Turkcesi_As_an_Extra_Small_Language_Romania_Tatar_Turkish[https://www.academia.edu/20136476/THE_TURKISH_LANGUAGE_SPOKEN_BY_THE_TURK_TATAR_COMMUNITY_LIVING_IN_ROMANIA THE TURKISH LANGUAGE SPOKEN BY THE TURK-TATAR COMMUNITY LIVING IN ROMANIA]{{Cite web|url=http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php|title=Общие сведения о татарах Добруджи|website=Академия наук Республики Татарстан|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220119184546/http://antat.ru/ru/academy/international/romania/information.php}}{{Cite web|lang=ru|url=https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3|title=Дунайские или румынские татары. Откуда взялись и как живут в настоящее время|website=|access-date=2022-01-19|archive-date=2022-01-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220118194703/https://zen.yandex.ru/media/turks/dunaiskie-ili-rumynskie-tatary-otkuda-vzialis-i-kak-jivut-v-nastoiascee-vremia-5f789651952c3b370ec526f3}}{{cite news|url=https://tatar-inform.tatar/news/taner-murat-dobrudzha-tatarlaryny-un-yashlek-balalary-tatarcha-irken-s-yl-sh-bel-5082672|title=Танер Мурат: Добруджа татарларының ун яшьлек балалары татарча иркен сөйләшә белә|publisher=Tatar-inform|date=24 April 2018|language=tt}} but today there are no more longer sharp distinction between this dialects and it's mostly seen as a one language.{{cite web | url=https://www.academia.edu/19984869 | title=Romanian Tatar language communication in the multicultural space | last1=Ismail | first1=Nilghiun }}[https://www.academia.edu/36788619/The_Sounds_of_Tatar_Spoken_in_Romania_The_Golden_Khwarezmian_Language_of_the_Nine_Noble_Nations The Sounds of Tatar Spoken in Romania: The Golden Khwarezmian Language of the Nine Noble Nations (Academia.edu)] This language belongs to [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic languages]], specifically to Kipchak-Nogai and is influenced by [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. + +=== Dialects === +Tatar language in Romania has three dialects:Eker, Süer (2006). [http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf Ekstra küçük bir dil olarak Romanya "Tatar Türkçesi"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417073058/http://www.edebiyatdergisi.hacettepe.edu.tr/2006232suereker.pdf |tarih=17 Nisan 2012 }} + +# The Şól dialect (''Şól tílí'') spoken by about 70% of Romanian Tatars. It's spoken mainly in the south and center of [[Constanța]] and has been heavily influenced by [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz]]. +# The Nogay dialect (''Nogay tílí'') spoken by about 20% of Romanian Tatars. It's spoken in [[Tulcea]], near and far north of [[Constanța]], and is the most conservative in preserving [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak]] elements. +# The Yalîbolu dialect (''Yalîbolu tílí'') spoken by about 10% of Romanian Tatars. It's spoken around the cities of Hacıoğlu Pazarcık ([[Dobrich]]) and is the closest to [[Oghuz languages]]. + +They differ mainly in pronunciation, and to some extent in vocabulary. + +=== Alphabet === +In 1956 is a Latin alphabet developed by the Institute of Linguistics of the Romanian Academy for the Tatar language in Romania, with the letters Á á, Č č/Ç ç, Ğ ğ/C c, Î î/I ı, Í í/Ĭ ĭ, Ñ ñ, Ó ó/Ö ö, Ș ș, Ț ț/Ts ts, Ú ú/Ü ü. The sounds for the letters î, ș and ț are from the Romanian alphabet. The sounds for the letters č, ğ, j, ñ, w and y are from a variety of languages. A new orthography was developed in 2010, which is now used by [[Democratic Union of Turkic-Muslim Tatars of Romania|UDTTMR]].{{cite book|title=ALFABE|location=Constanța|publisher=Editura Imperium|year=2015|page=[https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1795600770673670&set=ma-_-_-me-_-_-%C5%9Fa-_-_-ta-_-_-qirimtatartiliuyrenemiztatarlar-tatars-%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%80-tata 78]|isbn=978-606-93788-8-5|author1=Ismail H. A. Ziyaeddin |author2=Ali Cafer Ahmet-Naci |author3=Nida Ablez |author4=Risa Iusein }} Other alphabets was used by the writer [[Taner Murat]].[https://vebuka.com/print/170114173422-ad31c61dd7cdb69da4eb87d4e7c5f93e/Luceafarul_-_Sholpan_by_Mihai_Eminescu The translation of the book "''Luceafărul''" (Mihai Eminescu) by Taner Murat with this scripts][https://sites.google.com/site/tanermuratkitap/ro/alphabet Latin alphabet used by Taner Murat] The Latin alphabet that he did use was from the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Literatures from the University of Bucharest, with the letters Á, Ç, Ğ, Ñ, Î, Í, Ó, Ş, Ú. He did also use the Cyrillic script including the letters Ә, Җ, І, Ң, Ө, Ү, Ў. Also the [[Old Turkic script]] and the [[Persian alphabet|Perso-Arabic script]], with the letter ڭ. + +{| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-feature-settings:'cv50' 1;" +|- +!Latin character +!Name +!Sound description and pronunciation +|- +|A a ||A ||This letter represents the '''low unrounded RTR or hard''' vowel /ɑ/ as in '''''a'''n'''a''''' [ɑṉɑ] 'mother'. +|- +|Á á||Hemzelí A||This letter occurring in a limited number of Arabic and Persian loanwords represents the '''near-low unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel not belonging to authentic Tatar language /æ/ as in ''s'''á'''t'' [s̶æ̶t̶] 'hour', 'clock'. +|- +|B b ||Be||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced bilabial stop''' /ḇ/ as in '''''b'''al'' [ḇaḻ] 'honey' and the '''soft voiced bilabial stop''' /b̶/ as in '''''b'''el'' [b̶el̶] 'waist'. +|- +|Ç ç ||Çe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̱/ as in '''''ç'''a-'''ç'''a'' [ṯ͡ʃ̱ɑṯ͡ʃ̱ɑ] 'cha-cha' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar affricate''' /ç̶/ as in '''''ç'''e'''ç'''en'' [t̶͡ʃ̶et̶͡ʃ̶en̶] 'chechen'. +Common to Turkic languages, these sounds are quasi non-existent in Tatar spoken in Dobruja where they have shifted from «Ç» to «Ş». Therefore, although authentic, these sounds could be equally treated as academic. +|- +|D d ||De ||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: '''hard voiced dental stop''' /ḏ/ as in '''''d'''al'' [ḏɑḻ] 'branch' and the '''soft voiced dental stop'''/d̶/ as in '''''d'''eren'' [d̶er̶en̶] 'deep'. +|- +|E e ||E ||This letter represents the '''mid unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel /e/ as in ''s'''e'''n [s̶en̶] 'you'. +|- +|F f ||Fe ||This letter occurs only in loanwords for it represents sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar language. In authentic reading the foreign sound is naturalized and the letter reads as letter «P». In academic reading it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless labio-dental fricative''' [f̱] as in '''''f'''al'' [f̱ɑḻ] 'destiny' and the '''soft voiceless labio-dental fricative''' [f̶] as in '''''f'''en'' [f̶en̶] 'technics'. +|- +|G g ||Ge||This letter represents the '''soft voiced palatal stop''' [ɟ̱] as in '''''g'''ene'' [ɟ̱en̶e] 'again', 'still' with its allophone the '''soft voiced velar stop''' /g/ as in '''''g'''úl'' [gu̶l̶] 'flower', 'rose'. It also represents the '''hard voiced uvular fricative''' /ʁ/ as in '''''g'''am'' [ʁɑm] 'grief'. +|- +|Ğ ğ ||Ğe||The letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced palato-alveolar affricate'''/ḏ͡ʒ̱/ as in '''''ğ'''ar'' [ḏ͡ʒ̱ɑṟ] 'abyss' and the '''soft voiced palato-alveolar affricate'''/d̶͡ʒ̶/ as in '''''ğ'''er'' [d̶͡ʒ̶er̶] 'place', 'ground'. +|- +|H h ||He||Representing sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar language this letter occurs only in loanwords. Most often, in authentic reading, when it reproduces the Arabic or Persian ه‍ it is a silent letter or, if it is located at the beginning or end of the word, the sound is usually naturalized and the letter reads as letter «K». When it reproduces ح or خ the sound is usually naturalized as /q/. In academic reading it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless glottal fricative''' /h/ as in ''ta'''h'''t'' [ṯɑhṯ] 'throne' and the '''soft voiceless uvular fricative''' /χ/ as in '''''h'''eşt'' [χeʃ̶t̶] 'eight'. +|- +|I i ||I||The letter represents the '''hight unrounded ATR or soft''' vowel /i/ as in ''b'''i'''ñ'' [b̶iŋ] 'thousand'. +|- +|Í í ||Hemzelí I, Kîska I, Zayîf I||This letter represents the '''hight unrounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ɨ/ as in ''b'''í'''r'' [b̶ɨr̶] 'one' is specific to Tatar. +At the end of the word it is pronounced with half open mouth undergoing dilatation "''Keñiytúw''" and becoming '''mid unrounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' /ə/, also known as schwa, as in ''t'''í'''l'''í''''' [t̶ɨl̶ə] 'his tongue'. +|- +|Î î ||Kalpaklî I, Tartuwlî I ||This letter represents the '''hight unrounded RTR or hard''' vowel /ɯ/ as in '''''î'''şan'' [ɯʃ̱ɑṉ] 'mouse'. +At the end of the word it is pronounced with half open mouth shifting through dilatation "''Keñiytúw''" to '''mid unrounded RTR or hard''' /ɤ/, close to schwa, as in ''ş'''î'''lapş'''î''''' [ʃ̱ɯḻɑp̱ʃ̱ɤ] 'trough'. +|- +|J j ||Je||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced palato-alveolar affricate''' /ʒ̱/ as in ''ta'''j''''' [ṯɑʒ̱] 'crown' and the '''soft voiced palato-alveolar affricate''' /ʒ̶/ as in ''be'''j''''' [b̶eʒ̶] 'beige'. +|- +|K k ||Ke||This letter represents the '''soft voiceless palatal stop''' /c/ as in '''''k'''el'' [cel̶] 'come!' and its allophone the '''soft voiceless velar stop''' /k/ as in '''''k'''ól'' [kɵl̶] 'lake'. It also represents the '''hard voiceless uvular stop''' /q/ as in '''''k'''al'' [qɑḻ] 'stay!'. +|- +|L l ||Le||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard alveolar lateral aproximant''' /ḻ/ as in ''ba'''l''''' [ḇɑḻ] 'honey' and the '''soft alveolar lateral aproximant''' /l̶/ as in ''be'''l''''' [b̶el̶] 'waist'. +|- +|M m ||Me||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard bilabial nasal''' /m̱/ as in '''''m'''aga'' [m̱ɑʁɑ] 'to me' and the '''soft bilabial nasal''' /m̶/ as in '''''m'''en'' [m̶en̶] 'I'. +|- +|N n ||Ne||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard dental nasal''' /ṉ/ as in ''a'''n'''a'' [ɑṉɑ] 'mother' and the '''soft dental nasal''' /n̶/ as in '''''n'''e'' [n̶e] 'what'. +|- +|Ñ ñ ||Eñ, Dalgalî Ne||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard uvular nasal''' /ɴ/ as in ''a'''ñ''''' [ɑɴ] 'conscience' and the '''soft velar nasal''' /ŋ/ as in ''e'''ñ''''' [eŋ] 'most'. +|- +|O o ||O||This letter represents the '''mid rounded RTR or hard''' vowel /o/ as in ''b'''o''''' [ḇo] 'this'. +|- +|Ó ó ||Noktalî O||This letter represents the '''mid rounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ɵ/ as in ''t'''ó'''r'' [t̶ɵr̶] 'background'. +|- +|P p ||Pe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless bilabial stap''' /p̱/ as in ''ğa'''p''''' [ḏ͡ʒ̱ɑp̱] 'close!' and the '''soft voiceless bilabial stop''' /p̶/ as in ''ğe'''p''''' [d̶͡ʒ̶ep̶] 'pocket'. +|- +|R r ||Re||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard alveolar trill''' /ṟ/ as in ''ta'''r''''' [ṯɑṟ] 'narrow' and the '''soft alveolar trill''' /r̶/ as in ''te'''r''''' [t̶er̶] 'sweat'. +|- +|S s ||Se||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless alveolar fricative''' /s̱/ as in '''''s'''al'' [s̱ɑḻ] 'raft' and the '''soft voiceless alveolar fricative''' /s̶/ as in '''''s'''el'' [s̶el̶] 'flood'. +|- +|Ş ş ||Şe||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless palato-alveolar fricative''' /ʃ̱/ as in '''''ş'''a'''ş''''' [ʃ̱ɑʃ̱] 'spread!' and the '''soft voiceless palato-alveolar fricative''' /ʃ̶/ as in '''''ş'''e'''ş''''' [ʃ̶eʃ̶] 'untie'. +|- +|T t ||Te||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiceless dental stop''' /ṯ/ as in '''''t'''ar'' [ṯɑṟ] 'tight', 'narrow' and the '''soft voiceless dental stop''' /t̶/ as in '''''t'''er'' [t̶er̶] 'sweat'. +|- +|U u ||U||This letter represents the '''hight rounded RTR or hard''' vowel /u/ as in '''''u'''n'' [uṉ] 'flour'. +|- +|Ú ú ||Noktalî U||This letter represents the '''hight rounded half-advanced ATR or soft''' vowel /ʉ/ as in ''s'''ú'''t'' [s̶ʉt̶] 'milk'. +In the vicinity of semivowel y, which occurs rarely, its articulation shifts to '''high rounded ATR or soft''' /y/, close to Turkish pronunciation, as in ''s'''ú'''ymek'' [s̶ym̶ec] 'to love'. +|- +|V v ||Ve||This letter occurs only in loanwords for it represents sounds that do not belong to authentic Tatar spoken in Romania. In authentic reading the foreign sound is naturalized and the letter reads sometimes as «W», sometimes as «B». In academic it represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced labio-dental fricative''' /v̱/ as in '''''v'''als'' [v̱ɑḻs̱] 'waltz' and the '''soft voiced labio-dental fricative''' /v̶/ as in '''''v'''e'' [v̶e] 'and'. +|- +|W w ||We||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard labio-velar semivowel''' /w̱/ as in ''ta'''w''''' [ṯɑw̱] 'forest', 'mountain' and the '''soft labio-velar semivowel''' /w̶/ as in ''te'''w''''' [t̶ew̶] 'central', 'fundamental'. +|- +|Y y ||Ye||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard palatal semivowel''' /y̱/ as in ''ta'''y''''' [ṯɑy̱] 'foal' and the '''soft palatal semivowel''' /y̶/ as in '''''y'''er'' [y̶er̶] 'place', 'ground'. +|- +|Z z ||Ze||This letter represents two distinctive consonantal sounds: the '''hard voiced alveolar fricative''' /ẕ/ as in ''ta'''z''''' [ṯɑẕ] 'bald' and the '''soft voiced alveolar fricative''' /z̶/ as in ''te'''z''''' [t̶ez̶] 'quick'. +|} + +[[File:TanerMuratABC.jpg|thumb|Latin and Cyrillic alphabets used by [[Taner Murat]]]] + ==Legal status== The Crimean peninsula is internationally recognized as territory of Ukraine, but since the 2014 [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation by the Russian Federation]] is de facto administered as part of the Russian Federation.
comment: Restoring revision 1178605825 by Mellk: A large amount of mostly sourced content has been deleted by Zolgoyo without a discussion or edit summary. I don't see a reason why this content should be removed, will be reinstating and pinging Zolgoyo. [[w:en:WP:RW|(RW 16.1)]]
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a section titled "Dobrujan Tatar," which includes detailed information about the Dobrujan Tatar language, its dialects, and its alphabet. 

Weaponised

Justification: The addition of this section may serve to highlight the cultural and linguistic identity of the Tatar community in Romania, which can be seen as a counter-narrative to the dominant perspectives regarding the Tatar heritage in Crimea. This could be interpreted as an attempt to assert the legitimacy and recognition of Tatar culture in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions.

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

==Links==
[[http://tatar.net]]

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تلی}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تلی}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تلی}}}}),{{efn|Dobrujan Tatar: {{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|kîrîm tatar tílí}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|кырым татар тілі}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قِرِمْ تَاتَارْ تِلِى}}}}}} also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تلی}}}}),{{efn|Dobrujan Tatar: {{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|kîrîm tílí}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|кырым тілі}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قِرِمْ تِلِى}}}}}}<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]].
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>

initial_version:
'''Crimean Tatar language''' is a language of '''[[Crimean Tatars]]''', sometimes considered as dialect of [[Tatar language]]. This language is something meiddle of Kazan Tatar and Turkish. Total spokers: nearly 400,000: 250,000 in [[Republic of Crimea]], ~ 200,000 was in [[Uzbekistan]] before [[ethnic cleans]], nealy 3,000 in [[Russia]]. More than 1,500,000 inhabitants of [[Turkey]] are Turkish-speaking Crimean Tatars emigrated in 19th century. Crimean Tatars of Turkey mostly can speak Crimean Tatar.

Crimean Tatar in native language of [[Çobanzade]].

It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]] and also mutually intelligible with each of these languages, to varying degrees.
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
Rephrased a sentence to include "and also mutually intelligible with each of these languages, to varying degrees."

Not Weaponised. The change provides additional linguistic information without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

-'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تلی}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تلی}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]] and is also mutually intelligible with them, to varying degrees.
+'''Crimean Tatar''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırımtatar tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырымтатар тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تاتار تلی}}}}), also called '''Crimean''' ({{lang|crh|{{lang|crh-Latn|qırım tili}}, {{lang|crh-Cyrl|къырым тили}}, {{lang|crh-Arab|قریم تلی}}}}),<ref name=e25/> is a [[Kipchak languages|Kipchak Turkic language]] spoken in [[Crimea]] and the [[Crimean Tatar diaspora]]s of [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], and [[Bulgaria|Bulgaria.]], as well as small communities in the United States and Canada. It should not be confused with [[Tatar language|Tatar]], spoken in [[Tatarstan]] and adjacent regions in [[Russia]]; the two languages are related, but belong to different subgroups of the [[Kipchak languages]], while maintaining a significant degree of [[mutually intelligible|mutual intelligibility]]. Crimean Tatar has been extensively influenced by nearby [[Oghuz languages|Oghuz dialects]] and is also mutually intelligible with them, to varying degrees.
 
 A long-term ban on the study of the Crimean Tatar language following the [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars]] by the Soviet government has led to the fact that at the moment [[UNESCO]] ranked the Crimean Tatar language among the languages under serious threat of extinction (''severely endangered'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|accessdate=Mar 3, 2021|archive-date=August 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802160530/http://www.unesco.org/languages-atlas/index.php?hl=en&page=atlasmap|url-status=live}}</ref>
